15.description: This was delicious! I always walk by here but somehow never noticed this place before.Service was great, and both the enchiladas and the mango margarita were awesome.

57.description: Unfortunately things haven't gotten any better.  Pitcher of sangria came with no glasses, asked for glasses three times.  Got them myself whilst only available waitress (or so it seemed at least) was playing with someone's baby.  Another customer at the bar was quite irate about his order, I said nothing, I wasn't going to add fuel to the fire.   So after two requests to place an order, both times being told "I'll be right back", by that very waitress, and being in the building an estimated 72 minutes, we left.  The food is good, and I really hate giving places a bad review.  I like to support local business, and I like having a Mexican restaurant in the neighborhood with very good food, but the service is atrocious.

20.description: We are so glad to have a great Mexican restaurant in the neighborhood.  The service, food, and margaritas are excellent!  Highly, highly recommend the Carne Mas Alla Del Sol!

36.description: Best skirt steak I've ever had. Great service!

14.description: I have visited this restaurant twice. The first time was one a whim, and boy were we happy to make the trip! Both of us are first generation Mexicans in the US so are well versed with the Mexican cuisine. They do AUTHENTIC Mexican with an emphasis on quality. A higher end Mexican Restaurant if you will, so you won't be finding any over greased, sloppily put together dishes. Nor is this the kind of upscale place that completely changes the cuisine.. it has it's own modern style but stays TRUE to the cuisine, and everything one looks for in this kind of comfort food. I had the Chile Relleno, and my boyfriend had the steak (cooked perfectly). We were both wowed! (It's not every Mexican restaurant that can pull off a great Chille Relleno --the closest I've had to my momma's!). Flavors are great, service is friendly, and I LOVE that the owner usually makes his way through the restaurant. We will be back.

28.description: The best second hand shop in the worrrllldddd!!!! You can find amazing deals there and the stuff is clean and in good shape. Nothing is over priced and you can always make an offer if you think it is.

1.description: The good cause/ public benefit nature of this store bumps it up from what would ordinarily be a three star for me.  A lot of the bigger pieces are a bit overpriced for what you get which makes me hesitant to purchase anything there, but, as with any thrift store, there's a treasure trove that needs to be discovered through careful digging and constant browsing.The biggest problem I have is with the customer service.  It is incredibly inconsistent and more often than not, it doesn't exist.  There have been plenty of times in the past couple of months where I've been in there to drop items off and have had no direction from the staff, not a word said to me, and no help offered to bring bags and bags of clothing and item in.  The donation drop-off needs to be better marked and there needs to be someone who is committed and dedicated to receiving items.

39.description: This review is entirely about the pick up donation process.I just moved and had a bunch of stuff to donate.  I looked online for places that would come pick up a donation for me since there was a sofa and I also was looking to exert as little effort as possible.  I submitted an online form at both Brown Elephant and the Salvation Army.  BE called me back immediately to set up an appointment, I never heard back from SA.  The soonest Saturday that worked for me was about 3 weeks out, so planning ahead would be key if you don't have storage space in the meantime (which I do so not a problem)  They gave me a window of 10-1.The day of the donation they called me at 9 to tell me they would be there between 12 and 1 and ask where they should bring the truck (alley).  Two guys arrived promptly at 12:15 and loaded everything up in less than 15 minutes.  They were really friendly and polite and efficient!Overall, this was a stellar experience - I'd have been willing to pay to have someone come get all this stuff out of my basement, but instead, not only did BE do it for free, but I also had the opportunity to support a great charity!Thanks, Brown Elephant!  You'll be my go-to donation spot forever more.

9.description: I am a thrift store fan, and I love that this location is set up in an old movie theatre. I will say, however, that I don't really seem to find anything I like most times I stop in. The clothing selection is sparse, and I find myself hard-pressed to find a book I want to take home, even at their very reasonable prices.The staff is very friendly, and I do occasionally find a gem in the DVD bins, but nothing else really grabs me here. I guess that's the fun of thrifting though, coming back until you find that magical item that destiny steers your way.

29.description: Just moved to Andersonville from the Lakeview area, so I'm used to their Brown Elephant. I stopped in at my new one this weekend and was pleasantly surprised. This one is cleaner (and somewhat cheaper, unless I'm crazy) than the Brown Elephant in Lakeview. The selection seems to be curated here, where the Lakeview store is all over the place and kind of a mess. I love that in a thrift store, but it's nice to know that I can walk into this one and find quality stuff. I grabbed two matching bowls for $3 and a stack of six or so books for way cheap. Grand total = $7.10. Hell yes.

23.description: I have gone here multiple times--always hopeful for a different experience.  However, I usually find myself laughing at the high prices and leaving empty-handed.  Andersonville has so many great thrift stores and antique shops to choose from...Brown Elephant just can't compete.  Most recently I stopped by to look for old picture frames for a project I was working on--I found the average price of a beat up 4x6 frame was about $5.  Really?  I think you can buy a brand new frame for that much at Target.  They have a wide selection of books which are priced well (0.25-$1), but that's really the only section I would recommend.  Even their kitchen selection is comprised of miscellaneous cups and mugs for $3 each.  With all the other stores to choose from, Brown Elephant needs to be a little more reasonable with their pricing--they'd have a lot more business!

5.description: Everything is extremely overpriced. I laughed when I saw a used scratched up Nintendo wii selling for $60. For that price I would rather go to ebay and get a brand new one for the same price with all the accessories. What a joke and a rip off...Sooner or later, they will go out of business.Good Riddins

31.description: On Saturday my husband and i were around the neighborhood and we decided to check this place out. You never know what treasure you might find in a thrift shop. We went in and everyone in line and on the counter stare at us like we were some kind of aliens from another planet!. I should of taken that as bad sign and walk right out. Since we didn't care we walked in an looked around their clothes selection is about 4 little racks here and there nothing BIG. The racks has signs 2 dollar shirts 4 dollar long shirts 6 dollar sweaters. I found 2 cute shirts and i said 2 dollars each why not. A few minutes later the girl announce that they were closing and we walk to the longgggggg line to the "register" everyone was paying cheap stuff for the items they had picked up. So it was our turn, there were 2 guys one African American in the register and an older man that looked Native American with a navy sweat shirt. He looked and me and my husband up and down i guess to decide the price and he told me the shirts were 6 dollars each. I mean really nothing in your racks said 6 dollar shirt only sweaters and i told him about the signs on top of the racks and he said 6 dollars each!!!  I bought them because i was in line for so long. But i will never go back to this place. If you look put together or decent do not go here they will charge you and arm and a leg. If you look like you slept on the street and walked in to the store you will get everything CHEAP... HORRIBLE CUSTOMER SERVICE

25.description: The Brown Elephant of Andyville is an excellent way to kill an afternoon perusing things you probably do not need. They have a really impressive book selection that is constantly being replenished. I've recently been spending way too much time scouring their book selection and getting great books for $1. The thrill of the hunt is addictive, I can never buy another book at full price again. They also have a really nice selection of dishware, kitchen items and knickknacks. You never really need more tea cups but how can you resist for a few bucks? I can't. Their furniture is worth looking at if you are in the market for a couch or a dining room table but the competition for the best furniture seems pretty steep among shoppers and I am not prepared to lay on top of a dining room table to claim it as my own. They have a small-ish selection of decent looking clothes but the prices aren't dirt cheap like at Village Discount Outlet several blocks south on Clark.The staff is extremely friendly, the entire complex is very clean and well organized. Some things may be a bit overpriced but all in all I think it's pretty fair. Plus you are giving your money to a good charity when all is said and done. For me Brown Elephant is all about the books. I love this place!

12.description: The space is unique and beautiful.  The furniture can be interesting.  However, the customer service is non-existent (not like I expect much from a thrift store, but still...) and the prices on furniture are a joke.  Honestly, it seems like you are being punked the prices are that outrageous.  Even with the funds going to a good cause, this is a thrift store, not an antique mall.  Pass.  No need to ever go back.

37.description: I love the Brown Elephant and all that it stands for. I first stumbled upon the resale shop a few years ago, and my intention to just browse ended up in a purchase that greatly expanded my record collection, but cost me next to nothing. I have also donated several larger items to Brown Elephant, and have always had an easy time scheduling pick-ups around my crazy schedule. Every employee I've crossed paths with has been very friendly and helpful.

21.description: Great second hand store for furniture.  They have good inventory here and I believe you can bargain.  They also have clothes and accessories.  Things are organized and easy to get around.  They also have a seasonal section.

16.description: I have always had  good experiences at the Brown Elephant but today was pretty outstanding. Willie, a store rep. Helped me to measure, try out if a piece of furniture would fit in my car, load the furniture into my car, and set up my sale. He was wonderful! I love my beautiful piece of furniture!! Thank you, Willie!

17.description: This place has great prices on furniture! They are willing to bargain too! I haven't found anything I want to buy there yet, but I'm going to keep coming back to look.

10.description: I always come to the brown elephant optimistic that I'll find a hidden gem, but so far have left empty handed. I'm usually here to look at the furniture selection, and so far the sparse offerings have missed the mark. There are some great deals to be had, like the overstuffed chair and matching ottoman for $50 that I saw last time. But there's just something a little dated and clunky about a lot of the furniture here that have left me somewhat disappointed each time...

11.description: I always find something interesting here. It's not the best place for a huge selection of clothes, but is great for random home items and furniture. I've found some really unique original art here as well. Plus, there's always great music playing, which gives the place a friendly, upbeat vibe. Prices aren't super cheap for a second hand store, but proceeds help fund medical care for the uninsured .

26.description: Overpriced. I went looking to teacups and teapots for an Alice in Wonderland themed party I'm planning, and they wanted between $10 and $20 for a teapot. Ummm, if I wanted to pay that much for a teapot, I'd go to Target.

27.description: I emailed the Brown Elephant to schedule a furniture donation pick up. It was very easy online and they confirmed via email and gave me available date options and told me exactly when they would call and provide me a 1hr window.  It all went as they stated, the only glitch was they ended up with a full truck from earlier pick ups and had to unload before they arrived at my place but overall it was a great experience and for a good cause.  I would recommend.

35.description: Love this iteration of the BE.  It is always a fun experience going there. Makes it even more fun, as the proceeds support a great cause.

8.description: To all those people complaining about how overpriced Howard Brown is. Let me remind you it's a charity folks! God forbid you donate a little extra money to a organization that does a lot of good. If you want something for nothing maybe you should try dumpster diving.

0.description: It's a beautiful place. I love second hand stores. The Interior is worth seeing if you are a fan of old buildings. I never got lucky on video game stuff here, you just got to be lucky on what comes in. I found an awesome DVD set for my dad and the next day it was gone. Duh, silly me. Anyway. As a Wiccan I got lucky on finding a very particular item. My daughter was the one to spot it out as it was on display to be sold for Halloween season. I guess the dude who worked there knew I had something precious in my hand that was marked 5 dollars. He seen me through his Fabulous gray hair almost covering his eyes... I Seen't it.I put it back on the shelf and wandered off with my 3 year old daughter to find the wife and beg to buy this Witchy thing. Wife seemed interested too... Jackpot! We return and it's not on display anymore. All of us were like "Oh Well."But upon returning back to browsing... The Witchy thing was in a pile to be Re-Priced... OH NO!! And I knew it was Mr. Fabulous's idea. He knew I needed it. It was my precious. Well... My daughter was quick because she recognized it and grabbed it before it could be unfairly Re-Priced. Shame on that Man. But my Wife loves the place and I do too. That was my only incident ever and it would of got a 5 Star review but 4 is still good. I will for sure get some furniture from here and check back as much as I can for goodies.

38.description: I'm a big fan of Brown Elephant for many reasons.  While I have it on high authority that the Boystown location is better for certain men's fashion items, I've always been pleasantly surprised by hidden gems at this Andersonville store.The venue itself is one of the highlights.  Located in a historic theater, there is more than enough room on the showroom floor for all of the donated furniture.  When moving into a new apartment in the area, I was able to find a number of affordable pieces in acceptable condition.It is also incredibly easy to donate any unwanted items.  I've given a few bags of clothing and other miscellaneous items in the past few months.  Not only can you feel good about donating to support a worthy cause, but they'll also hook you up with a coupon to save 25% off your next order.

20.description: Love this place! Before my move to Chicago I did my research on thrift stores and was lucky enough to move into a place within walking distance of this gem! On my third day in the city I decided to venture out and I ended up buying a complete dish set and a beer mug for $18. Not bad. The prices are great and the staff is friendly. Great furniture and awesome book selection - quarter books!

19.description: Went shopping today for furniture. Ended up find a nice couch for $125 (they dropped the price to $100), but once we got it into the car, we realized the bottom was broken. They told us they don't normally do refunds, but since it just happened, they would allow it. They even help you load & unload furniture. They gave me my money back. The only thing I'm disappointed about was that it was broken, but they were super nice & helpful. I will definitely be returning.

33.description: Parking is hard to find!... but once inside, you might find some deals you like. Some priced reasonably and some a little over-priced. I wanted office chairs that they had-- wasn't new or in excellent condition-- but I had doubt about its durability for the price. Nonetheless, I went home with one pretty shirt for a very good deal. I think I'll be back again when I'm in the area.

2.description: New to Chicago I was told to visit this location and check-out their selection for possible furniture finds. I thought it was great that much of the money goes to funding a good charity. Now the selection were fair, nothing amazing. The pieces were of "Good Will" standard which was fine. Then I saw the prices and like some of the other reviews on here-I was slightly shocked that some of the prices seem a bit inflated for the item. I think their appraiser might want to do some research to get an appropriate price-point.All-in-all, If all your looking for are some tchotchkes then stop by on a lazy Sunday, other then that I can't imagine finding a great furniture pieces at the right price.Maybe their second location might have a better selection.

34.description: While this place has a smaller selection of clothes and shoes than Goodwill, and is also slightly pricier, the money goes towards a good cause. I think they have staff that actually will research the donations, especially the furniture and price them near or slightly below market value (vs Goodwill where everything is a set price.) I saw an almost new espresso maker that was gone when I did a second lap 10 minutes later. The store itself is located in this old theater, which gives it a grand old air.

32.description: The joys of thrift store shopping - hours spent rifling through used books, kitchenware, art posters, clothes, daydreaming about making-over the second-hand furniture.  If you're like me, it's an afternoon well spent; a little piece of heaven.   Affordable, of course, and all of the money goes to a good cause, so if you buy something you like, there's a good karma bonus!So why only three stars?  Because I recently walked into the Brown El and almost had a panic attack - the store was half empty!!  I ran over to an employee and asked if they were going out of business.  He said no, but that they were trying to focus on quality rather than quantity.Quality over quantity?  At the Brown Elephant?  Are you insane?  No, no, no!!!  Gimme back my quantity!  I want those aisles PACKED to the rafters with goodies.  Part of the joy of thrift store hunting is the panning for gold - finding that gem that you just can't live without.  Why oh why the big change? This used to be the one place in town where a person could furnish a kitchen for a handful of bucks, and have a good time doing it - now we can only oggle stray pieces of fiestaware?And who exactly is pre-judging the so-called quality?  You know what they say about one man's trash ...   Please get this place fully stocked with mountains of stuff, like it used to be.  Do that, and I'll give ya yer 5 stars.

18.description: Awesome spot to find gems for your home.  The turnover in here is daily.  So if you need something and don't see it the first time just go back the following day.  There will be new stuff.I have purchased  a table, coat rack, dishes, clothes, and jewelry. All for dirt cheap like $20 or less per item.Now here are a few important things to know.  If you want to transport a piece of furniture you must have a means to get it to your home as they do not deliver items for you.  They do provide names and phone numbers for people you can call to deliver.  I got some guy  for $30 to deliver an item for me and he carried it up the three flights of stairs for me.Second, if you donate an item to them such as furniture, they will pick it up from your home.Third, the money they collect goes to HIV/AIDS Research at Howard Brown.Stop by.  You are bound to find a gem for you or someone else.

13.description: Just went for the first time. Stopped after visiting a couple of Salvation Army stores and thought this store was way more reasonably priced and had better quality items. I was surprised to read in some of these reviews that people felt the store was over priced. I actually had the opposite reaction. I plan on going back frequently...

4.description: A+ for their furniture. A++ for their proceeds going to Howard Brown. Also amazing - the people who work in the donation area! They never let you carry your own donations and are the friendliest people. Their clothing selection is solid, though smaller than the other location. It's also great for used queer books and DVDs! Sometimes their prices are a little expensive for me, but hey, I'm just thrifty.

24.description: Great prices, amazing selection on furniture and knick-knacks. I can't believe it took me so long to visit this place since I grew up in this neighborhood. First time there this weekend and already found two great furniture pieces (computer desk/console and tv stand) both in amazing condition for two amazing prices. I highly recommend this places. Especially because "the revenue generated by donations and purchases at the Brown Elephant Shops help fund services for the more than 50% of Howard Brown Health Center clients who are under or uninsured."AMAZING!!!

6.description: Pulled up to the loading dock to drop 15 bags of clothes as well as a couple of boxes. Pro: Nobody blinked an eye at the huge amount of stuff. One person in the area answered questions when we posed them. Con: The other person in the area didn't even make eye contact. Nobody went out of their way to be helpful. These two cons are the only reason I debated between 3 and 4 stars. I rounded up.Went in after the drop-off and parking (street parking which was fairly convenient considering what a bustling neighborhood this is). The space is totally cool; the building used to be a theater. The staff on the floor was friendly. I found a beautiful 100% silk necktie for $3.My family and I are doing a massive clean-out of our house. It's good to know that we can bring the stuff here. It's a well-run operation for a good cause.

22.description: Every time I go here, I am hoping to find something fun.  Instead, I am disappointed by high prices.  I'm sure that some people are willing to pay some sort of premium for used merchandise, but it won't be me.

15.description: This store is great for what it is. It happened to have a great 50% off furniture (wood only, I think) sale and I found a great TV stand for just $8.The service was fine, nothing special but friendly enough!The other location didn't seem as good but I also came away with a $40 desk that I look forward to using!

7.description: Ridiculous prices!!! Almost all books i looked at were around 6$, and checking on ebay reveals that you could buy them new with almost the same money!Clothes... oh well.. half of them didn't have tags on or the tags didn't have a price. When there was a price, it was on the high side and whenever I found a nice dress for 8$ (lowest price that there was on dresses) it had stains or rips in clearly visible places! I will never step into this place again. Even decorative items and cheap china was hugely overpriced.  I wouldn't even want to donate anything here, to be sold with ripoff prices..

36.description: Shortly before a move and after reading the reviews on Yelp, I e-mailed The Brown Elephant to pick up a futon and an old desk of my husbands. An employee provided me with a time frame on a Saturday - 9:00 AM to 12:00 PM. The movers showed up around 11:00 AM ish after calling around 9:00 AM to confirm the pick up. Three guys showed up, took our furniture and went on their way. They were courteous and professional. When you schedule a pick up, they request a small donation, which I had no problems with at all. I hope to use The Brown Elephant in the future. Great concept.

30.description: This place is great for when you want something new for your home, but you don't know what you want.  They have a large selection of plates, platters, glasses, furniture, artwork and furniture.  And they have lots of books, cd's, records, and oh yeah clothes, too.  The workers are friendly, and they make you want to donate your stuff here.  They even give a 25% off coupon to anyone who donates, and you can fill out a tax form easily while you're there.  They play at least one The Smiths song while you're in there, which just makes it that much more fun.

3.description: I have been coming to the Brown Elephant in this location for several years now. I always stop in when I'm in Andersonville, and never leave empty handed. Great quality furniture and decorations if you're into the antique/vintage stuff. I love that it is inside am old building with minimal remodeling, it really adds that extra touch to thrifting. I am always amazed at the sales I get. More recently, I got a pair of brand new Anthropologie pants for $3.... The original was......GUESS? Wait for it.................. $128!I rarely but brand new things, and usually get used items for even jewelry, and household furniture. This place is great.

14.description: Great place to find unique items for the home. At reasonable prices, too. Selection of items changes each time I visit. Staff very friendly and helpful. Will be a continuing shopper here for  many more return trips.

28.description: This store has been here for many years and it looks the same as it did way back then.  Over crowded shelves, too much product, narrow aisles, overworked butchers and lazy cashiers.  OK, they aren't lazy, just moving in slow motion.I like that they offer many varieties of Asian products, its a quick stop when you're in the need of something specific like chili hot sauce or a flavor of Soy.  They also offer different options when it comes to their butcher area, did you know that you can order your fish and then have them fry it for you also?I like that they have a special price on fish heads and tails. Not for me! For the dogs living at my house.  Fish is good for them and they don't charge you up the ass like some other butcher stores.  You can also usually find a good price on select meats and small fishes.  Again, I am super picky about the freshness of meat for myself, so I don't buy that from here for me.  For the dogs, sure, I'll get anything.  I picked up pork necks at 60 cents a pound the other day.  Some time ago I was in here with my Mom and we're nearing the checkout counter.  I'm thinking hmm, I wonder what Filipino candies might be waiting near the counter.  I wasn't surprised to find Nurse's uniforms on display, I knew my Ma was interested, so I let her get two new uniform tops.  She said to me, "This is the good material, it comes from Philippines.  I dunno if it does or not, these nurses uniforms were expensive.   There's a food area where you can get some everyday Filipino favorites.  Check it out if you're daring.

1.description: Went here for tamarind seasoning mix and ended up with that and a load of sweets. It hasn't set yet, a little soupy. Cassava cake was excellent, should've gotten 2. They had every kind of Skyflakes, except the original which is what I prefer. I didn't get anything in the cafe, but I will next time. The cashier was friendly.

9.description: Uni-Mart is located in my neighborhood and it's greatly convenient. I'm fan of the place. I love their home cooked food to take out. I don't know much about Filipino food but I see many similarity in Okinawan food, the ingredient, and cooked way. Especially vegetable dishes. It's Interesting.

29.description: When I'm craving some home cooking but have no desire to cook, I go here.  They have a small area in the back set up similar to a Panda Express where you order entrees ala carte.  You can almost always find lechon (roasted pork), lumpia (mini meat egg rolls), turon (banana egg rolls doused in melted sugar, TRY this!), chicken and pork bbq, and at least five other dishes.  They also have tables of other baked goods.  Never get the longonisa (sweet sausage) unless you enjoy biting into huge chunks of fat.  You're better off buying the frozen variety in the freezer (and for a lot cheaper).  The food is ok for a quick fix but definitely doesn't compare to anything my parents would cook (isn't this always the case).  Prices for the prepared food are fairly reasonable.  I've easily gotten enough food to feed 4 for roughly $20-25.Beyond the prepared foods, you can buy an assortment of other Filipino goods: prepared sauces, noodles, rice, frozen egg rolls, frozen meats, etc.  They also have a small variety of 'fresh' fish and vegetables.  The interior is fairly clean, but the aisles are a bit too close for comfort.  I tend to go on the weekends and the parking lot is always jam packed, yet it is still fairly easy to maneuver  yourself around the store.  Prices are pretty average.  Service is minimal but adequate.

23.description: Need to bring lumpias (aka FIlipino mini-eggrolls) to bring to your next family event? I'd suggest going to Uni-Mart - basically, the staple grocery store of most Filipino families living on the north side of the city.  They sell lumpias in the ready-made food section ($7.50/lb for about 25-30) as well as a variety of other Filipino dishes (turon, adobo, caldereta, lechon, bbq chicken, etc.).  If you want to place a larger order, you can always place the order a couple days ahead of time, so they can have it ready for pick-up right before your event.Plus, the grocery section basically has every FIlipino food items you could ever look for (shrimp chips, shrimp paste, pancit noodles, salted egg, pan de sal, calamansi juice, etc.). You can also buy frozen lumpias and then fry them yourself, if you're up to dealing with that daunting task.  I picked up $80 worth of food here for Thanksgiving and it was enjoyed by all! Note: They don't take Amex, but they do take personal checks. The parking lot may have the tendency to fill up on weekends and it's pretty difficult to maneuver around in because it's a little small.  Oh, and they apparently give you a free bottle of sweet and sour sauce with purchases over $50....Cute!

5.description: I tried really hard to love unimart, but there's so many things about it that annoy me. Food is great, taste is great, but service is sooooo incredibly sloooooow.  It takes any of the ladies fifteen minutes  to help one person with one order, unless you get a person ahead of the line that also happens to order the whole menu, the you're there at least half an hour.  Price wise, food is over priced compared to other restaurants in the area like isla or Ruby's.  I say if your desperate, go here, but if you want faster service and better food, look someplace else.

31.description: I went to the Unimart branch in Chicago, food was way to greasy and lacks flavor. Although they have the most variety of dry goods as well as they carry their own line of pastries, still does not capture the true Filipino taste I grew up with (eg. Goldilocks, Red Ribbon). I tried the Woodridge location, food was a little better but not great. Also not sure how long the mamon (sponge cake) was sitting on the shelves coz after a day I bought it was spoiled right away. Definitely not going back.

25.description: Okay, so 100th review I've reserved for sentimentality.  I love Uni-Mart and miss Uni-Mart.  It reminds me of childhood, driving to the market with Mom and Dad and picking out our favorite ingredients to make the most amazing Filipino dishes.  I can hear the clinking of pots and pans and the chopping of fresh vegetables now.  It also reminds me of my adulthood, living on my own, and feeling the perfect elation and freedom of gaining personal space, the freedom of being in my neighborhood of choice, and the freedom to do whatever I wish in my kitchen -- creating that familiar symphony of kitchen sounds with my own two hands, my own sense of taste and smell, but the tradition of family secrets.  Being walking distance from Uni-Mart was an amazing luxury that lasted a short, but much-appreciated time.  They have everything I need to mirror my mom and grandma's best.  And if I don't feel particularly kitchen savvy, they have deliciously prepared Filipino favorites in the back like pancit, kare kare, crispy pata, and humongous, tasty egg rolls!  I regret that I live so far from Uni-Mart now, but I can easily get back into the car (with me driving this time, instead of Dad).  No matter how far, it'll always be close to my heart.Salamat, po!

12.description: Lumpia, pancit, lechon, etc. Uni-Mart is one stop shopping for all your Filipino foodie desires.  I've always had an easy time ordering for parties and other events, and the food is always delicious.

21.description: Uni-Mart is the only major Filipino food grocer in Chicago proper, and that's the primary reason why you should come here. It features fresh fish, vegetables, tropical drinks, a good assortment of Filipino/Asian snacks and chips (my favorite are the flavored shrimp crackers), prepackaged baked goods, Pocky, frozen meats (wait...they sell a chicken tocino? Really?) and...a hot food bar. It is most easily accessible by the Clark St. (#22) CTA bus or by car. There is a private parking lot....I should sound more enthused about Uni-Mart but I'm...not...because I frequent better and cheaper Filipino food marts in the suburbs.I don't like Uni-Mart's hot food items. The lumpia is bland and the saucy barbeque on a stick tastes like a dessert because they put WAY too much sugar in the sauce. I've had the other food items here and they weren't really worth mentioning.I do commend Uni-Mart for its SIOPAO (think of a bao, a white flour dough ball encasing pork adobo, chicken or red bean, that's the size of an adult man's fist). Siopao is a great "baon" (brown-bag lunch) item.

16.description: There are a few other area Filipino food marts, but this is the one i remember being dragged to as a little girl. The funny thing is that even after 15 years, this place still smells exactly the same. My husband and I come here now a least once a month to stock up on jasmine rice, seasonings, sauces, longaniza and lumpia rolls. He loves coming here. This is pretty much the only place i will ever buy my rice from. Just keep in mind that the parking lot can be hard to maneuver on busy days.

17.description: Yet another place in Chicago that I have managed to negate until recently... and I'm mad at myself for it. I stopped by this afternoon, as some friends of mine kept talking about Filipino food and the cravings slowly surfaced. There is a parking lot which is convenient. The 'market' area looks like it would be larger from the outside but it's just a couple aisles of Asian necessities - you know: halo halo mix, shrimp chips, and macapuno ice cream! lol. Definitely reminiscent of the Filipino markets back home in L.A., and it was a bit comforting for a homesick soul. I lurked around the food selection in the back for a few minutes before deciding on getting menudo (beefy dish) which was really good, but a bit pricey for a small serving (which could be split by two). I liked the fact that the menudo had bongongong (sp?! lol) as I've never had it like that; just wish there was olives in it like the recipes back home. I think there was also a hotdog in there LOL so I'm not sure if that was intentional or not. I also ordered a small side of the bisteak (beef & onions) which again was a little expensive for a small, but definitely enough to feed two. Small side of rice was marginally priced.

10.description: After stuffing myself silly during a recent trip to see family in the Philippines, one would think I'd be tired of Filipino food, right? Yeah I thought so too. I was kind of craving some treats and "close enough" home-cooked meals. I was a little disappointed to not find my favorite brand of hopia, and the ready-made meals were looking kind of blah, esp. the chicken adobo. I blame myself for getting there near closing time, which most likely counts for that. I got an order of pancit bihon. The woman behind the counter was like almost every Filipino mom I know (incl. mine). She gave me a rather hearty helping of pancit to go. Um. I guess I'll be eating that for a week? Best part of this story? I also ended up cooking a batch of adobo once I got home...as if I wouldn't have enough to eat.

11.description: I have not tried the ready-to-eat food at their "restaurant" in back, but will review that when I do.  I've gone in a few times for some small items that are keeping me from making a good curry or something at home.  This is very close to me, so it's good for a quick stop for some rice vinegar, coconut milk, soy sauce...that kind of stuff.  I was looking for arugula once and the three store employees I spoke to didn't know what it was and kind of followed me around looking to be explained what I was talking about.  I'll chalk it up to their attention to pleasing the customer, but yeah...don't go there thinking you'll get some good, fresh produce.  Their frozen selection is also pretty good for wonton/pot sticker wraps and other goodies.  If you have time to go to Golden Pacific market down on Broadway, I'd go there.  If you don't, then this is your spot.  I'm sure their hot food is a great incentive for some to go in, and I'm excited to try some!

26.description: Unimart rocks!  For your longaniza cravings and addiction, Unimart comes through.  Longaniza is sometimes referred to as the filipino version of chorizo, but it's sweet instead.  About 1" in diameter, the casings are wound so that you have a bunch of 3-4" sausages bound together that you can fry up in a pan and serve with your eggs and Jasmine rice.  It makes for quite a hearty breakfast.Sorry, I know...this isn't a Food Network blog!  Unimart has a decent selection of filipino foods, candy with fun labels at the checkout, and they serve great hot food to go.  If you're lucky to be there when eggrolls are of avail, GET SOME!  They are big, full of cabbage, pork and other assorted veggies.  Generally, filipino food isn't super-spicy, so the timid sha'nt be afraid to try the various dishes...kare kare...crispy pork...fried fish...menudo...  But, if you're a vegetarian, you might have a challenge finding something at the hot food stand.  Also, many dishes are of the gnaw-on-the-bone nature.I had their pancit once and remember liking it, but never since because Jil's mom makes the best pancit ever.  Thirty Helen's agree!!!

27.description: Sometimes after my Sat morn session of bball, I'm too exhuasted (lazy) to go home and put meat between 2 pieces of bread.  So en route home, I would stop by the cafeteria in the back of uni-mart.  I usually get the lechon (roast pig), fried fish, or menudo (flip style chilli).  The lechon costs about $8 a slab and comes with I believe liver sauce.  It's quite interesting how this sweet liver sauce condiments this crispy pork (I think I made a new verb).  I don't usually bother with the lumpia and chicken adobo because it's not that great.        Since I'm already there, I pick up some items like frozen longanisa sausage and pineapple soda.  BTW, the bibingka sold here is not really bibingka.  And I always check to see if they have banana ketchup, but  they only have banana sauce.  I want to make some filipino (Jollibee) style spaghetti but they never have the thicker, sweeter ketchup I'm looking for.      Anyway, one time I checked out with lechon, a cup of rice, and some groceries.  I went home, and took a few bites.  To my dismay, I realized that I just paid $7 for plain rice because the caf lady labeled it wrong.  $7 is not much, but out of principle,  I could not enjoy my meal knowing that I paid that much for a cup of rice.  I don't think there is a single Asian person in the world that would pay that much for rice coming out of grocery store.   Besides, my mom's voice was giving me a guilt trip.  So, I did my 1 minute commute, explained the situation, got an apology, and I told them, "Just pay me the difference in lumpia."

0.description: Based solely on the Ube Sans Rival dessert that they sell here.  I WANT THIS EVERY DAY OF MY LIFE.Aside from this, the place is dingy, but has everything and anything you need to satisfy your Filipino food needs.

20.description: Their to go food bar was actually pretty good.  However, their food selection was limited.  Wish they were bigger.

19.description: Came here per recommendation of my coworker Nett B. cos I asked her where to buy Balikbayan boxes.Giving only 3 stars just because the boxes are $3.99 versus RC in Skokie's $3.29.Note: I tried going at 7:20pm on a Thursday and they looked like they were closed for some time and busy cleaning up, so the hours posted on yelp might be outdated.

2.description: A delightful spot in Edgewater. They have a full Filipino butcher meat and fish counter. They also do catering on this site. Home style kitchen for takeout and eat in. Also feature frozen Filipino imports. A lot it import beverages .Assorted bakery and candy items. Nice staff. A cut above in the Asian market game.

18.description: I was craving macapuno (baby coconut) ice cream and was pleasantly surprised to find it (in HUGE tin containers) at Uni-Mart.  Wow wow wow.  This stuff might be better than the fresh stuff I used to get at Mitchell's in San Francisco (that's saying a LOT).  The chunks of coconut are sort of sugary grated globs of coconut.  Can you spell cavities?  But it's SO worth it.One thing to note: There is a place that sells the same thing for $2 cheaper on Argyle St...though it's farther for me, so worth it to shop here.

13.description: You can make the half filipina girl move away from her filipina mom, but you can't make the half filipina girl stop missing mom's food. On the northside for something completely different. Tired after trekking from Hyde Park and have to go to Rockwell/Peterson. Passing Clark I suddenly remembered there was a filipino grocery store. I immediately jumped off the bus(ok, not quite but you get the picture) because I started to miss my mama's cooking. SInce I am not the best cook I usually rely on those seasoning packets- Mama Sita's, Mccormick's etc. to make adobo, calderata,etc. But since moving to the south side I haven't been able to pick up those packets. I guess I could get them online..but I keep forgetting. Sometimes I wish I was half Chinese instead of half filipina so that going to a nearby asian market would be more convenient! Could just hop on the red line and get off at Chinatown.Alas, my mom is one cool Filipina and I wouldnt' have it any other way. BUT it's really inconvenient for grocery shopping.I also picked up two packages of Longaniza which I am currently chomping on as I type. I seriously do not know why filipino food hasn't caught on with the American public. Longaniza would convert the masses.And darn those yummy bakery goods and the food to go.I am carb cycling and I happened to go to UNIMART on my low carb day. GRR....Although I could have picked up one of the meaty dishes which would be low carb compliant. I just knew I'd be tempted with rice. (yeah, I'm a  half asian person who eats rice maybe once a month even on my high carb days!) I almost bought me some Pan De Sal. Right now I can imagine dipping that yummy bread into my coffee, just like mommy. Of course she dipped the bread in Nescafe(ugh), I would dip it in Intelligentsia, Metropolis or Alterra. I am low carbing and trying to do Paleo because that's what my ancestors did...uh....but coming to Unimart it seems like my recent ancestors have been eating yummy breads. I did avoid the breads and picked up longaniza and upon eating it realize it might not be low carb...lol. It's sweet sausage(I highly recommend Victor's Longaniza in the frozen foods case!). But it's my high carb day, so oh well.They also have duck eggs. hee hee. Totally in line with low carb!  May have to pick them up.I did get my seasoning packets and can't wait to try them on my all meat day tomorrow.I will be back Unimart. On my high carb rice day.

4.description: Definitely have a wide variety of choices and tastes! The workers are kind and prices are very affordable. I took my family here when they came to visit me from New Jersey. They liked the food. They need to bring some CEBUANO - STYLE Lechon here ! ;)

24.description: I was craving macapuno (baby coconut) ice cream and was pleasantly surprised to find it (in HUGE tin containers) at Uni-Mart.  Wow wow wow.  This stuff might be better than the fresh stuff I used to get at Mitchell's in San Francisco (that's saying a LOT).  The chunks of coconut are sort of sugary grated globs of coconut.  Can you spell cavities?  But it's SO worth it.One thing to note: There is a place that sells the same thing for $2 cheaper on Argyle St...though it's farther for me, so worth it to shop here.

6.description: This place definitely fix my Filipino food cravings that I can't cook such as Laing, Chicharon Bulaklak, Okoy, Liempo, and Palabok!!!I think their Palabok is to die for... There's really not a good place to get it unless you're at your Titas or Lola's house. The chicharon bulaklak & Okoy are soooooooooo good. Reminds me of my childhood. Definitely go get some! If they don't have it they will cook it for you! The things they sell are aighttt. It's pricey so I normally get my longaniza, malungay, and wrappers at Viet hoa on argyle. Overall this place I worth going to! Do the box instead of the to go containers. So much better!

22.description: Philippine treat goodbanana lumpias yumPockey for sale

15.description: Need to bring lumpias (aka FIlipino mini-eggrolls) to bring to your next family event? I'd suggest going to Uni-Mart - basically, the staple grocery store of most Filipino families living on the north side of the city.  They sell lumpias in the ready-made food section ($7.50/lb for about 25-30) as well as a variety of other Filipino dishes (turon, adobo, caldereta, lechon, bbq chicken, etc.).  If you want to place a larger order, you can always place the order a couple days ahead of time, so they can have it ready for pick-up right before your event.Plus, the grocery section basically has every FIlipino food items you could ever look for (shrimp chips, shrimp paste, pancit noodles, salted egg, pan de sal, calamansi juice, etc.). You can also buy frozen lumpias and then fry them yourself, if you're up to dealing with that daunting task.  I picked up $80 worth of food here for Thanksgiving and it was enjoyed by all! Note: They don't take Amex, but they do take personal checks. The parking lot may have the tendency to fill up on weekends and it's pretty difficult to maneuver around in because it's a little small.  Oh, and they apparently give you a free bottle of sweet and sour sauce with purchases over $50....Cute!

7.description: They have the full assortment of Filipino groceries and bakery items, as well as an excellent take-out counter (many choices of freshly-prepared dishes).  Yes, the store looks old, and yes, you will likely wait in line for a little bit, but so what?  The place has character, the workers are friendly, the prices are reasonable, and the food is fantastic.  Do yourself a favor and try an order of their pork adobo.

8.description: a few days after returning from the philippines, all i could think was, "i should have stuffed more pastries in my suitcase!" girl, i was craving ensaymada like nobody's business. enter uni-mart. i think i bought every kind of baked good they had. now a week later i have had a chance to consume most of it. quality & flavor ranged from A (amazing) to D (dry) and some in between.pandan cake- A+++ube cake- A+ube bread- Acheese roll- B (pretty good but miles away from what i had in the flips)ensaymada- C (i've had way better. and will keep searching for better.)pan de coco- D- (skip it!)also got some toron which i would totally get again. and they carry lots of the snacks i'm sure i'll need to stock up on again in the near future. i'm glad they're here, but i'm still kinda left wanting. i'll be checkin' out some other filipino joints before coming back here.

30.description: If I could be the Anthony Bourdain of Chicago, I would bring you this - the best kept eggroll secret in Chicago...BUILDING - What this place lacks in ambiance and marketing, it makes up for big food and big taste.  Okay, a non-descript building, not much parking, and you gotta wonder what they sell because this place does not look like it has much, and it vaguely smells like someone has been frying something in there.  Well this is what I grew up within some of the Filipino homes I have visited, and it is a precursor to something delicious.TAKEOUT FOOD - When you walk to the back of the store, you are greeted by a takeout counter and a long glass case only a non-muslim southeast asian could appreciate.  A large takeout counter makes up about 30% of the store, yet may make up a huge percentage of their business. Filipino food consists of 5 different food groups - starches (bread or rice variations), fried meat (mostly pork related), barbecue (chicken and pork), stews (vegetable and meat and combinations), and soups.  If you go to this place for anything at all, you should go for, and you should write this down, the LUMPIA SHANGHAI.  Lumpia Shanghai is a mini meat eggroll unlike any other eggroll adulterated with heavy cabbage.  The thin crackling filo type shell stuffed with garlic, carrot and onion-seasoned pork is appetizer perfection for meatlovers.  It comes with a sweet sour dipping sauce that is unnecessary, but adds variety.  At $6.00/lb, one pound fills a half a styrofoam takeout clamshell.  The light crunchiness of the shell, along with the garlic spicyness of the meat makes this the perfect accompaniment with beer.  Even the next day, these lumpia shanghai heat up nicely in the oven and will hold for at least 3 days, if they last 3 hours.  LUMPIA SHANGHAI WARNING: Do not go hungry when you buy these.  The smell of the cooked lumpia will torture you until you careen the car into a parking spot just to stop your incessant drooling.The pork barbecue sticks and the chicken barbecue sticks are next best (in that order).  Generously skewered pieces of meat coated in a sweet barbecue sauce, ready for another sneaky snack in the car. Other items in the glass case?  Lechon (roast pork), other stuffed meats (like chicken relleno, a chicken stuffed with a meatloaf, oh yeah), a variety of traditional fried fish, and stews. STEWS - Most of these are traditional and you should as a Filipino friend what they are.  Nothing will be too hot or spicy, just different.Adobo is combination of chicken and pork (there they go again, trying to marry the meats together) cooked in soy sauce, garlic, black pepper, bay leaves and vinegar.  The richness of the pork and the lightness of the chicken make for a nice tasty dish.  Pancit noodles are an egg noodle frenzy of chinese pork sausage, pork and chicken (see dat again?), carrots, celery and mushrooms in a rich oyster sauce flavor.  Excellent carb that is also served with white rice (you will find that almost everything in a Filipino diet is served with white rice).BREADS - If you like soft, roll type bread, try the pan de leche or the pan de sal.  Both are great.  The other products within the store are catered toward the Filipino community.  Everything is in english and you should find no problem with any of the selections. PARKING - Tough, but worth it.The food is very good, and not only is it near and dear to my heart, it is probably in my arteries as well.

3.description: Sisig supposed to be parts of pork mixed with soy sauce on a sizzling plate (that means warm and brown colored if it is in "turo turo" style.) When I ordered it it was white and cold (looked like kilawin to me.) Its my favorite filipino dish so I was hoping that it would be the real thing.Also the hours for BDO cannot be found online.Otherwise, it's your mom and pop's grocery store. A place where you can get a quick bite if your craving for filipino home cook meal.

14.description: The best time to visit Uni-Mart is a Saturday morning.  The place bustles with activity and laughter of friends gathering and shopping, and the hot food bar is packed with every Filipino dish you could ever want.  The food sells by the pound and is usually grabbed up by 2pm.   Get here later than that and all you will find is a greasy mess of leftovers, so consider yourself warned!

12.description: Stay away from this placei asked them to fix a problem they never came to fix it  they promise to come and then it turns into the same promises and bull-shits with each passing dayi work overnight so i dont have time to babyshit and wait for themso thanks but no thanks for wasting my precious resting time after work

7.description: I recently purchased two A/C units from Minas and I could not be happier with the experience. I dealt directly with Aram, who was very attentive and courteous. I have non-standard A/C sleeves and so not only did he take it upon himself to help research available options, he also gave me the best price out of all the dealers that I contacted (I contacted many, including big box stores). I also had Minas install the units; they were very respectful when entering my home, showing care not to dirty anything AND they arrived at the exact time they said they would come. I would absolutely recommend using this place.

19.description: When we moved in 2003, Comcast completely botched our cable install, and I was livid. Our neighbor heard my tirade & recommended Minas, as they're a DirectTV distributor. Blood still boiling from my Comcast interaction, I marched down to Minas, and not only were they polite and helpful, they immediately offered a next-day install at 11AM (and showed up right on time! - a miracle these days.) Since then my husband & I have been loyal Minas customers, both for rentals (they do have a mah-velous selection) and TV repair (again, courteous & timely service). We've never had a bad experience in over 4 years.

1.description: Best video rental place ever. Not many places exist like this anymore. You have to appreciate the family friendly environment.

2.description: Weird store,  I visited today looking for movie rentals. Looks like they sell electronics also. You have to have an account to rent movies from them. It wasn't horribly priced, we rented two older movies for 5 bucks, for 5 days. They had a pretty wide selection, and they also sell movies and vhs tapes for cheap. The staff greeted us upon entering and were friendly. They explained if we needed an extra day with the movie to just come ask, because they're pretty lenient.  Probably my new video rental spot.

9.description: I've only used this place for movie rentals. But they have a wide selection, DVDs are in good condition, and it's not pricey to rent from them. The staff is also super friendly.

6.description: Raffi, from Minas TV & Video, installed a very large and difficult roof antenna for me. He was great. Very responsible, caring and professional. Very reliable and good pricing.

18.description: We love this friendly neighborhood video store.   We hope it stays in business for years to come.  They have a great movie selection, and they were really helpful with technical advice as well.  I bought some equipment from them and that was all well priced also.

10.description: Electronics:I wanted to purchase a super simple DVD player.  Nothing with any bells and whistles.  I went to Mina's.  They were super friendly.  Had what I was looking for.  Didn't try to get me to buy something fancier or more expensive.  I was so glad to give my money to them, a family owned, 40 year old local store, than to fork my cash over to Target down the street.Videos:My main video store is Specialty Video with Mina's as a good back up.  Sometimes Mina's has things that specialty does not.  Plus, if I am looking for a season of a TV show, I will always try Mina's first.  They will give you the entire season to watch for one week.  With other stores you have to rent each disc separately and it is never a week long rental.  Score.

13.description: Very nice staff, family owned business. I was a little disappointed because they ended up not being able to repair my portable DVD player. So I was out the $25, plus I ended up having to buy a new one. I do agree with the other reviewer that it did take several weeks for them to call me back. I did not hear from them so I had to call them after about 3 weeks and the person let me know that the laser would cost too much to replace so I should just buy a new one. Bummer. So, I don't have too much to say as far as an experience-I just know they have some pretty nice stuff in there and the staff was knowledgeable and professional. If you are tired of "big box" stores, this might be another option. I just wish I could have scored a cheap fix for my DVD player that was only 2 years old. Boo hoo for me.

16.description: My plasma went out and brought it to Minas. The guy who helped us, wish I knew his name(had a goatee and glasses I think) was super, super helpful and really nice. Helped me carry it out and into the shop. Got the estimate pretty quickly. They had to order a part but once it got there got the tv back quickly. Same guy helped me load it back in and again was really friendly. Def would go with them again for a repair.

17.description: Minas has movies I haven't been able to find elsewhere (And the Band Played On and La Reine Margot, for example). As said elsewhere, the prices are good too: $2 to $3.The dad-owner even told me how to connect a VCR and an antenna so that I could play an ancient video tape. I had just mentioned that I needed to figure out how to do that, and the mom-owner called to her husband to come out  and teach me. That's nice service.In addition to rentals, they've got the titular TV section, but they've also got video games, portable DVD players, headphones, antennas, air conditioners (in season), candy, popcorn, soda (good to know if you're doing laundry next door), etc.Stuff is sometimes out of alphabetical order, which doesn't really bother me. If the son-owner is there, he can tell you whether they've got what you're looking for and he'll probably get it for you. He's gotten movies for me that I didn't see on the shelf. If you're like me and you can't wait the day or two for NetFlix, amble into Minas. If you must drive, they always seem to have spaces in front of the store.

15.description: Stay far away from this place - they sent out a guy to take down our television and the guy was here for 45 minutes and actually broke our wall mount - our brand new $370 wall mount.  We were told the owner would be back the next day to take the tv down and after we called them (the owner did not take it upon himself to follow up with us that evening or the next day) the next day he was unable to come until friday - mind you this all happened on a monday evening.  Our 52 inch super heavy tv was hanging by a thread without minas caring at all about what their repair guy did.  So now we are going to have to buy a new wall mount and pay for someone to install it - which will cost me close to $700.  STAY AWAY!

0.description: Always great to do business with a outstanding Edgewater business.  Arum and Raffi were incredibly helpful in the selection of our new TV.  Going there allowed me to complete a age old project - converting those 20 year old VHS tapes to DVD!  For me it was simple, great local service, a price that matched Amazon.  Why wouldn't you buy from the neighborhood?

5.description: Minas TV was able to do exactly what they said they would do...that gets 5 stars from me.I paid the diagnostic fee for my broken 42" LCD tv; they called me the next day to tell me what it would cost to fix it. I accepted (on a Saturday), and it was ready at the end of the day Monday. My diagnostic fee was applied to the total repair cost, so I paid $70 to find out what was wrong, and another $100 and some to get it fixed...about half the price of the TV brand new.Thanks! Will most certainly be back

11.description: My 10 years old TV broke down last Wednesday.  I called Minas TV and their technician came within an hour.  I was really surprised because I called some companies before and nobody wanted to come because it was too old.  Not only he fixed the device within 40 minutes but also connected all my stereo and set up both remote controls.  The price was about  what I expected.  Outstanding service!  I recommend this company to everybody!

8.description: My 6-yr old flat-screen's video died, though the audio and other features were fine.  I discovered there's such a thing as TV-repair and cruised Yelp to find a neighborhood joint.  Half of Minas is for DVD rentals (which I'm also surprised still exists), and the other half is TV's.  They can send a tech to you, but I brought my TV to them. They require a $60 deposit to diagnose and, if easy, to fix your TV.  It took them three days to get back to me, and they pronounced my TV defective.  Not sure what that means.   They transferred the $60 deposit to a new TV purchase.  My selection was out of stock and took 3 days to arrive.  All in all, it took a week, which felt like too long.  However, Amran was incredibly kind and friendly, he has a super chill, sweet dog, and an older lady was watching Wednesday afternoon soaps on a magnificent large screen and eating lunch.  I like this place.

3.description: Here's what happened to me. Our TV would turn on but only stay on for a couple of hours and then shut itself off. Upon turning it back on, it would go "click click click" and not turn back on for about 24 hours or so. Researching on the Internet, it seemed that the power supply board was the likely cause. We explained the problem to Minas, dropped off the TV, and paid a $60 diagnostic service fee. Several days later, Minas called and told us that they did the same test as us (turn it on until it turned itself off) and that it'd be between $350-$450 depending on what the problem was. Apparently, he didn't actually open the TV to find out what the actual problem was. So really, Minas did nothing but take our money and tell us what we already knew. They offered us $30 off if we purchased a new TV from them. If the issue is the PSB, I've found them online for under $80. What a ripoff.My suggestion is to get service and shop elsewhere.

14.description: I had a TV that needed repair.I dropped it off on April 6th, 2009. I received a call on April 9th with the diagnosis and a timeframe of 5-7 business days to get the part in and install it.I followed up with them on April 17th (6 biz days later) and they informed me that the part had not been received from their 3rd party distributor yet and that they would call them and get back to me that day. I never heard back. So, I called on Monday, April 20th and talked with the other biz owner and he said he would call to find out what was going on. On Tuesday, April 21st, he informed me that their distributor received the part broken and needed to order another one. I was told that the part should be at MINA'S by Friday April 24th and their tech was on vacation so he wouldn't get to it until the following Wednesday (April 28th). I called on April 28th and MINA'S still had not received the part from THEIR distributor.  I finally picked up my fixed TV on Monday, May 4th......ALMOST 4 WEEKS AFTER THE DIAGNOSIS was done.I understand it was not MINA's fault, DIRECTLY, but, their 3rd party distributor, that they use, are part of MINA's and when I went to pick up the TV, MINA's did not make any attempt to knock anything off the price as a courtesy for me being inconvenienced!  The 2 stars are for the long wait, the poor customer service and for not making any effort to compensate me for the inconvenience.

4.description: Professional - knowledgeable - full service - see your project through until you are 100% satisfied. Media/tv/audio/visual technology & equipment is rapidly evolving - having Minas install and provide tv, components, wires, installation is a great investment.   Over time you will save yourselves time and headaches putting the trust into Minas hands to get the job done.    PLS contact me for further referral.

58.description: Super cute spot.  Yummy pies.  I had the peach and blueberry.  I've also had the chocolate peanut butter pie which is out of this world.  I keep waiting for them to have the grasshopper because yum!

56.description: Oh My Pie! Got the mini pie flight: it's a mini pie made of 4 different pie flavors that you pick. I selected Michigan Sour Cherry, French Silk, Chocolate Peanut Butter, Coffee Toffee.  I absolutely love cherry pie, so I started with that one and almost melted in my chair. It was amazing. Best pie ever. It doesn't even need the sugar on top. Tied at 1st for best flavor of the four is coffee toffee. Most coffee flavored desserts are severely lacking. This pie makes up for every single lackluster coffee ice cream, coffee shake, cup of coffee, coffee flavored chocolate I've ever had...it's DELICIOUS!The French silk was good, a little frozen on the bottom. A very good combo of light/fluffy and creamy/rich. The chocolate peanut butter is great for those that like a dense pie and those that like Reese's peanut butter cup filling way more than the chocolate. Basically, it's more peanut butter than chocolate, but still good in its own right. I also got a chocolate cream pie to go. Have not tried it yet, but already salivating thinking about it. I'm going back to this place for every birthday, celebration, holiday, fake holiday, and half-birthday.

29.description: Excellent pie, and even nicer people!  We decided against wedding cake for our wedding and instead opted for pie.  We ended up ordering four First Slice pies for our wedding (Michigan Sour Cherry, Apple, Pecan and Balsamic Raspberry Pear).  They were a HUGE hit with our guests!  I had no pie left over at the end of the night- everyone wanted to try all four, and I know many people took some home.  Sara Beth was extremely helpful in coordinating our order.  I think I emailed her three weeks before our wedding, and she immediately got us in for a tasting, set up our order and arranged for it to be delivered to our venue.  The whole thing was as easy as pie (pun intended!), and I appreciate the fact that the money I spent is helping those less fortunate.  I'm also thrilled that the Andersonville store is so close to me, so I can go buy pie for other family events, as I know it will now be requested of us often!  Thank you, First Slice, for being so awesome!

42.description: Excellent little pie shop. I've never disliked a single slice I've had. I've taken my pie to go enjoy at home and I've also had a seat outside enjoying a slice along with a cup of coffee. Both are great experiences. I'm determined to try every kind they have!

23.description: Came here with a friend ages ago and it is now our go to spot to catch up in this neighborhood. I really enjoyed their coconut pie and chocolate covered strawberry! You could definitely tell it was made fresh that morning. I really like this place, only drawback is that it is a bit of a walk from the train.

47.description: Great neighborhood pie shop that also serves coffee and sandwich items. I was pleasantly surprised to find that it is also non-profit, with all proceeds going to help the homeless. The prices are reasonable, great pies, nice space and great employees.Definitely check this out and do some good for the community as well!

8.description: Cute place! Good pie, ok coffee, and an extensive lunch menu. Barista seemed stand-offish, but it's to be expected at local coffee shops.I got a small coffee and a "coffee-toffee" slice. Coffee was ok, and they have 50 cent refills, which is good. Coffee-toffee was a slight misnomer: it was more like a mocha-French silk pie. It seemed like the only toffee was sprinkled lightly on the top, but that was about it. That being said, it was REALLY good! The pie's consistency was thick and creamy, and the chocolate and coffee flavors were deep and delicious. Although I just got pie and coffee, their lunch options look soooo good! Curry chicken salad, Chicago vegetarian sandwich, mango jicama salad--the variety of options and flavors look great!Can't wait to come back to try more pie and some non-pie options!

31.description: A poem on pie. I love pie. Pie is delicious. Come here if you like pie. The chocolate peanut butter is my favorite. Mmm girl. Fin.

34.description: Pies are always on point, coffee is always fresh, so many different flavors to choose from and their service is great. Glad they're in the neighborhood

16.description: Wow the blueberry cheesecake pie is to die for and it is now one of my favorite pies of all time. This little shop is jewel in our neighborhood and I can't wait to return to try more of their delicious pies. I would definitely recommend them to all my friends and family.  I love their pies!!!

13.description: I'll preface this review with the fact that I prefer a lighter flavor profile, and this extends to desserts as well--I tend to like less sweet desserts or desserts where the sweet is well balanced with bitter or sour flavors. I got two slices of pie--one, the famous Michigan cherry, and the other, the raspberry balsamic with pear. I thought both of them were far too sweet; so much in fact, that I couldn't have more than one tiny bite of each without breaking up the sweetness with coffee. I was expecting both to have a bit of a tang and was especially disappointed to find that the raspberry balsamic/pear pie came off as a raspberry only pie. I was also pretty disappointed with the crust; perhaps I had let it sit for too long since I had it to-go, but the crust was on the thin side and lacked the buttery flakiness that's typical at other pie shops. Quite disappointed--friendly service and cute shop, but just way too much sugar in the pies for me.

11.description: OMGAH yes! I finally got the chance to stop by first slice pie and it was a great experience. Such a cute little boutique with yummy goodies. Upon arrival, we were greeted by an energetic cashier girl and she made sure if we needed any assistance, she was there to help. There were so many selections to choose from but we ended up getting a slice of blueberry cheesecake and chocolate peanut butter. I personally love the blueberry cheese cake pie and it was so delicious I wanted to have more. Surprisingly, the blueberry did not overpower the taste of the pie and it was amazing. It's a great cozy sweet treat shop. Pies weren't the only thing that they sold. There was many other great treats as well.

39.description: Ordered two pies from here (both were mini in size) but great for sharing among a couple of people. We tried the key lime and chocolate cream and both were great! This location is in harder to find location but I would come back in a heartbeat when I need my next pie fix.

37.description: Pies, guys! So many different pie options, by the slice and by the pie, inside a nice coffee/sandwich shop with wifi, outlets, and evening hours. This is basically the greatest thing since sliced...pie. The sandwiches are a bit pricey ($8-9) but surprisingly good (I recommend the chicken and guac) and served with a generous helping of salad and chips. I wish all coffee shops had this kind of general coffee shop goodness plus a specialization in bringing you a vast variety of some delicious dessert item, like cupcakes, donuts, deep-fried twinkies, whatever. My entire coffee shop work-life would be so much more sugary.

0.description: I adventured all the way up to the far North side, beyond Devon Ave, to the part of the city where the grid breaks down and I no longer recognize whether I'm in Chicago or Skokie, or even which way is the lake.  It was a journey to hang with my friend Whitney, to go to Target and bring her cat to the vet with my car.We stopped for lunch at cafe that came recommended for its pie.  Not that I was up late the night before obsessing over pie in my pajamas... OK I was.  I really wanted some pie. First Slice Pie Cafe puts out an excellent slice.  Based on my friend's Southern background, we shared a huge slice of French Silk.  The chocolate mousse was silky as advertised.To balance the sweet with the savory, we shared a ham sandwich with melted Wisconsin cheddar and sundried tomato.  I love how soft (yet still toasty warm) the bread it came on was.  Thank you internet for a great recommendation for pie!  My name is Arthur and I'm a pie addict.

38.description: This place is great for stopping by and taking some time to relax in the neighborhood. The cherry pie, cherry balsamic pear pie, and the coffee toffee are all delicious! The espresso was pretty good as well.

51.description: So...i got to First Slice, Andersonville 10 minutes before closing on a Tuesday night. At a lot of food places, it's super annoying to get customers right before closing since everyone is trying to clean up and get ready to close. but, the workers were SO SO FRIENDLY-- i didn't feel rushed at all. so thank you so much First Slice! plus, tuesdays they have a band perform- from the last 5 minutes that i caught, they were great too!oh.. and the pies (chocolate cream, coffee toffee, and French Silk) were so so so tasty, not overly sweet, perfectly creamy and crunchy and delicious. everything you would hope for in a pie.

27.description: If I need to fulfill a salty/sweet craving?  Chocolate peanut butter pie.  Someone having a party?  Chocolate peanut butter pie.  If I feel like being nice and want to bring a treat to work?  Chocolate peanut butter pie.  In other words, the chocolate peanut butter pie is AMAZING!!  I've tried replicating this pie at home, but it doesn't even come close.  I don't know what First Slice does, but I'll just leave it to them and pay the 20-something dollars because it is totally worth it.  Everyone who has tried this also can't believe how delicious it is.  From the chocolate pie crust to the crushed peanuts on top, everything is perfection.  Other favorites of mine include the key lime and Michigan sour cherry pie.

32.description: This pie is always homemade with the freshest ingredients. I can't go to Chicago without stopping in for a slice!! If you go on Pie Day; the line is out the door and around the corner!

54.description: Oh My Gah!!! The French Silk Pie is soooooo gooooddddd!!!! It's look so French (what's French anyway) and so SILKY and so sexy!!! I had the Key Lime Pie too and it was so delicious (better than the one I had a week ago at Miami)....perfect balance between sweet and tangy!!

48.description: Must have: French silkFirst Slice is fantastic.  In addition to having great pie choices, they also have a large sandwich and coffee shop menu if you were stopping in for a meal. They space is light and airy and has wifi, but is too popular and small to use as a coffee shop to work in.Each pie slice is $3.50 (full pies are available for takeout and range from $20-$25) and rich enough to split and be satisfied. Why would you want to split a piece of Fresh Slice pie though?? So I got to sample two between the Bf and I. The French Silk was fantastic! And I am not even a huge chocolate person! It had a slim crust and ample chocolate filling and cream topping. The filling was not a generic chocolate taste, but had the richness and depth of a good dark chocolate. The French Silk is a blue ribbon pie if there was one.I also had the chocolate peanut butter pie. Mounds if creamy peanut butter nested in a chocolate cracker crust. So rich, you need to accompany it with some milk or coffee to break up the peanut butter.Both pies were fantastic, but I would have loved a little more crust to filling ratio. That's a personal thang though, because  I think the crust is the best part.

44.description: Visited for a second time last night. I had some family in from the suburbs for dinner and thought it would be nice to stop there for a slice of pie afterwards. We arrived at 8:30pm and by the time we were done ordering and paying it was 8:35pm. We were told that because the shop closes at 9pm we could not stay to eat the pie that we had just purchased. We hadn't planned on staying long, probably just 10 more minutes. This was very frustrating and a little embarrassing. Telling paying customers that they can't sit in the dining room shows poor customer service. I understand that you can't stay open all night but if the sign on your door states that you're open until 9pm then you should not turn away paying customers who want to eat in your dining room before that time. I won't be returning.

24.description: We definitely will be coming back. After a so so dinner experience at Hamburger Mary's around the corner we popped in for some pie to apologize to our appetites. We were rewarded! Everything looked good, the staff was friendly and helpful and, importantly, the pies were delicious. I tried a slice of the balsamic raspberry pear pie (warmed up a bit). The sweetness and tartness were well balanced and the crust was perfect. He tried the coffee toffee pie and oh it was so rich and good. If my slice didn't have me so lost in my own sweet comfort food fantasy world I would have kept "sampling" his too. The cafe options sounded promising though we didn't try them. Great little neighborhood treat.

7.description: There are way too many bakeries in this city that get carried away with niche pastries and "creative" new desserts that fail to do the one thing dessert is supposed to do: make you smile. First Slice does pie and they do it well! Their cherry pie is stellar. It's roll your eyes back in your head good. I only get one slice at a time because I know if I get a full pie I'll eat the whole thing in one sitting. I am not a fan of balsamic vinegar--especially in desserts--but I tried the balsamic pear pie and it was really pretty good. I probably won't get it again but I was impressed.Pie is the reason to go here but they do a few other things well. The quiche is very good. It's thickly sliced and rich the way quiche is supposed to be when you make it at home. Everything tastes like its homemade. I seriously think they might have somebody's grandma chained up in the back making pies. I've also had a ham sandwich from First Slice. It was crazy good. The cheese was rich and hearty and the ham was warm and really high quality. Go for lunch and stay for dessert! The best part is that I live so close I can go get a full picnic then bring it home to have with wine.

49.description: it's a damn good pie shop that happens to donate its profits to feed the hungry and the homeless. But don't come here for just for the charity. Come here for the French silk pie. Even Martha Stewart said it is one of the best in the US.

40.description: This place was incredible. The service was awesome and the food was incredible! The pie reminded me of my grandmas homemade pie! The goat cheese and pear sandwich was super tasty as well. They were out of the pie I wanted and offered me a free slice next time they have it!
