I would recommend this to anyone for many different occasions! You have to go!

53.description: First slice pie is like a tasty tasty slice of heaven on your plate. I preordered and picked up six pies for an office party (early pi day celebration!) and couldn't be happier with the results. The folks that work there are super friendly and were helpful with all aspects of my order. The shop itself is way cute and I look forward to stopping in for a slice and some coffee on an upcoming beautiful spring day. Now, for the pies. I ordered six pies (peanut butter chocolate, apple, polka dot, key lime, French silk, and sour cherry. I of course had to try them all! Each pie was amazing and I had a hard time deciding which was my favorite. I know they are famous for their apple pie (and believe me it did not disappoint) but I think I might have loved the chocolate peanut butter the most. I am a sucker for peanut butter pies and this was one of the best I have ever had. There was a perfect balance of peanut butter and chocolate and it was clear that they use high quality ingredients -the result was out of control amazing! I obviously would recommend this ace to everyone! It is for sure my new favorite pie place in Chicago.

30.description: I'll preface this review with the fact that I prefer a lighter flavor profile, and this extends to desserts as well--I tend to like less sweet desserts or desserts where the sweet is well balanced with bitter or sour flavors. I got two slices of pie--one, the famous Michigan cherry, and the other, the raspberry balsamic with pear. I thought both of them were far too sweet; so much in fact, that I couldn't have more than one tiny bite of each without breaking up the sweetness with coffee. I was expecting both to have a bit of a tang and was especially disappointed to find that the raspberry balsamic/pear pie came off as a raspberry only pie. I was also pretty disappointed with the crust; perhaps I had let it sit for too long since I had it to-go, but the crust was on the thin side and lacked the buttery flakiness that's typical at other pie shops. Quite disappointed--friendly service and cute shop, but just way too much sugar in the pies for me.

46.description: Worth the 30 minute drive! The pie was excellent! I had the raspberry chocolate cheesecake and my hubby had the traditional apple. I don't really like cheesecake but I do now! It was so light and fluffy. Apple pie was great next time getting it with ice cream. Defiantly looking forward to our next visit.

1.description: 3 words: PEANUT BUTTER PIE!This is hands down one of the best pies I have ever had.  I especially like that I cab buy a "mini" pie version for a very reasonable price.  I have tried a few other kinds of their pies, and wasn't a fan...but this little slice of heaven always keeps me coming back!

55.description: First Slice is an awesome little cafe over in Andersonville that specializes in about a dozen or so different kinds of pies and standard coffee shop fare you can find practically anywhere (salads, grain salads, coffee, tea, etc.)  It doesn't have the most ostentatious sign or advertising out front, but it is SO worth the visit every time.The staff are extremely friendly, the ambiance is very chill and it's just so lighthearted.  There's no pretentiousness to be found within any inch of the shop and the pies they serve are made correctly and deliciously.  I tried a slice of the coffee toffee pie and the flavor of both the caramel-y toffee and medium-roast (arguably slightly burned) coffee creams were outstanding, especially when eaten together with the chocolate cookie crust.  It never got loud the entire day I spent working there, and the only time it really got somewhat busy was during the lunch hour.  That said though, there were no interruptions in sight and I was able to work the day away with ease.  I would happily eat here again and even spend the day here again.  It's warm, friendly, comfortable, and no one tries to get in anyone's way.  Pair that with a lusciously thick slice of pie and that'll put a smile on anyone's face!

9.description: Must have: French silkFirst Slice is fantastic.  In addition to having great pie choices, they also have a large sandwich and coffee shop menu if you were stopping in for a meal. They space is light and airy and has wifi, but is too popular and small to use as a coffee shop to work in.Each pie slice is $3.50 (full pies are available for takeout and range from $20-$25) and rich enough to split and be satisfied. Why would you want to split a piece of Fresh Slice pie though?? So I got to sample two between the Bf and I. The French Silk was fantastic! And I am not even a huge chocolate person! It had a slim crust and ample chocolate filling and cream topping. The filling was not a generic chocolate taste, but had the richness and depth of a good dark chocolate. The French Silk is a blue ribbon pie if there was one.I also had the chocolate peanut butter pie. Mounds if creamy peanut butter nested in a chocolate cracker crust. So rich, you need to accompany it with some milk or coffee to break up the peanut butter.Both pies were fantastic, but I would have loved a little more crust to filling ratio. That's a personal thang though, because  I think the crust is the best part.

26.description: OMGAH yes! I finally got the chance to stop by first slice pie and it was a great experience. Such a cute little boutique with yummy goodies. Upon arrival, we were greeted by an energetic cashier girl and she made sure if we needed any assistance, she was there to help. There were so many selections to choose from but we ended up getting a slice of blueberry cheesecake and chocolate peanut butter. I personally love the blueberry cheese cake pie and it was so delicious I wanted to have more. Surprisingly, the blueberry did not overpower the taste of the pie and it was amazing. It's a great cozy sweet treat shop. Pies weren't the only thing that they sold. There was many other great treats as well.

25.description: My friends and I stopped in on the last day of our road trip. Not only were the pies DELICIOUS but the quiches were a pleasant surprise! The woman working (owner?) was friendly and chatty...it seemed like a lot of locals were regulars. The brown line is just outside the door so it is a convenient first stop before a day spent in downtown chicago.

12.description: Maybe I frequent more cozy cafes, but I like going to ones with comfy couches, a warm atmosphere, decor, etc. First Slice still felt nice. It's on the smaller size, but it gets pretty decent traffic of people coming in and out, and people sitting and working. My boyfriend and I really enjoy coming to Andersonville and decided to come here after dinner to grab some dessert and to read before heading home. I got the chocolate, raspberry cheesecake and he got the apple pie- both were so good. I especially liked the cheesecake because it tasted light and had the perfect amount of sweetness.

59.description: Meh. We have made the tour of the pie palaces in the city, and had to try First Slice to see how it would compare.  If you really want good, delicious, sink your teeth into pie, this is not it. We had the Traditional Apple and the Michigan Sour Cherry.  While nice, the crust was thin and the fillings while good, were not outstanding. No offerTo warm up the apple pie. Cherry filling did have a pit, so it must be made fresh. Nice service and draws a crowd - but not fulfilling.

21.description: There are way too many bakeries in this city that get carried away with niche pastries and "creative" new desserts that fail to do the one thing dessert is supposed to do: make you smile. First Slice does pie and they do it well! Their cherry pie is stellar. It's roll your eyes back in your head good. I only get one slice at a time because I know if I get a full pie I'll eat the whole thing in one sitting. I am not a fan of balsamic vinegar--especially in desserts--but I tried the balsamic pear pie and it was really pretty good. I probably won't get it again but I was impressed.Pie is the reason to go here but they do a few other things well. The quiche is very good. It's thickly sliced and rich the way quiche is supposed to be when you make it at home. Everything tastes like its homemade. I seriously think they might have somebody's grandma chained up in the back making pies. I've also had a ham sandwich from First Slice. It was crazy good. The cheese was rich and hearty and the ham was warm and really high quality. Go for lunch and stay for dessert! The best part is that I live so close I can go get a full picnic then bring it home to have with wine.

17.description: We definitely will be coming back. After a so so dinner experience at Hamburger Mary's around the corner we popped in for some pie to apologize to our appetites. We were rewarded! Everything looked good, the staff was friendly and helpful and, importantly, the pies were delicious. I tried a slice of the balsamic raspberry pear pie (warmed up a bit). The sweetness and tartness were well balanced and the crust was perfect. He tried the coffee toffee pie and oh it was so rich and good. If my slice didn't have me so lost in my own sweet comfort food fantasy world I would have kept "sampling" his too. The cafe options sounded promising though we didn't try them. Great little neighborhood treat.

10.description: Stopped in on a whim for dessert after dinner at another restaurant and was very pleasantly surprised with the raspberry pear balsamic pie which I would highly recommend.

5.description: The chocolate raspberry cheesecake will bring me back again and again. With a quaint atmosphere and cashiers who are just the right amount of snooty for working in a pie shop, I'd still probably get my pie to go. I'm intrigued by the sandwiches. But mostly the cheesecake.

3.description: Charming place with good people, hence a 3 instead of a 2.Pie was ok.Tea was fine.Table was really sticky....so much so my napkins stock to the table.BangBang Pie is much much better.

35.description: Still a three as I'm eating. The chili was cold. And the hostess slash front man didn't know the ingredients of the food. Whether it had dairy or not. The ingredients aren't posted so you can choose what not to eat. The cook was Spanish and the communication was not that great. I give it an mmmm

19.description: One of my favorite spots for lunch. Depending on the time of day, it can be a little cramped for seating - particularly around 3pm when the hoards of Andersonville parents bring their children here for an afternoon snack and let the kiddos run wild. This is not the kind of place that you should let your kids do that, FYI. I always find myself ordering the same thing here. Cappuccino with almond milk, Michigan cherry pie, and a tuna salad sandwich. The sandwich comes with chips and a delicious salad with sliced apple and some kind of vinaigrette. Most of their sandwiches are around $7 and are very filling. For all that comes with it, I think it's a great value. They also have some charitable meal subscription services that help provide meals to local families in need.

28.description: Excellent pie selections, some are a little quirky in just the right way. Food options look good, it's a pretty quiet place and a bit small, so it might be fun to work out of here on a lazy afternoon. Guy behind the counter was a little standoffish, but not rude, so whatever.

45.description: One of my favorite spots for lunch. Depending on the time of day, it can be a little cramped for seating - particularly around 3pm when the hoards of Andersonville parents bring their children here for an afternoon snack and let the kiddos run wild. This is not the kind of place that you should let your kids do that, FYI. I always find myself ordering the same thing here. Cappuccino with almond milk, Michigan cherry pie, and a tuna salad sandwich. The sandwich comes with chips and a delicious salad with sliced apple and some kind of vinaigrette. Most of their sandwiches are around $7 and are very filling. For all that comes with it, I think it's a great value. They also have some charitable meal subscription services that help provide meals to local families in need.

33.description: Absolutely amazing apple pie, blueberry cheesecake pie, raspberry chocolate pie, pecan pie, and key lime pie. Their cookies are also pretty good. Coffee is fresh, staff is SUPER nice and friendly. We love coming here for a quick and tasty dessert paired with a cup of coffee and taking it all on a stroll around Andersonville! Come here- you'll truly enjoy it!

43.description: Wow the blueberry cheesecake pie is to die for and it is now one of my favorite pies of all time. This little shop is jewel in our neighborhood and I can't wait to return to try more of their delicious pies. I would definitely recommend them to all my friends and family.  I love their pies!!!

2.description: Great pie & coffee. Reasonably priced compared to other pie places and you get a delicious huge slice of pie. I had the french silk pie and it was delicious. Not overly sweet like most french silk pies, the chocolate was made with cocoa, you can tell by the taste. Paired it with a cafe au lait which was fresh and delicious. The staff was warm and welcoming. I will be back to try other pies!Will up it to a 5 star once I try other pies!

18.description: Delicious! I ordered a raspberry pie, a balsamic pear pie, apple pie and French silk and all of them where incredible. The French silk pie is probably the best I've ever had, and I'd highly recommend the balsamic pear as well! Just a heads up though, the apple pie top & crust wasn't as good the next day.

41.description: I've been here numerous times...way too many times.  Their chocolate pies are the best. Coffee Toffee, Chocolate Cream and the absolute best French Silk I've ever had.  My friend had the tart cherry and it was just ok.   All of their lunch items look great.

52.description: christ on a cracker, i love this place. the staff are awesome and friendly.they offer mini pies and that are only 6 dollars.their slices are also relatively cheap and well made. they constantly have amazing selections and are pretty unique. i love, love, love this place. this is my go-to dessert place when i'm in andersonville!

50.description: Been here a few times and usually pretty good.  However most recent experience not so good.  Attaching a pic and not sure what to think.I think it's a good cause but when you pay $3.00+ for a smaller piece of pie compared to most places you really hope to get a full slice or something that resembles a slice and isn't smashed.Probably wouldn't be as much of a deal except when you order two and the don't compare.  The second one had none of the crumble on top.  Also brought to the individual serving us and the response was "eh, it does that sometimes because the way it was pulled apart.  Hope the other person enjoyed the extra pie from mine.I wonder if success is affecting their quality.

4.description: My husband and I stopped in at First Slice Pie Cafe after dinner one night.  My husband had some kind of fruit pie (I can't remember--maybe cherry?  That seems right).  I had the french silk pie, which is objectively the best kind of pie.The pie was really, really good.  I also had a decaf espresso with a little milk in it, which was a total highlight too.  It tasted so good next to the sweetness of the pie, and it made for a delicious dessert.  I would totally go back here!

6.description: Bomb @ss pies.  $3.50 might be steep for a piece of pie, but haven't you paid he same for a cupcake?  I think the street price of a cupcake is $7.00 these days PIE greater than CupcakeThe French Silk makes a great late-night snack and their apple pie will conjure up thoughts of fall and the holidays anytime of year.

22.description: First and foremost, this place is such a quaint and adorable cafe. The interior is what I see on pinterest decorations. I had super high expectations in pie quality  for this place mainly because I always assume if a place specializes in one type of food then it should be way above average. Unfortunately, it wasn't the mind blowing pies I had expected. They were good pies don't get me wrong. But a bit too sweet for my taste buds and lacking that extra kick of homemade pies. Overall I would summarize this place as a cool fun place to hang out, has a good charity mission, and decent pies.

15.description: First Slice Pie Cafe is an adorable little shop on the corner that if you blink, you might just miss it. Thought I'd start this review with an overused cliche for all you folks out there in cyberland.  It really is a cute cafe though with many selections for pastries. Being a pie shop and all, I had a funny feeling pie was what they did best. So I took a risk and got just that.I had a slice of the Peanut Butter Chocolate pie. It was reasonably priced and looked a bit different than how I would normally imagine a pie of such a name. The crust was chocolate with an overloaded completely peanut buttery filling with a thin layer of chocolate on the top and what seemed to be crushed peanuts on top of that. It was rich and decadent...and I love peanut butter & chocolate to no end...but it was just too much peanut butter & not enough chocolate. It was good but to put it plainly I've had better. I tried my friend's after she had a bit and wanted no more. I agreed with her that it wasn't impressive. Meh.With so many pie shops in the city that blow my mind, I don't see much reason in coming back here outside of the convenience factor.

57.description: I love this little cafe!They have really great sandwiches, salads, & quiche. They are essentially a pie shop with lunch. I'm not a fan of pie, so I haven't tried their pies yet. All of their sandwiches come with a side salad & potato chips. I love the salad, it's dimple mixed greens with chunks if apple & a simple but flavorful vinaigrette.

20.description: The aromas front his cafe just make you think of grandma baking her delicious apple pies. At least that how it is for me. I love how inviting this little piece of heaven is. Though it is a bit small, it's the kind of small that is cozy, relaxing, and makes you want to huddle up under a warm blanket and start reading. The food just melts the senses, while it keeps me wondering about the next desert to hopefully fill my plate. There is always something new to try and this is a place that the family could come to for a nice relaxing night out.

36.description: Cute place! Good pie, ok coffee, and an extensive lunch menu. Barista seemed stand-offish, but it's to be expected at local coffee shops.I got a small coffee and a "coffee-toffee" slice. Coffee was ok, and they have 50 cent refills, which is good. Coffee-toffee was a slight misnomer: it was more like a mocha-French silk pie. It seemed like the only toffee was sprinkled lightly on the top, but that was about it. That being said, it was REALLY good! The pie's consistency was thick and creamy, and the chocolate and coffee flavors were deep and delicious. Although I just got pie and coffee, their lunch options look soooo good! Curry chicken salad, Chicago vegetarian sandwich, mango jicama salad--the variety of options and flavors look great!Can't wait to come back to try more pie and some non-pie options!

14.description: Best pie I've ever had and I don't even like pie. The crust is heavenly light, the chocolate is light, the sour cherry is amazing, not your usual cloyingly sweet, but just right. Makes you wanna go there and have pie all the time!

28.description: This is without a doubt one of the best American Restaurants on the North Side of Chicago.  My favorite menu item, the Pot Roast, has mysteriously disappeared from the menu, and I'm hoping that it's simply because it's considered a seasonal (see winter/fall) item.  The beef is amazingly tender.  Neither over nor under cooked. The flavor is exceptional, and is intensified with a nice, slightly thickened beef jus.These people know how to do beef.  The burgers are outstanding.  If you know the difference in an excellent burger, and a very good burger, you'll know how rare this is.  Ha.  I said rare.And they know how to do pulled pork.  This isn't a barbecue place that reeks of smoke like a proper "BBQ", but their pulled pork sandwich is tender and has a wonderful sauce that's a perfect balance of spicy, sour, and sweet.The Bread Pudding is perhaps the best I've had.  The apples are soft but still retain their shape.  The pudding itself is a country style, with larger bite sized pieces of bread.  But the miracle of this bread pudding is the caramel sauce.  No, it's not like any caramel sauce you've had.  You won't find it on ice cream or on an apple pie and certainly not in a store.  The sugar base is caramelized to a very dark color before being thinned to a perfect sauce consistency.  It's heaven.One of the newer items, the Tempura Fried Brussels Sprouts, is a delicious, but quite rich appetizer.  Order them, and plan on sharing them. Maybe even among three people.  The Wasabi dipping sauce absolutely makes the dish, but does not overpower the flavor of the sprouts.The ambiance of the restaurants feels more comfortable than uppity, and somewhat utilitarian and dated. This restaurant is not trying to impress you with its decor, although it is perfectly welcoming.  Table placement is somewhat close, and the restaurant is well illuminated at night.  I would not call it especially romantic. But it is seriously some of the best food you will eat on the North Side.

1.description: So I have to admit, it's been a few years since we've been here.  And I had fond memories of this place, so I took a few friends here for dinner.  Service started slow.  Even coming in the door, we stood around for awhile in a room of 1/2 empty tables before we were seated.  Opentable wasn't even needed (I made the reservation 30 minutes or so before arriving).  After we were seated, it did take some time for our waiter to take our order.  He did guide our friend to a delicious special wine they had.  Oddly enough, she swears that upon the second glass, they gave her something else less desirable.  Maybe they thought after the alcohol then and before we arrived, they wouldn't notice?  Not sure.  I liked my drink, which was Jose's Martini.  Something apple and pear infused I think.  It was delicious and not too sweet as some of these special martini's tend to be.  Kudo's to Jose.  Others took advantage of the $5 martini special and they were delicious as well. We ordered the Tempura Broccoli as an appetizer on the server's recommendation.  Personally, I found it much too thick on the tempura.  The wasabi dipping sauce is definitely an acquired taste and I really wish they offered a different option.  Like something more in the soy dept.  Anyhow, after a few pieces, I just was pealing off the tempura and eating the broccoli by itself.  For dinner, it seems I was the only one that really was satisfied with the selection - which was on the special menu called Paul's Pasta (or was it Pete's, whatever it was, I did enjoy the fresh tasting pasta that had a light Alfredo coating - lots of other ingredients like onion and zucchini in it, but honestly can't remember all of them except it was pretty darn good.).  A couple of our dining companions had appetizers for dinner - one being the muscles from the specials menu and he complained they were a bit gritty.  The other ordered the "Cape Henry Crab Cakes" (which I sampled) and both of us thought they were way too heavy on the bread and neither could find or taste the crab.  Hey, if you are that low on crab, just take it off the menu.  And the fourth had the flatbread, which she was disappointed in mostly because she could not customize the ingredients.  Apparently they are made ahead of time so, special orders are not possible.  I may have given this 3 stars if I just had the main course alone and if the service was a little more expedient (it wasn't that busy so not sure what was going on there.)I think I should have just rested on my fond previous memories of this place.

39.description: I took a friend for Sunday brunch and was certainly glad I made reservations. The room was packed and the servers were kept active. We had to wait for a table, but it was not long, less than ten minutes into our reservation time.The staff was attentive and very friendly. We were able to place our orders shortly, and considering the large number of patrons at the time, our food arrived hot and fresh in a timely manner. I ordered the pork chop and eggs while my friend had the Broadway Burger. We enjoyed every bite. When the weather gets warmer, we should try the outdoor seating and partake of the bottomless mimosas.Broadway Cellars is a wonderful neighborhood place, and I would recommend getting your reservations in for a good meal and a fun time.

9.description: I used to live around the corner from this place and cannot say enough good about it. Food is inventive and tasty and bottomless mimosas can't be beat. Also the bartender who works on the weekends, she's the sweetest!Only down side can be the wait. I go back because it's worth it but definitely make a res. If it's the weekend

29.description: Gathered with good friends for a great  meal last night at BC.  Been going there for years, have yet to experience a mediocre meal!  What set last night apart was the above and beyond service from waitperson Tim!  Very attentive and well informed, great banter with our table.  Ask for his section when you go!

23.description: The mushroom ravioli is delicious.  The wine selection is excellent.  Our server was attentive without being overly intrusive and I could actually hear all of the ladies at my table, both are always appreciated.

5.description: The brunch here can't be beat. First of all, you can make a reservation which seems to be rare for a brunch place on the north side. Secondly, bottomless mimosas for $10 or bloody mary's and mimosas for $15 - you can get in some fun trouble. Finally, the food is outstanding. Seriously - my friends and I have never been disappointed no matter if we are going with an old standard or trying a new dish. Broadway Cellars - for the win!

31.description: We love this spot. When we moved to Edgewater this became our group of friends' go-to brunch spot. We have since moved up to Rogers Park, and would still rather come to Broadway Cellars than any other place nearby. Mainly, I highly recommend their New Year's Eve dinner/open bar package, we've done it twice now and it never fails to be a delicious (and pretty drunken) good time.

25.description: Great burgers as well as other menu item staples. Wonderful wine selection and 5he owners are fantastic.

12.description: I came here with a friend on a Saturday for brunch. The ambiance of this place is great. I had the veggie sandwich on wheat bread with fries on the side. That, was rather refreshing on a warm summer morning. On the patio. Very nice dining area. Bottomless mimosas!! Great! If there was really such a thing! LOL so we got here at 11:15ish and ordered our meal and mimosas. We stayed for about 2 and half hours and had a few refills of mimosas. We weren't ready to leave but yet the waitress (which by the way was super friendly) gave us our check, weird. We weren't half way done with our meal but she said "I'll leave it here so I don't forget it" ok. Didn't think think much of it. Then she returned again and said "is this ready, no rush" by this time she annoyed me a little because she slowed down with our mimosas refills and asked for the check even though we didn't ask for it.Feeling rushed. Yes! Kinda rude too.We had a good time. My friend didn't notice the waitress. I did. I live to far to come here again. I didn't appreciate being practically kicked out. Too many mimosas refills! Maybe it should be bottomless mimosas for 2 and half hours!! Haha!! Sorry. I'm big on customer service. You serve people for a living. Do it right. Please and thank you...

37.description: I have been before, but recently took my visiting in-laws for brunch on a Sunday afternoon. It was the perfect place to go. My favorite is the quiche, but everyone was happy with their selections, which included two types of eggs Benedict. Plus, you can't go wrong with bottomless mimosas! The staff is friendly and the atmosphere is great, and even better when it's warm outside!

21.description: The brunch menu was decent but the bottomless mimosas were the highlight of my day. My glass was never empty. The waitress was on point with the refills!! I ordered the bbq beef burrito with avocado minus the scrambled egg...it was just ok. My BF ordered steak and eggs with sweet potato fries. The steak was TOUGH but those sweet potato fries were to DIE for. I give the food 2 stars but the customer service really won me over. Someone checked on our table often but not too much where it was annoying. KUDOS to the staff on being so attentive and YEESSS to those mimosa.

16.description: Broadway Cellars is great for a date night! They have live music and good specials. I enjoy their flatbreads and the pork chop. The service was a little slow.

17.description: A neighborhood restaurant that has risen in my opinion over time, but still occasionally disappoints. The chef there has taken a serious interest in recreating many classic dishes - a few with interesting variation - and I have come to have a certain security that those dishes will be delicious. Service varies a lot and there has never been an emphasis on server training, but overall things usually go pretty well.Last week there was an issue with our Open Table reservation that has left a sour taste in my mouth, however. I made a rez and checked in when I arrived, but when I got home there was an email from Open Table saying that the rez had been cancelled about an hour after we had checked in. I immediately called the restaurant and was told that they would fix the problem. Four days later, after the points never showed up, I was told by the owner, Barbara, that it would not be able to be fixed. A petty issue, but an illustration of the variation in the service experience.I still recommend the place, but am disappointed by this latest indifference to customer experience. We had been eating there about once a week over the summer, but without so much as an offer to buy me a drink on the next visit, not sure when we'll go back anytime soon.

10.description: Another great brunch place!Bottomless mimosas are a must if you go here! They're usually slammed so I highly recommend getting here early especially if it's a larger group!

11.description: I owe Broadway Cellars an apology because it took me nearly 8 years of living in this city, 3 of which I lived two blocks away, to finally try it out. My mistake. First of all, they don't play with the bottomless mimosas. My glass never completely saw the bottom before it got filled again. And hey, there's reasonably priced food too! I had The Grump, which was really good. However, my friend next to me order some pancakes...I think it was a special, I don't know if they're a regular part of the menu, but I'm pretty sure that if heaven offers brunch, they would serve those pancakes. I promise, I will not wait another 8 years before my return!

26.description: I ordered take out from here because of the great reviews, unfortunately neither my boyfriend or I was satisfied with our meals. The pulled pork BBQ sandwich was bland and dry but most disappointing were the sweet potato fries. They were completely flat and bland. We didn't finish either of our meals. A pro, the delivery was prompt.

27.description: Ok. I'm a white 20-something woman living in Chicago. It's a requirement for me to love brunch. I've brunched many places, but not everywhere. But I have to say (and have said many times) Broadway Cellars has the best brunch in Chicago. Others may disagree, but man oh man.Let's begin with the booze factor. $10 bottomless mimosas or bloody Mary's. You're just not going to beat that. They're also very generous with filling up your glass.The food is also fabulous! Their crab cake Benedicts are delicious. I also just recently ordered their dish "it's not easy being green." It's a Benedict but it's poached eggs on a spinach artichoke tart. Just fabulous! The broadway breakfast is good, as is the breakfast carbonara. I know pasta is not a breakfast food, but it you open your mind it, it's fab!I have been here for dinner on a couple occasions. The dinner options are fine. Truly, what they do well is brunch! If you haven't been, you need to go!

35.description: I owe Broadway Cellars an apology because it took me nearly 8 years of living in this city, 3 of which I lived two blocks away, to finally try it out. My mistake. First of all, they don't play with the bottomless mimosas. My glass never completely saw the bottom before it got filled again. And hey, there's reasonably priced food too! I had The Grump, which was really good. However, my friend next to me order some pancakes...I think it was a special, I don't know if they're a regular part of the menu, but I'm pretty sure that if heaven offers brunch, they would serve those pancakes. I promise, I will not wait another 8 years before my return!

8.description: Ok. I'm a white 20-something woman living in Chicago. It's a requirement for me to love brunch. I've brunched many places, but not everywhere. But I have to say (and have said many times) Broadway Cellars has the best brunch in Chicago. Others may disagree, but man oh man.Let's begin with the booze factor. $10 bottomless mimosas or bloody Mary's. You're just not going to beat that. They're also very generous with filling up your glass.The food is also fabulous! Their crab cake Benedicts are delicious. I also just recently ordered their dish "it's not easy being green." It's a Benedict but it's poached eggs on a spinach artichoke tart. Just fabulous! The broadway breakfast is good, as is the breakfast carbonara. I know pasta is not a breakfast food, but it you open your mind it, it's fab!I have been here for dinner on a couple occasions. The dinner options are fine. Truly, what they do well is brunch! If you haven't been, you need to go!

0.description: This review is for brunch only. One of my go-to brunch places. I will admit that it's partly because I live around the corner that I go here so much, but it's a solid choice to spend the early Saturday or Sunday afternoon (especially if you can get a spot on the patio during the summer). If you are looking for a nice boozy brunch on the far north side, this is your place. It's $10 AYCD mimosas or bloodies. When it comes to the food, I usually go with the Ned Beatty. I love the flavor and it sops up the booze you drank last night and the booze you are drinking that day.

38.description: Sunday brunch here was wonderful! Naturally, I'm in favor of the bottomless mimosas. I had the steak & eggs, it was great. I also dropped my phone between the long booth bench and the wall & Molly our server as well as another staff member were very helpful in getting it out! I will be back! Thanks!

20.description: Food is very good, but service on a Wednesday night was terrible.  Took over 1 hr to get 1st course. Totally inattentive. Had to ask for main course and the check.

19.description: Broadway Cellars is an unassuming place right in the heart of Edgewater.  The menu is very accessible American style fare.I've only been to brunch here which features bottomless mimosas and a good selection of menu items.  There is an outdoor patio on the side street which is nice and peaceful.  If you're looking to be in the thick of it, with a lot of action - this isn't your place; however, if you want to hangout, relax and have a leisurely meal then this is a great spot.  Recommended.

33.description: I had the tastiest steak and the tenderest green beans and the savoriest salad and the wait staff was kind and attentive and everyone else loved their meals too and the bread was the crustiest you can get on the north side. I love this place! I'm so glad it's in our neighborhood.

2.description: BRUNCH REVIEW:Their food is delicious and has a good variety.  However, the service for brunch is terrible.  I've witnessed fights between servers, servers disappearing for 30 minutes, servers who never refill coffee, and servers being rude or making me feel uncomfortable with their commentary.I really hope Broadway Cellars can step up their game because this is a great location and has awesome food but I am always left with a mediocre experience.

34.description: Went for the bottomless mimosas and ending up loving the food too! Everything I had was great. We were able to walk in but it was definitely busy, I'd suggest making reservations.

32.description: After having a great meal here for brunch a few weeks ago, we were excited to go back for dinner. Will never go back. Good first: the two stars are 1) for our server, who was a nice guy; and 2) for my wife's steak, which she said was really good. We showed up for our 8:30 reservation and it was kind of hectic at the hostess station with big groups leaving and a big delivery order going out. This is a casual, neighborhood place so no big deal. The hostess offered us a table near the window or in the back. We didn't want the window because it was a little chilly out, so we chose the back. And, boy did she mean back--like practically inside the bussing station. I think it was really a staff table that they put a tablecloth on. We could hear the crashing of dishes all during our dinner. Why we were seated here when there were other nicer tables open is beyond me. The noise of the banging of silverware and plastic tubs became unbearable at one point. A friend of the servers was eating dinner at the next table over and after he was finished, he stood near our table visibly eavesdropping on our conversation while he talked to the servers and busboys crashing plates and dishes around. My meal--trout covered in some kind of sauce with a cucumber salad--was not something I ever want to see again. I couldn't eat it. The fish wasn't fresh, the sauce looked like something I won't mention, and the cucumber salad was not a salad--it was a pile of sliced wilty cucumbers dressed in water, no dressing of any kind, with no flavor. I'm still, now several days later as I write this, shaking my head at this--I can't believe a restaurant whose whole business is to create a nice dining experience for people would be ok with treating their guests this way.

18.description: 2 visiting friends, a local chum and I had brunch here today.  We all loved what we ordered (I had the "breakfast pasta carbonara" - which was exquisite) ... and our waiter, Tim, was very pleasant.My friends complained that the bottomless alcoholic beverages they had were very weak... but other than that, the place gets raves from us (especially in regards to food quality and vibe).

13.description: What a great brunch! My husband and I met up with my friend and her husband (and their twin babies) just after open on Sunday morning. We had a reservation, which I would definitely recommend as the place filled up fast! The staff was super friendly and they were very accommodating in giving us a larger table and 2 highchairs. The portions are incredibly large. You can definitely eat half and save the rest for a 2nd meal. Or you can be like all of us and stuff your face with everything in front of you! Not a single complaint about any of our orders, which included the Ned Beatty bbq benedict, chicken sandwich, quiche du jour, and club sandwich. We did not partake in the bottomless mimosa option, but saw that many others did. Maybe next time!Would recommend for a casual brunch with friends, family, or a fun girls brunch.

4.description: Dined on a Sunday afternoon with my boyfriend it was his first time eating here. I know it gets packed on a Sunday so I called ahead made a reservation ,when we arrived she didn't even have our reservation noted down she had it on a tiny piece of paper. I didn't mind it she seated us quickly we date down and waited about 5-10 mins before the same lady who sat us down took are drink order. Then waited another 10 mins, our waitress didn't introduce herself just asked for her order and walked away. Once are food arrived she only came around are table once my boyfriend had to ask for a refill on his water and towards the way of our meal she came around to refill my mimosa. The food was great I was just disappointed with the service we received.

24.description: All the food was very flavorful. We sat outside and it was perfect, not too loud. Server was very attentive and friendly. Mimosas were on point, not too strong or too weak. Only giving 4 stars because there aren't any real interesting views, which we hoped for, but the flowers were nice. Will definitely go back soon.

6.description: Dropped in on a friday evening, $5 martini's, hard to resist. Had the Sesame crusted seared tuna. Was not only very eye appealing, but very tasty and it was not skimpy. A great value. Nice crowd. Will be back to sample some more.

22.description: I came here with a friend on a Saturday for brunch. The ambiance of this place is great. I had the veggie sandwich on wheat bread with fries on the side. That, was rather refreshing on a warm summer morning. On the patio. Very nice dining area. Bottomless mimosas!! Great! If there was really such a thing! LOL so we got here at 11:15ish and ordered our meal and mimosas. We stayed for about 2 and half hours and had a few refills of mimosas. We weren't ready to leave but yet the waitress (which by the way was super friendly) gave us our check, weird. We weren't half way done with our meal but she said "I'll leave it here so I don't forget it" ok. Didn't think think much of it. Then she returned again and said "is this ready, no rush" by this time she annoyed me a little because she slowed down with our mimosas refills and asked for the check even though we didn't ask for it.Feeling rushed. Yes! Kinda rude too.We had a good time. My friend didn't notice the waitress. I did. I live to far to come here again. I didn't appreciate being practically kicked out. Too many mimosas refills! Maybe it should be bottomless mimosas for 2 and half hours!! Haha!! Sorry. I'm big on customer service. You serve people for a living. Do it right. Please and thank you...

15.description: My husband and I had our 3rd visit to Broadway Cellars today (first time during brunch), and we've had such an amazing experience from the start that it would be selfish not to share it with the rest of the world. We both had steak and eggs, bottomless Mimosas, I had the flour-less chocolate mousse cake for dessert and my husband had their cheesecake. I think for the first time ever this was my first visit to a restaurant where everything went perfectly and I have zero complaints or suggestions for improvement. Our server Tim made sure our glasses were never empty and that we were pleased with our food, always very friendly and polite. A very nice guy that we were lucky to have as our server and to have a fun chat and share a bit about us and the neighborhood.We definitely recommend Broadway Cellars and next time we decide to stop by we'll be calling in advance to make sure we get Tim as our waiter again!

7.description: Great food - pork shank with a superb mole sauce, pork chop with mustard sauce, mushroom ravioli, sweet potatoes used to great advantage mashed or fried.  We all loved the tempura fried brussel sprouts with wasabi sauce. Very generous portions.  I recommend skipping the under-dressed, tasteless Caesar salad. Dropped to 3 stars because of lackadaisical service; not sure if they were understaffed on a busy Friday night or just a distracted waiter.  We wanted to order additional appetizers, but by the time the waiter returned, we skipped it.  Likewise with dessert.  These were not evening-spoilers, but they are the difference between a really good restaurant and one that is just OK.

36.description: Great place for Sunday brunch! Bottomless mimosas & bloody Mary's were a nice incentive. Bbq beef burrito, breakfast carbonara, bbq pulled pork on jalapeno cornbread are a must. Some outdoor seating is available, too. Make a reservation as this place fills up quickly & you really don't want to miss out!

30.description: Really wonderful brunch today. Delicious It's Easy Being Green Benedict--perfectly poached eggs atop a spinach artichoke tart with crisp potatoes. Out of the ordinary and very tasty!The waitstaff was so professional with our party celebrating my birthday! From seating everyone as they came in at different times to serving and packaging up the cake I brought in from Swedish Bakery, Broadway Cellars provided a perfect venue.

3.description: Stopped by here on a beautiful Sunday morning and was warmly greeted by the staff there! They were all very attentive and made sure we were comfortable and familiar with the menu.My friends and I ordered the Ned Beatty, The Grump, and the Salmon Benny. According to my friend, the Ned Beatty is perfect for someone who loves BBQ. The Ned Beatty was just what it is and the flavored are nothing out of what you'd already expect. The best part according to me friend were the potatoes.For The Grump, the crab to filler ratio in the crab crabs were lacking. There were also a lot of spices to mask the already very invisible crab flavor. As for the Salmon Benny, which was my fave and I had no complaints, the cucumber salad complimented the salmon very well. The dish was overall very refreshing and just the perfect portion for brunch! There was a good amount of salmon for the price. The potatoes pancakes were also a nice change from the usual English muffins of biscuits at the base of every Benedict. I would order this dish again!

14.description: Great burgers as well as other menu item staples. Wonderful wine selection and 5he owners are fantastic.

12.description: Third Coast Comics is a great place if you're looking for comic books. They have a very large variety of comic books. I truly recommend it!

7.description: This is a homey little comic book store with an excellent selection. The subscription service is excellent.

19.description: Ummmmmm what's with all the one-review posts? Suspicion!Saw this place for the first time last night and stopped in. They were hosting a knitting night. (I don't knit, but good to know that they host events.) I'm not a huge comics person, so I can't really speak to their selection, but I did end up walking out with a Chris Ware book. Terry, the guy working there, is very friendly and has a good vibe about him. I'll definitely stop back in.

1.description: I don't normally read comics, but I dropped in while exploring the area. The workers there are friendly, and they even gave me advice on other nice local places .

2.description: I love this place. Terry is the best, I always hope he's in when I stop by. I am disappointed when he's not. I stopped by after closing once and he let me in anyway. There are always events and great programming. The Doctor Who meetup group has frequent showings here and it's always a good time. There's an annual chili cook-off in the back courtyard. Free Comic Book Day is a big deal here. I like their selection of books as well. Especially since I'm not a huge comic person. I like them, but I don't read many of them.

9.description: I stopped in the other day with an eight-year-old Batman fan that was visiting me.  The owner was so careful to suggest age appropriate material.  He let me look at one of the comics for my review before handing it over to the child.  The owner ended up steering us over to a kid friendly section.  How impressive.  Someone thought of a little kid's best interest before making a buck.  We ended up getting a Batman chapter book.  We'll be back!

6.description: Top Notch Shop!! Just wish they had a bargain box for comics. Decently organized and a lot to offer , over I still wish they had a bargain box lol.

18.description: As a mid-twenties-something girl, I cringed when my boyfriend announced that a new comic book store was opening just a block from our place.  I've never really been "in" to comics much, so i've never had much desire to spend hours in a comic store, unlike him.  I've been dragged to comic book stores all over Chicago in the past with their "no look" policies (would you really buy something without knowing what it's about?  Not every one who goes to comic stores are comic-whores), unfriendly staff and their judgmental attitudes when I finally pick up a copy of Scott Pilgrim...hey, it's still a sale and i'm not ashamed to say I like hipster comics!The store, painted in Superman colors, is inviting and takes me immediately back to childhood memories of my favorite superhero, as opposed to the stark-white dullness of many other stores around.  The comics are displayed well so that you don't feel overwhelmed when you first walk in, and if they don't have what you're looking for, they can get it for you in a jif!  For those like me, new to comics and not sure what to buy, they are more than happy to guage your likes/dislikes to help you find new comics to enjoy.Even if you decide not to buy anything, stay around to chat!  TCC is focused on the customers and building good relationships.  They even have a beer-garden for comic-book meetups!  Yesterday we spent about an hour in there talking with Terry about comics and more.  I highly recommend Third Coast Comics to everyone from comic geeks, to people like me who just dabble every now and then, or even to people who just want to chat with the great staff!

10.description: Admittedly, I have some bias - I know the owner well, but even if I didn't, I can heartily recommend Third Coast.It's not your typical comic shop - no mouth-breathing, misogynistic fanboys work here. (I've only had that happen to me once, but at another, now closed store). What you *will* find is a staff that is willing to help you find the "right" book. Third Coast stocks both indie/small press as well as traditional superheroes; they have an *extensive* collection of trades (I always seem to end up making an impulse purchase when I'm there), and the store also sponsors regular events (including a monthly meet up). This place, quite simply, is a gem. Go visit. Now.

13.description: I have been to many comic shops in my day, and I have to say that Third Coast Comics in Edgewater is among the worst that I've been to. Admittedly, it gained 2 stars from me only because I couldn't give it the 1.5 it deserved.I noticed this little hole-in-the-wall shop while I was walking down Broadway near my apartment. I returned with some friends recently to check it out, and was seriously disappointed when I did.The shop is small, barely bigger than the size of my front room. Seemingly, the smallest section of the shop is dedicated to actual comics -- only one wall is dedicated to the three shelving units of single issues, and another on the opposite wall for indie comics. Looking over what little selection they did have on hand, I noticed that most of the comics were not anywhere near current. The largest section of the shop is up front near the door, which doesn't work properly by the way, where the few patrons other than me and my friends were sitting around in some bizarrely-fashioned reading section.We were there for over 30 minutes, and one of my friends had an entire 5-book run of comics in hand to buy, and yet no one said anything to us since we had entered. The staff on hand, which consisted of either 2 or 6 people -- I couldn't tell which, since those in question were all just standing around talking to each other near the register -- were your stereotypically overweight, neck-beard, fanboys who were all wearing varying degrees of Batman paraphernalia.We exited the shop without buying the comics, which was a good choice in my opinion, as I would be hard pressed to give this establishment any of my hard-earned money. I would be willing to pay the $2.25 to take the Red Line to Belmont and walk 15 minutes to the vastly superior Chicago Comics on Clark and School, or, begrudgingly, to Graham Cracker Comics on Broadway and Belmont.I would say that I am surprised Third Coast Comics is still in business, but with it being the only comic shop around, its unfortunately not hard to see why.

16.description: I can't say enough good things about this shop.  A comic shop can be an intimidating place for a woman who never read comics before but Terry has no problem getting you caught up or suggesting a great graphic novel based on the books or TV shows that you like.  He also hosts monthly meet ups, which are a great place to meet cool Chicago geeks and catch up on pop culture (and drink some beers).  Third Coast also gives 10% discount to Edgecard holders, so what are you waiting for?

17.description: Fantastic comic book shop in Edgewater.  Well organized with a very friendly owner.  They also host events from time to time which you can find out about on their website.One caveat is they don't seem to stock back issues.  I'm a trades reader so this isn't a problem for me at all.I really hope Edgewater embraces this place.

15.description: Stopped in on a Sunday. There was 1 employee working and maybe 1 other person in the shop.Not a lot of stuff in the shop, really just comics. I prefer when they have statues and other comic related merchandise.I was there for over an hour looking at graphic novels and the 1 employee never even talked to me.

0.description: Terry is a fantastic guy, I love talking with him and I love his shop. It reminds me of the good ole days when comic shops went in par with record shops. He is very thoughtful towards his clients and works great to get you what you want or need!

5.description: Very nice comic book store.  Well organized and they have a helpful staff, especially for a novice like myself!

11.description: I'm fairly new to the comic book nerd lifestyle, as I only started my freshman year of college thanks to an even nerdier friend of mine. I read a few titles that he already had, but then had no clue where to turn from there. I did a little research and had a vague idea of what I wanted, but when I ventured into Third Coast (my first ever comic book store visit), Terry was more than helpful. He let me be for the most part, but when asked for a recommendation he went to town. The guy's passion is finding what you as a person might be interested in, firmly believing that EVERYONE can find a comic they love.While the selection isn't super extensive, it's for a purpose: to make things more welcoming and easier for newbies to get access to. If there's a title they don't have, I've heard Terry is good about ordering. Now, three years later, it is still one of my favorite places in Rogers Park/Edgewater.

8.description: You know you're in the right place when the first bit of conversation you hear is on how "Charlize Theron was a bad ass and Kristen Stewart sucked in Snow White", then you jump into the debate as to who would/ should play Wonder Woman in the new movie. Yep, they make you feel at one with your geekiness. Plus, actually have a good knowledge on the issues they carry which also includes a nice indie/ local artist selection. I stopped in for some new bags & backs to redo my recently regained collection from my Mother's dusty attic. I had no idea they were different kinds and I learned that the old school backs has some sort of toxic substance, so they recommended starting fresh on all of them. Prices are fair and they don't just stock the new stuff, back issues are in the back of the store. I have no doubt they will see me again.

3.description: Love this place! Terry is super welcoming and I got everything I needed. Support your local comic book shop!!

14.description: I love this place!  I have not paid much attention to comics since the mid-80's but have always enjoyed good superhero and related stories.  I accidentally found this place while walking off a huge brunch at the nearby Bananas Foster Cafe.So, since the 80's a lot of cool stuff has happened with comics.  First of all, there is a massive genre of Zombie comics.  It's all even cooler than it sounds - Spiderman Zombies, Jesus vs. Zombies, Ash Williams from Evil Dead movies vs. Marvel Zombies.  I had to pinch myself with all of the new awesomeness discovered.Here's the best part, the staff were great with walking me through some good issues to buy.  I had basic questions, they were enthused to talk Zombies with me.  Very helpful.  Good store layout too, and a collection of graphic novels and some other merchandise.  My wife found plenty to browse through for the twenty minutes or so I was there.  Comics are for adults now, and I can't believe it took me this long to find out!  Third Coast Comics is a great place to go, browse and discover some cool new takes on the comics you might not have looked at since the 80's.  There was plenty more than Zombie stuff.  I stocked up on some Doctor Doom related comics too.  I can't speak to how this store responds to the needs of the hard core comic fan, but for a novice it rocks.  Make it a full excursion and have brunch at Bananas Foster Cafe which also oozes goodness.

4.description: This is a very good Comic book store, you have a great selection of comic books from Marvel to Dc, to Adventure time comics and graphic novels written by local Chicago writers. If your looking to get a comic for yourself or a gift for a friend it's a good place to get what your looking for.

58.description: This place compares favorably with a Treasure Island and/or a Trader Joe's, but with an Eastern European bent, as well as a Latin selection second to none, and a TON of fresh meats and produce.

56.description: Great place.  They have a good produce section with good prices.  They even have a few organic items here and there.  Overall I rate this place high.  Nice neighborhood place, much better than Jewel or Dominick's when it comes to produce.  Not as good as Stanley's in Lincoln Park.

29.description: So...I'm not a clean-freak.  A bit of dirt is a part of life, and I'm fine with that.Except, I went here for the first time a few days ago.  And in one particular part of the store--not even a back wall or anything, but more where two rows of shelves met in the center--I smelled the distinct smell of pee.I thought for a while maybe for whatever reason the whole store might smell like that (sometimes small stores have weird smells), but it turned out to be just that one place, like it was fresh.  Not anywhere near a produce counter or fish counter or other source of potentially odd smells.That made me pause and think. What could make a grocery store smell like pee right by the produce and dry goods section?  And not near any bathroom I could see?My first thought was, "Oh, they must let a cat patrol or something at night. It's a city, there's probably mice and rats and that's what cats are supposed to do as working animals: control rodents."  I'm actually ok with this.But the more I thought about it, I realized with our modern health code cats likely aren't allowed either, and the store was dingy enough that while I'm cool with a patrolling cat, you should also be using other measures too. And a good cat shouldn't pee outside of their box. (I know they do, particularly males, but I'd think if you were using a cat as rodent patrol, you'd replace it until you found one that didn't do that in a food store.)And I don't know if it was cat pee.  It could be rat pee.  Or mouse.  Or heck, human. My nose isn't exactly an expert on determining species from the smell of pee.So experiencing this really bothers me, particularly inside a grocery store.  I've been to Edgewater Produce and Skokie's Marketplace on Oakton, both of which ALSO specialize in fresh produce and/or ethnic foods.  Neither have ever smelled of pee. I've never smelled pee in any of the big chain stores either.I think I won't be coming back here.  Even though they're the first store I've seen which has something like the cream horns I used to be able to get as a kid from Eagle in the suburbs.  But the smell of fresh pee is a bit much for me.

42.description: Good produce.  Small local grocery store.  Great fresh cooked bread!

23.description: Clean nice place. Just wished they had more bosnian food. Only reason for a lower rating.

47.description: I am giving the Devon Market a 5-star review for its customer service.  Harry was very helpful to me and I wanted to thank him by giving the store a great review.  In addition, I found the store to be very well-stocked and if offers reasonable sale prices.  This was my first time here and I will be coming back.

8.description: I saw a rat running down the meat refrigerator today, believe it or not!Never coming back again here

31.description: Nice produce and meat selection. Large parking lot. Sells beer and liquor, which isn't all that common in this area.Otherwise I was completely lost trying to find a bottle of Margarita mix. Not a well organized store. I asked one employee,  he directed me to the wine aisle.  It wasn't there. Another employee sent me to customer service. Customer service sent me to the juice box aisle. So yes I did find 4 employees willing to help, but not one that could tell me where it was. I left twenty minutes later with no Margarita mix.

34.description: Love this place. Great fresh produce, nice assortment of ethnic food and pastries too. Neighborhood gem!

16.description: One of the worst checkout wait times of my entire life. Cashier chatting with what appeared to be her boyfriend or another employee who was leaving work. Took about 20 minutes to buy a bag of ice. Only one customer in front of me in line.

13.description: Been meanin to update my review.There's been some nice improvements. Now there's a juice bar in there, the raw meats have come down in price a tad bit. I don't see the arrogance of owner(s) anymore. Just a cashier or two that isn't polite but click on "ignore" sequence & we're all good.Again this is not the kind of place to do major grocery shopping. But when you don't feel like driving anywhere (if you have wheels to do so) & you need only a few items, it doesn't hurt to stop by here. Prices are affordable. Meat quality is good. Bakery stuff is REALLY good (better than I last remember).For some reason now the store has a nice amount of character. It's ok to run in for stuff when you have that small gathering at your apartment & you're out of something. Good staple for the neighborhood.

11.description: If you have a problem or complaint, the owner could care less about you.  Recently, I noticed a very unsanitary procedure behind the deli counter.  I witnessed one unprotected hand grabbing pieces of food from a tray being prepared at the same time by another co-worker for the general display counter.  Disgusting, took a picture and reported this place to the city of  Chicago.   The counter girl's 4 inches of hair hung over the food as her saliva fingers kept mopping up the food into her mouth... NO LIE!She wanted her picture deleted but I refused as she was in a public place and I had every right to keep the picture as proof.  After witnessing this, in combination with the owner's, I couldn't care less approach to my concerns when I tried to reach him.... NO return calls! ....  I filed my complaint and vowed never to walk in here again.I wouldn't send my dog in here to eat if this is how unsanitary this place is.Eat here at your own risk....

39.description: I actually agree with Claire. The products and prices are great no doubt about it but the cashiers are so rude. It is rude when they keep talking to their cashier neighbors while they are ringing you up! They need to be more friendly. I barely shop here but the times I've done there's been only a couple of them who had greeted me, the rest are terribly bad at greeting the costumers!!!!

37.description: Back when I used to live on the North side of town, Devon Market was my go-to when I needed something fast and fresh. They have high quality produce and carry different ethnic foods.Their meat selection is diverse and of great quality. The prices are competitive with what is in the area. Some of their middle aisle products are a bit pricey, but again, they are key in a pinch.I like that they are a mid sized grocer. I had Dominick's close by, but was never satisfied with what I found there. I also had the rinky dink grocers nearby, but those were iffy at best.Patronize Devon Market, so that when I'm in a pinch and on the northside, I can continue to buy great food.Now, go.

0.description: This place rules. Amazing produce selection with regularly great sale prices. Decent beer selection too. Good wine selection. And all kinds of awesome little other things for ye of strange unpredictable tastes, like packaged rainbow trout for $3.00, exotic cheeses, or $12 bottles of Russian vodka. And the employees, so nice!!

38.description: Good service,prices and lots of different products from Europe.I would recomend to everyone who is looking for good food.For weekends baked pork or lamb.Good job.

51.description: I have no idea why people shop at this place.  the produce is all second rate quality. there are other stores on devon with better prices and quality.  at least at jewel and dominicks you get decent produce that lasts.  what good is it if you have to throw half of your purchase in the garbage?

27.description: I go here for most of my grocery products. They always have friendly customer service and a wide selection. Their produce is fairly fresh as well.

32.description: Its a decent neighborhood mart. They have a good selection of produce and other goods. I will say if you like customer service and the friendly chit chat you wont get that here. What you do get is a decently priced grocery store that's walkable. I do wish that there was a person on staff to help with their large wine aisle. There is soooooo bottles that it would be nice to have someone who knows wine and can make a recommendation.

54.description: It has the nice local-feel to it, but it has a very limited selection (as expected since it's small) and the produce was pretty bad. Maybe I just chose the wrong day to go.

48.description: I love Devon Market for the following reasons, they have awesome produce and meat selection and the sushi is even great! I love the Euro section as well! I have always had great customer service too. The only thing that is strange is that I find that the items pricing/aisles are not labeled well. It's a small store but sometimes I wander in a circle trying to find something because cereal and olive oil are in the same place! Other than that, love it!!!

44.description: A friendly, happy, neighborhood market with a variety you can't beat for the prices. The Deli counter staff will make sandwiches for you and they are much more affordable than any other options in Rogers/ Edgewater

24.description: Fantastic selection of fresh fruit and vegetables at the best prices. Went there yesterday for ingredients for pasta dish and got couple different kinds of mushrooms, salad fixings and smoked bacon from deli. Also great place for fresh bread and usually warm. Great value at great prices.

7.description: Not good if you are looking for organic food. They had absolutely no organic produce. Wish the quality of food was better here.

49.description: I have gone to Devon Market  weekly for several years. I am amazed at some of the negative reviews but having seen some of the customers, perhaps some of them got the treatment they earned. I always bring in a back pack to self pack groceries and no one has ever questioned me. The prices are fantastic, expecially for produce and meat.  The staff is nice, helpful and eager to please and I'm just some old white guy, not eastern european or any other  in group.  Love the little asian lady who makes sushi and is so eager to please customers, The Deli staff is lovely and make some of the best humas. Mexican-style meats are great, too.  I just wish they carried salmon and shrimp that wasn't farm raised.   I visit Dominicks for some of the staples but mostly just to remind myself of what a rip off Dominicks is and Jewel...don't even get me started.

40.description: Such a little gem in Rogers Park. Great produce selection and very reasonable prices. I work nearby and usually come here to get some lunch. They have some yummy selections in the deli, including fresh veggie rolls. I can usually get out with a great lunch for less than $6. The people who work here are friendly and helpful. It can get really crazy at certain times of day, so I try and make it here before the 5:00 rush.

53.description: I lived near this place for years and never went in.  That was my mistake.  The produce is the best in the city and the prices are way below jewel. Their meats and deli have everything.  Lot of wines and great sushi.The only really downfall is that the canned foods and sundries are overpriced. But just the meats and the produce makes this a very worthwhile trip.

30.description: Don't try to grind any other coffee than on the grinder 8 something. And they were completely vehement about that.

46.description: My biggest issue with this place: Hi prices. some items are up to $2 over the normal grocery store price (I know because just came from Jewel Osco and Trader Joe's earlier today for the purpose of comparing prices). They have a wide selection of some items (pickled vegetables), and a limited selection of other items (only 2 brands of real cheese). Some prices are simply outrageous, so that bothered me quite a bit. However they stay open until 10 and they are around the corner from me. They also were cool about taking my passport for wine b/c I lost my license. Not the worst grocery store in the world, but they are definitely not going to be my regular grocery store. I appreciate that the produce seems fresh, but $0.50 to $2.00 extra on many items will add up to paying hundreds more on groceries this summer than I need to. I'm not into donating money to businesses for no reason.

1.description: This isn't a huge supermarket, but it's big enough. What I like best about the store is (1) The produce is good, and they have a higher proportion of floor space given over to fresh stuff than many stores, plus with good prices. (2)The staff is friendly, while behaving exactly like real people: the checkers and the deli people especially. (3) There's a pretty good selection of ethnic food: Hispanic and central European (the owners or managers are Bosnian Ithink, and about half the above-mentioned staff is Eastern European), and some Oriental.They have a fair selection of low- to mid-range wine and beer, including lots of brands from Romania, Croatia, Hungary, Poland, etc. Their wine prices are reasonable; their liquor prices are high.Feb 2016: The store has gone somewhat downhill in the last six months or so. There has been a fair amount of personnel turnover, and the new people are less friendly and, mostly, less knowledgeable: in particular the security guy as you come in - Pete is gone now, had been a fixture for many years, knew every nook of the store, and was very helpful. The new guy is OK I guess, but brusque and of course doesn't know the store well.In case the owners read this: in the winter your checkout people are freezing, because the cold air comes in from the front door constanly opening of course. They've been wearing scarves and sweaters and some of them even gloves and coats. It might cost a bit, but how about a bit of forced air heating for them?

55.description: The Devon Market.  Friendly neighborhood grocery, that brings ya that kinda small family atmosphere.  Prices are so-so, but good enough for inbetween major trips to Aldi or Dominicks.  Prepared foods are good.  Decent selection of wine, and the produce is always fresh and outstanding! Happy to support small businesses like this!

9.description: Something about the Devon market has a really homely feel. Right when you enter you will notice it is always busy and rightfully so. They have a great selection of fresh fruits and vegetables and even a freshly squeezed juice area. I have noticed that the pastas are a little more expensive than I would get at say Jewel but this store does have almost everything you need. They even sell baklava and sushi! There is an area near the front with freshly baked bread and some treats!

26.description: If you have a problem or complaint, the owner could care less about you.  Recently, I noticed a very unsanitary procedure behind the deli counter.  I witnessed one unprotected hand grabbing pieces of food from a tray being prepared at the same time by another co-worker for the general display counter.  Disgusting, took a picture and reported this place to the city of  Chicago.   The counter girl's 4 inches of hair hung over the food as her saliva fingers kept mopping up the food into her mouth... NO LIE!She wanted her picture deleted but I refused as she was in a public place and I had every right to keep the picture as proof.  After witnessing this, in combination with the owner's, I couldn't care less approach to my concerns when I tried to reach him.... NO return calls! ....  I filed my complaint and vowed never to walk in here again.I wouldn't send my dog in here to eat if this is how unsanitary this place is.Eat here at your own risk....

25.description: i honestly don't understand how does city inspection allows filty place  like this to stay in business most products that come over seas are outdated i have given like 3 times try each time its outdated on product date is fine but product inside like cookes turned green i was like omg how is this allowed in chicago?

12.description: Okay selection, sedated employees, prices vary widely, and layout is extremely confusing.Yes, the deli is in the back, the veggies and fruits are around the edges and dairy is on the opposite end of the store from produce. Other than that, I have no idea where to find things consistently. I cannot discern any type of logical layout for all of the food NOT on the edges. Want all of the chips in the same place? Nope. Think snacks should all be in one aisle? Nope. I have been here at least fifty times.Prices: Some stuff is cheap other things not so much. Just keep an eye out. The employees here are what brings down the store rating down the most. Except for the security dude, who is always helpful and friendly, the people who work here cannot be dragged into helping you. Pleas for help often get futile pointing---with rolling of eyes if you ask for anything beyond pointing. Employees never smile and consciously avoid eye contact. Even the checkout people can barely begrudge a small cold "hello"; let alone a "hello" with any warmth behind it.I frequently come here with a bemused look on my face thanks to the confusing layout; I have never heard a hello or been asked for help. Sad.Several of the reviewers have noticed that this place isn't clean. I have to agree. I am not a neat freak. I am of the "What doesn't kill me makes me stronger" school when it comes to germs. However, this is a place that sells food, not a home depot. Would it really be that much to ask an employee to windex some shelves once in a while? I'm not even asking for dusting. I just think that mystery stains are gross when I am buying non-packaged food.

59.description: This is my neighborhood grocery store and I love it. In a world filled with mega-chain, over priced options for grocery shopping, the Devon Market is a sanctuary from my childhood.Fresh, seasonal veggies that aren't over priced, an *actual butcher counter where they actually butcher stuff*, bread baked in-store, a full deli counter and staff which is helpful, friendly and greet me by name when I walk in the door; Devon Market is how grocery stores should be - local, personal and affordable.I know some people have claimed to have other experiences at this neighborhood grocery store, but I've been shopping at Devon Market for the entire six months since I moved into Rogers Park and I've never seen the staff be anything other than helpful and respectful... even to a woman I watched the manager catch in the act of shoplifting a bottle of wine. He was patient, albeit firm, but still completely respectful. I -personally- find it hard to believe some of the other reviews I've read about this place... I say that as a person who stops into the market three or four times per week.

21.description: The way grocery stores used to be. You could get to know the cute girls in the deli section, or grab a fresh juice from the juice bar. I couldn't find any organic fruits and vegetables though. That was disappointing

17.description: So...I'm not a clean-freak.  A bit of dirt is a part of life, and I'm fine with that.Except, I went here for the first time a few days ago.  And in one particular part of the store--not even a back wall or anything, but more where two rows of shelves met in the center--I smelled the distinct smell of pee.I thought for a while maybe for whatever reason the whole store might smell like that (sometimes small stores have weird smells), but it turned out to be just that one place, like it was fresh.  Not anywhere near a produce counter or fish counter or other source of potentially odd smells.That made me pause and think. What could make a grocery store smell like pee right by the produce and dry goods section?  And not near any bathroom I could see?My first thought was, "Oh, they must let a cat patrol or something at night. It's a city, there's probably mice and rats and that's what cats are supposed to do as working animals: control rodents."  I'm actually ok with this.But the more I thought about it, I realized with our modern health code cats likely aren't allowed either, and the store was dingy enough that while I'm cool with a patrolling cat, you should also be using other measures too. And a good cat shouldn't pee outside of their box. (I know they do, particularly males, but I'd think if you were using a cat as rodent patrol, you'd replace it until you found one that didn't do that in a food store.)And I don't know if it was cat pee.  It could be rat pee.  Or mouse.  Or heck, human. My nose isn't exactly an expert on determining species from the smell of pee.So experiencing this really bothers me, particularly inside a grocery store.  I've been to Edgewater Produce and Skokie's Marketplace on Oakton, both of which ALSO specialize in fresh produce and/or ethnic foods.  Neither have ever smelled of pee. I've never smelled pee in any of the big chain stores either.I think I won't be coming back here.  Even though they're the first store I've seen which has something like the cream horns I used to be able to get as a kid from Eagle in the suburbs.  But the smell of fresh pee is a bit much for me.

10.description: I'm becoming a big fan of D.M.  I especially like the cookie aisle and love the Greek chocolate wafers for $1.00!  Yummo.There's also a Mexican bakery department that puts the actual bakery up the street to shame.  $1.00 for two lovely cherry or apple turnovers delicately laced with sugary and flakey dough.  The breads are delish as are the tortas - you can buy 7 pastries here for the price of one at the competitor up the road -- your kids will love you for it :)

5.description: A great store- I love the "European" feel, the fresh baked breads and pastries.
