However in the fridge they had an abundance of two flavors and the one that had the ice cream I wanted had a peanut butter cookie. I'm sure people love peanut butter cookies I'm just not one of those people. So I go to the counter and ask if they can make me one with a chocolate chip cookie instead and the guy looked at me like I just asked him for his first born. He started trying to come up with an explanation which kind of ended up sounding like he didn't want to make it. So to end his long speech I just asked so those are the only ones you have and he quickly responded yes. Hmm you would think something made in house would be easily made. Anywho I had the fat Elvis ice cream and it was delicious. I will definitely come back but probably earlier when they have different staff.

33.description: The ice cream selection wasn't great. They were out of almost all of their flavors on a Monday night. What gives? I ended up having to get one of their take-home options from the freezer and once I got home, I realized that the brand of ice cream wasn't even their own house brand. It was some brand from Wisconsin and it was awful. I couldn't even finish half of it. I'm just not sure why so many people seem to be impressed by this place but maybe I'll give it a second chance.

43.description: It's not the most cleanest but have so many choices. There was a homeless guy inside but the fact that they let him stayed inside while it was freezing cold was a nice thing to see.

2.description: "You salty!" If I were a novelist, I can only imagine the types of characters, situations, and places that would make those words come alive. But in my simple world of "I scream, you scream, we all scream for ice cream," those words--your name--are the only ones that come to my nervous tongue as my eyes absorb your creamy caramel texture; the only words I can purr as I run my tongue across your salty chocolate stripes; the only words that will pass through my lips as they absorb your salty caramel flavor; the only words that can pass my teeth as they nibble on your salty cashews, and the only words that I can sigh with resignation as I suck the last bit of melted goodness from the bottom of the moist sugar cone in which I held you. Oh, "You salty." You live in a tasteful, chef-inspired equivalent of a beauty pageant runway; yet after ogling all the others, and sampling quite a few, my heart remains with you. Even after taking home a pint of your goodness, I still didn't tire of you.You sweet. "You salty." I only have ice, in my freezer, for you.

18.description: Always great selection of ice cream with a couple of soy options. Nothing but polite employees :) And temperature color-changing straws!Got a root beer float using horchata ice cream

41.description: Friendly staff and best butter pecan ice cream I've ever tasted! An instant favorite on my list of places to get a treat.  A++

52.description: Ice cream! I was initially overwhelmed by the wide variety of flavors. But after assessing all they had to offer, I was quite pleased with my selection. I'm glad I went with the junior scoop. It was more than enough to satisfy my craving.

50.description: Fantastic! If you are looking for something sweet, look no further! Cookies, cakes, and decadent ice cream in many flavors!

4.description: Great ice cream shop if your in the area.  Cake desserts also.  The ice cream is Ice Cream Shoppe ice cream.  I wouldn't drive out of my way to visit but if you're in the immediate area this is a great place to relax in the coffee shop style seating while the kids play hop scotch on the pattern in the floor.  Parking situation is brutal in the area.

6.description: George's is a must-stop for me any time I'm hanging out in Andersonville. It's a really spacious ice cream parlor with tons of tables and even some couches for you to lounge on and enjoy your ice cream. It's in a great location right on Clark in the heart of Andersonville too!They offer a wide variety of ice cream flavors that change over time. I had an amazing super blueberry one the first time I ever visited. I also tried one of their pre-set sundaes that had everything chocolate all piled into a bowl. DELICIOUS! It's hard enough to choose a flavor or two without even considering all of the sundaes and shakes they offer too.Service has always been extremely friendly every time I've been. Definitely try a few flavors before deciding which ones you're going to devour.5 stars for this great ice cream shop!

22.description: Really happy with it. The vibe inside the shop is really great and we spent a good amount of time just sitting inside and eating... There are so many flavors to choose from and most of them are original mixes (not just the traditional chocolate/vanilla/cookies and cream/etc). I definitely felt like I got my money's worth

15.description: Absolutely loved George's! Such a cute little place, decor is cute, place is clean, staff was nice... We had a 3scoop sundae.. I'm not much of an ice cream person, but I've gotta say, I'd definitely come back for some! Next time I'll try some of the baked goods or maybe the chocolate dipped Twinkie!

57.description: Add me to the list of people who are head over heels in love with this place! Friendly, cheerful staff, a huge selection of delicious flavors (including soy flavors for those of us who can't do the "real" stuff), amazing looking baked goodies that I can't wait to try, plenty of room to sit, fun atmosphere with fun music, oh and tons of old school vintage CANDY. You just can't go wrong at George's. I kind of want to move in.

20.description: It was quite busy when we went, and the line could probably have moved a little faster (things got a little melty while we were waiting by the register to pay). But the ice cream and atmosphere was wonderful. Wouldn't be surprised if this is the best in the area.

36.description: We hit this place frequently during the summer months (at least once a week on our date night cap off)......okay winter months too. How can you not?

14.description: Delicious flavors and cool artwork. There's also a great selection of cake and candies. There's a really pretty and relaxing patio in the back that you can enjoy during the summer, and it butts up against Alleycat Comics, so you can have coffee or ice cream and then stop in Alleycat to get something to read. The reason it didn't get 5 stars is because the lines are always really long, and they don't have a coffee grinder even though they sell some of the best coffee.

28.description: Breads and jams and veggies and cheese oh my!!Andersonville Farmers Market is great. I love how many tents have food samples to try. Seriously, because of this I probably bought more than I should...well played! It's smaller than some markets, but has most everything you need. You could def make a meal with everything here, plus a few extras. It's Wednesdays from 3-8 so it's nice that I can go over after work. They even have live music! This will now be my go-to market for the summer!

1.description: You can't help but love classics like Goldfinger, and Secret Agent Man on an accordion.  That was the live music selection at today's winter farmer's market.  The market is small with maybe around 20 vendors.  They had homemade candies, pastries, soups, bread, and salsas.  I ended up with some great  organic winter spinach and winter radishes, and also some ciabatta bread.  (I think I see a sandwich in my near future.) I was also intrigued by the never-ending knowledge of the black garlic vendor, and ended up with some of that, too.  Though the market is  small it's a good place to pick up some fresh goods, and commune with your neighbors.  And, it gives you just a taste of summer when all the outdoor farmers markets are in full swing.

39.description: I think Mr John B. should give this Market another chance!! Though I do agree with him on the idiots that think bringing their double wide (but have only one kid) strollers is a good idea. Even at 6pm the tables were full of all kinds of delicious treats. Fresh fruits and vegetables, cheese (which I couldn't get enough of the samples... sorry), even some unique items like soap, dried herbs, and infused vinegars. Jarred goods galore, meats, and breads filled my eyes... note to self don't go hungry. All in all I walked away with a bottle of dill infused vinegar, a Santa Fe herb rub, zucchini and some squash. The best part is that it only cost me $12 dollars.I like to also mention that each and every both had the nicest people selling their product. This would normally give it five stars but it really was a pain to get in and out. If you have the time check it out for yourself.*** They also selling potted herbs so you can grow your own at home, well worth it for someone who cooks a lot.

9.description: This farmer's market is friendly, convenient, and has so many wonderful local and organic options.  The only downside is that it is very small.  If you can find whatever it is that you are looking for on the block between Clark and Ashland, then this is an excellent option.More so than other Farmers Markets that I have been to, this one hosts many vendors who do more than just raw goods.  You can usually find artisan bread, cheeses, tofu, pastries, and other local creations.  This is nice if you're trying to put together an entire meal from the market without rounding out your shopping list at a large supermarket.Some of the vendors can be a bit pricey... that's the cost of quality products.  Fortunately many are becoming credit-card friendly and if you should need cash there is a US Bank with an ATM just up the street.

29.description: This review is specifically for one of the Andersonville Farmer's Market vendors, Videnovich Farms. I just moved to the neighborhood this winter, and I'd really been looking forward to the farmers' market. It's been a busy summer, so I don't get to go as much as I'd like to, but the 2 times I've been so far, I've stopped at the Videnovich Farms stand, and both times it was my favorite vendor to stop at. I believe the person at the stand is Vera, and she's just awesome. She's a very personable person, she's quick with a smile, and she seems to really enjoy letting people know about her farm, the vegetables, and, the most interesting part, the yarn. Her farm has sheep and she creates skein's of wool that she hand-spins. She leaves the wool in its natural shades, and it's amazing the variety of shades the wool naturally comes in. She also dyes some of them using flowers, plants, etc, creating beautiful colors. Another great thing about Vera's stand are the smells! She's got cinnamon basil, lavender, and other things that smell so good. I felt like I was transported to the farm in Michigan. Part of what I enjoy about going to my local farmers' market is the opportunity to socialize and to interact with vendors. Vera, of Videnovich Farms, really seems to have quite a flair for talking with market goers with a friendly demeanor and a knack for providing information about her wares. I'm definitely thinking about buying some beautiful yarn from Vera and making a scarf, or giving a skein of yarn to a knitter-friend. I definitely recommend checking out her stand, at least to experience the evocative scents, or even a little chat, and, who knows, maybe you'll even end up taking home some lavender, yarn, or a pepper.

23.description: Hump Day only gets better during Andersonville summers. I adore this farmer's market most of all for the focaccia, berries & cherries, purple carrots, mushrooms, cave-aged cheeses, seasoned tofu, free samples. There is no need to buy your produce anywhere else during these months. You can make a single twenty-dollar bill stretch for you, OR trade many more bills than that for some of the finest delicacies wo/man can naturally grow or produce.Plus they accept credit cards. Plus the vendors love dogs.

5.description: This was the 2nd Farmers Market I've gone to in Chicago and again wasn't very impressed. Had less vendors than the Logan Square Farmers Market. I went on 6/4/14 and just felt the display by the vendors was thin overall. I arrived around 6:30p so with an hour and a half left I'm sure it's not uncommon to be out of product. I did take note that one vendor (Twin Garden Farms) wasn't present as they are advertised on the website. I was hoping they would be there because of their unique corn on the cob. I did not see any signs of them there. It was also a rather cool night and it had been raining most of the day so that could have impacted the overall sad feel to the market. I will give it a go again in a few weeks or so as I want to support local busniess.I was again disapointed with the lack of fresh cut flowers and one vendor with just potted ones for gardening.

31.description: Fantastic! Any time I want to spend $5 for a small jar of cheese spread, no scratch that . . . . any time I want to spend $5 for a small jar of SPREADABLE CRACK COCAINE, I'm coming to the AFM and Brunkow Cheese of Wisconsin (of course). Ohmyfreakinggawd. This stuff is so good, and they have a small hibachi on site, for grilled cheese curds. This cheesehead rejoiced. I was powerless, my wallet sprung open beyond my control.Also great Concord grapes, and apple cider. What was priceless was procuring really healthy, delicious snacks (grapes and free samples) for a hungryish "I want a snack!" kid.Great, small market in the best 'hood in Chicago. Pricey, but eh - every once in awhile, you have to indulge. Oh, and running into My Favorite Yelpers at the market? Priceless as well.

25.description: Love the hours, love the produce, jams, breads, ice cream, meats, juices, granolas...

12.description: I really like this farmers market. I don't feel overwhelmed with selection as I do at other farmers markets (not that I'm knocking you Daley Plaza, but sometimes I just leave with an apple because there are too many varieties of all produce) and there is a neighborhood feel to this farmers market. I've been here 4 weeks in a row and several tents know who I am as they start reaching for the honey crisps and the sun burst tomatoes. The prices are reasonable---I purchased slightly beat up honey crisps for $5 (I chose the second hand looking ones as they were $2 cheaper) and 1/2 pint of organic sunburst tomatoes for $2.50. It can get crowded as it's on a narrow strip of Berwyn and many people bring strollers and/or dogs, so be aware of that before heading in. Also, they have a token system in case you forget to bring cash (like me).

37.description: Uh....YUM!  There were samples everywhere!  And they worked because we left with bags and bags of goods, that's for sure!  Tofu, tea, cheese, and fruit samples galore! We were serenaded by some kiddos sing-a-long much to my ears disgust....but guess you have to make it a family affair!This is a great little market that is perfect for the after work crowd.  For that mid-week time where the produce you purchased on Saturday is no longer looking to pretty, or just gone altogether!The cheese man will be my new best friend and I love John B. for pointing him out in particular.  Everyone was so nice in explaining their products.  It was a great neighborhood market.  Although a bit cramped, especially with strollers and dogs everywhere.  If only all the booths could move back a foot, then I wouldn't feel like I was running into everyone with my backpack.Will be back again that's for sure.  And the fact that I have farm fresh produce in my fridge on a Thursday is wonderful!  What a great ending to a work hump-day!

21.description: I'm only able to make it here near the tail end of the market, which is unfortunate. They are open on Wednesdays from 3-7. Obviously, it's a farmers market, so all the food there is generally what's available AT THIS TIME. It's all local-ish vendors, as well. It's a nice market with nice vendors, but it's pricey. It's great supporting local farmers, but honestly, I wouldn't be here every week just because I can't afford to spend $30 on a few fruits and vegetables on a regular basis. Good quality stuff though. There were some SERIOUS blueberries last time I went. Super serious. And tomatoes. The tomatoes were superb.

16.description: My apartment smells fabulous right now, because I'm slow roasting tomatoes from the farmers market. Because they were "seconds" -- some overripe, some bruised, none perfect -- I got a 10 lb bag for 5 bucks. That's cheaper than The Jewels.I've fallen hard for my local farmers market. It's not big, and there isn't the variety of some markets, but to quote Spencer Tracy in "Pat and Mike," what's there is cherce.What is there? Well, the usual rundown of fruits and veggies, of course. Apples are coming in, and the beloved honey crisps are everywhere. ($5/qt, which in my case was 7 apples, which is much better than The Jewels.) Though I'm a little put off by the winter squash. Too soon! But it's the non F&V stuff I tend to buy here. Great breads - if a little pricey - from Bennison's. Amazing fresh and aged cheeses from Brunkow Cheese in Wisconsin. They have a raw milk white cheddar and horseradish spread that is amazing. And an aged cheddar that is one of the best things I've ever put in my mouth. And you know there's a lot of competition there. Preserves from Rare Bird which include - are you sitting down? - strawberry chocolate. And so much more. Infused vinegars, herb rubs, fresh eggs, fresh pasta. Goat meat! Krsna, are you listening?Of course, most of this stuff isn't cheap. Sure, there are bargains like the tomatoes and apples, but the eggs are $4.50 a dozen. But a half pound of 6 year aged cheddar for 12 bucks is more satisfying than a pound and a half from Kraft for the same price. Go for it.The market must be doing well, because it has been extended until Oct. 7. (Originally, Sept 9 was going to be the last day.) Hours are now 3 to 7. I assume this means they'll be back next year. Which is good news for all of us.

17.description: The Andersonville Farmer's Market is great for your dosage of local-produce-warm-fuzzies for the week. It's conveniently located (right off Clark), which is nice, but it's a little small (no parking lot for these guys, they have to make do with the side street).I feel it's friendlier and more intimate than other farmers markets I've been to in the city. They have a nice selection of produce, and you can certainly get a lot of your weekly (healthy) grocery shopping here with fruits, vegetables, eggs, cheeses, tofu, pastries and more!

10.description: This is one of my favorite things in the neighborhood, and there are a lot of things I like in the neighborhood. There's a solid variety of vendors (many of whom have free samples... just saying) and prices are fair.  If you know what's in season, you can probably get a deal. The focus is definitely on produce, which works for me.I also really like that it's in the evening, which helps me avoid the less-than-preferable scenario of hanging around with 3 pounds of apples and/or tomatoes after my lunch break/until I go home.

11.description: I finally made it the whole 7 blocks away to this farmers market. Andersonville is technically a part of Edgewater, but let me tell you, this farmers market rips the pants off of the Edgewater market! It is no jealous sibling, but a hulking behemoth of wonder! What a slacker I have been for not making it here sooner!! Oh. My. GOD! There must have been 7 or 8 stalls of fresh veggies. I have been craving tomatoes like a heroin/crack whore and supermarket tomatoes will not do it. I had to get my fix. And let me tell you, I have been nodding in tomato glory all week! They were not horridly expensive, and super wonderful!!! THE CHEESE, oh, the CHEESE is to die for. I came home with some fresh mozzarella and a wonderful horseradish cheddar spread. Spread? you may be thinking- Yes, add a dab of this to noodles and you have the best darn Mac-n-Cheese that you can imagine! Add some mixed mushrooms from the vendor (10$ for a really full bag) and you are set for some of the best Mac and Cheese that you can imagine! My mouth is watering just thinking about it again. I am going back this week, and next week, and every week until they close. Yes, they do sell bakery items, ice cream, meats, you name it. But between the cheese, shrooms, and tomatoes, I am the happiest person you can find! I wish they would teach the Edgewater people how to do it. This is two blocks worth of stands, delicious, wonderful stands!

26.description: as i write this, i'm eating a breakfast of cherry vanilla bean granola, fresh red raspberries, perfectly ripe peaches, and vanilla yogurt.  i know you're jealous, but don't worry!  you can have it all too!  all you have to do is go to the andersonville farmers market.it really rocked my world.  tons of amazing produce and handmade concoctions.  i loved the balance of fruits, veggies, breads, meat, cheeses, desserts, and even kombucha and ice cream!  also, they have a spot set up for local musician groups to play music, and a puppet show across the street.  i realize the puppet show is for kiddies, but i was thoroughly entertained.i thought i'd died and gone to heaven, until i checked my empty wallet.  it's a leetle pricey, but the quality is far above and beyond the store that it's worth it.  the only thing i didn't like was that i just found out about it a week ago!  ack!  must make up an entire summer's worth of farmers-marketing in the next couple weeks!  which should be simple, given that it runs from 3pm-8pm on wednesdays.  nice!

27.description: I've vowed to go to this wonderful farmer's market every Wednesday from now on.  I love it!!  The fruit is so sweet, juicy, and amazing that we finish it within 2 days.  The cheese spreads and breads are also delicious!  I've recently purchased an asiago-garlic loaf from Bennison's and it was soooo good....melted asiago cheese and chunks of garlic!  I'm so tempted to buy so many things from this market, but I'll just do it little by little and try something new every week.

35.description: I love the farmers market! I would highly recommend Videnovich Farms.  We have purchased their CSA box which we pick up each week at the market and have not been disappointed.

8.description: I appreciate the fact that this market is open into the early evening hours. This is really wonderful especially for people who work full-time during the week. This market features a myriad of produce items, many kinds of breads and excellent meat vendors. This Farmer's Market features a rotation of vendors (merchants), which s a great way to give new vendors an opportunity to participate every other week. You will see items, such as, baked goodies and fresh real fruit jams. Due to the "rotation" of vendors (merchants) you may not see a specific vendor the following week. One vendor that I was very happy to see this year was "Black Garlic North America" which offers aged, fermented garlic which has a sweet, delicate taste and balances most dishes perfectly. I love using this garlic in different meats as well as using it sparingly in salads, grilled salmon or broiled Talapia. I also purchased some organic vegetables and fruits. I even found corn, which is very hard to find at a Farmer's Market. Picked up a few ears for my husband who loves corn on the cob. This Farmer's Market is open through October 15, 2014 and every Wednesday from 3 to 7 pm. Gotta love it!Due to "space" this is not a huge Farmer's Market, however, it has some wonderful items. I like the size of this market, because it doesn't take long to get through the entire market and hit up most of the vendors here. I have been to many, many Farmer's Market over the years and most close by early afternoon. On the other hand, this Farmer's Market is open until 7 or 8 pm (depending upon the day of the week and time of month). This year the market opened two-weeks early, which was very exciting for those of us who enjoy a great Farmer's Market. There are nearly 30 vendors offering everything from fresh-cut flowers, wonderful bottles of wine to a myriad of cheese to honey and including fresh lamb, delicious ripe fruits and unique vegetables. If you enjoy tea in the fall and winter time (or year round) you must check out the gourmet tea vendors. There are pies, gourmet pasta sauce and unique salsas that you may not find any where else. I noticed some people brought their knives (yes, you heard correctly) -- knives -- and someone will sharpen your knives for FREE while you walk around the Farmer's Market and shop till you drop!I met Brady Bradine at the Farmer's Market. This is his fourth year being a vendor at the market. He sells all-natural, whole grain baked goods, which I can appreciate but can no longer eat. For example, Brady sells cookies, cupcakes, muffins and brownies from his bakery located in Oak Park, IL (it is called "B True Bakery"). I didn't purchase any items from the "B True Bakery" but my friend purchased a cupcake and cookie for her husband. I gave up sweets and anything that contains sugar, but I do admit my mouth was watering and everything looked fantastic and smelled super fresh. My friend rated the cupcake with 4-stars (as she ate it while we were walking around the market). Her husband enjoyed the cookie and said it was "very, very good." He didn't rate the cookie. However, he inhaled the cookie very quickly so I will take this to mean that maybe the cookie was/is 4 or 5-star worthy.If you have not been to a Farmer's Market this Summer, get your ass over to Berwyn Avenue (between Clark and Ashland Avenue) and treat yourself. This is their sixth year. I love a good Farmer's Market, and appreciate that they also offer organic products that will not break your budget. I also appreciate that they accept credit cards, debit and LINK cards which makes it very convenient for everyone to shop at this Farmer's Market. Some of the other Farmer's Market that I have shopped at this Summer are "cash only" but not the Andersonville Farmer's Market. Out of all the Farmer's Market that I have been to this Summer this is one of my favorite markets. It is such a great community of people and the vendors are fantastic and sell quality top-notch products. It is affordable so I can purchase healthy organic items for a lot less than I would pay at Whole Foods! Check out this market before it ends. You will not be disappointed!Hhhhm, I am not sure why someone voted this review as "Funny." Strange.

0.description: I am starting to be a bit of a meat/veggies snob. I don't get to Farmer's markets as often as I would like. Although this market is not the most conveniently located to where we live, I would go out of the way to do my shopping here. They have a good variety of vendors here. One can find almost every kind of perishable and it is all local! All of the vendors are friendly and more than happy to tell you about their wares. Not only are the vendors awesome, the crowd is also really cool. Started up a few conversations with folks just standing in line or browsing.. This is going to be on my rotating schedule of farmer's markets to attend!

38.description: Bread: $5Cheese samples: $0Tofu samples: $0Appreciating bright, colorful berries in the sun: $0Seeing lots of fine products, friendly people, and supporting local businesses and my neighborhood: pricelessWhen you can give up a Saturday morning and take at least one or two legs of public transportation to get to a decent farmers market, knock yourself out.  For me and everyone else, this is my market.

20.description: Sometimes, I forget that I live in the nation's third-largest city... and that sometimes usually happens when I'm perusing the Andersonville Farmers Market.As expected at a farmers market, there's free samples for the taking. I'm talking in-season jams, glorious cheeses grilled on the spot, handmade tofu, cardamom blueberry granola, banana foster-flavored popcorn, quickly-snapped-up ears of Iowa corn and juicy apricots. But, bet you didn't know real smiles were up for grabs, too! I'm wearing my ear-to-ear Sunday grin on a Wednesday... hump day, my dears, has never rocked this hard. Where's that apron?And when I awake tomorrow, I'll have my way with organic eggs, sweet gypsy peppers, oranges juiced by the hands of yours truly and a slice of zucchini bread. I believe this is what we Americans call "stopping to smell the roses" though more accurately, I'll be stopping to smell the heady fragrance of fresh-cut lilies (also purchased at the AFM).If you forget your cash, don't despair - you can buy tokens on your credit/debit card and they basically work like cash (you'll get hard change back). This small, easy-to-navigate open air market is open 'til 8pm every summer Wednesday, and they keep it going into the borrowed days of Indian summer, too.LOVE. That is all.

19.description: Ah, the midweek highlight that is the farmers market! I miss it already. I only moved to the neighborhood in the late summer, so I can speak more to the fall offerings than spring or early summer. My favorites: Apple cider from Michigan. The beautiful name-your-price flower arrangements, run by the friendliest young women. Homemade caramels in the most delicious flavor combinations, like honey vanilla or rose. Halloumi cheese and tofu. Squid ink pasta. Samples GALORE. Take a few laps to compare prices, then dive in. Enjoy the live music, the dog friendliness, cheerful vendors, and best of all, the late operating hours.

33.description: My apartment smells fabulous right now, because I'm slow roasting tomatoes from the farmers market. Because they were "seconds" -- some overripe, some bruised, none perfect -- I got a 10 lb bag for 5 bucks. That's cheaper than The Jewels.I've fallen hard for my local farmers market. It's not big, and there isn't the variety of some markets, but to quote Spencer Tracy in "Pat and Mike," what's there is cherce.What is there? Well, the usual rundown of fruits and veggies, of course. Apples are coming in, and the beloved honey crisps are everywhere. ($5/qt, which in my case was 7 apples, which is much better than The Jewels.) Though I'm a little put off by the winter squash. Too soon! But it's the non F&V stuff I tend to buy here. Great breads - if a little pricey - from Bennison's. Amazing fresh and aged cheeses from Brunkow Cheese in Wisconsin. They have a raw milk white cheddar and horseradish spread that is amazing. And an aged cheddar that is one of the best things I've ever put in my mouth. And you know there's a lot of competition there. Preserves from Rare Bird which include - are you sitting down? - strawberry chocolate. And so much more. Infused vinegars, herb rubs, fresh eggs, fresh pasta. Goat meat! Krsna, are you listening?Of course, most of this stuff isn't cheap. Sure, there are bargains like the tomatoes and apples, but the eggs are $4.50 a dozen. But a half pound of 6 year aged cheddar for 12 bucks is more satisfying than a pound and a half from Kraft for the same price. Go for it.The market must be doing well, because it has been extended until Oct. 7. (Originally, Sept 9 was going to be the last day.) Hours are now 3 to 7. I assume this means they'll be back next year. Which is good news for all of us.

2.description: My favorite local farmers market I've visited, by far. I've always wished the season would start a little sooner than the first week of June, though. Maybe they'll finally heed that advice, and start a few weeks earlier for 2014? I can understand the season ending in mid-October, due to the fact it starts to turn very cool enough right around that part of the fall. I still really wish their farmers market season would begin at least by mid-May, though.Though some of the vendors are a tad expensive, I always find something to enjoy about this farmers market every time I go. If you have a chance and a Wednesday afternoon/early evening to come by, check it out.

34.description: This is a great little farmers market that is being spoiled by inconsiderate patrons.People, please, it's a small area.  No, it's not OK if you run into me with your bike.  It's not OK if your dog gets startled in a small area and goes crazy.  It's not OK for yuppie mommy to assume that they have the right of way just because they're pushing around their little darling.Going to have to agree with the previous poster in regards to the hassle created by inconsiderate people that don't have the common sense to a) lock bike on uncrowded street b) leave fido at home or c) be considerate and not use their stroller as a battering ram (it's just plain rude to use a stroller to nudge someone out of the way!).As for the food, there is some great produce by a few vendors. It's nice to see Phoenix Bean have a stall.  There is meat/eggs available, however some vendors don't bring certain items because, as one vendor said tongue in cheek "the Green City Market is the best and that's where they sell most of it".Prices are a little high and you can tell that the vendors are setting prices together.  Coincidence that all vendors have the raspberries priced exactly the same?  I think not.  The convenience, in spite of the bad behavior demonstrated by selfish people, makes it worth the trip on Wednesdays.

32.description: Great place.  The staff works hard to make it very enjoyable and I love the samples.

18.description: Fantastic! Any time I want to spend $5 for a small jar of cheese spread, no scratch that . . . . any time I want to spend $5 for a small jar of SPREADABLE CRACK COCAINE, I'm coming to the AFM and Brunkow Cheese of Wisconsin (of course). Ohmyfreakinggawd. This stuff is so good, and they have a small hibachi on site, for grilled cheese curds. This cheesehead rejoiced. I was powerless, my wallet sprung open beyond my control.Also great Concord grapes, and apple cider. What was priceless was procuring really healthy, delicious snacks (grapes and free samples) for a hungryish "I want a snack!" kid.Great, small market in the best 'hood in Chicago. Pricey, but eh - every once in awhile, you have to indulge. Oh, and running into My Favorite Yelpers at the market? Priceless as well.

13.description: This is a nice addition to the neighborhood.  The vendors are friendly and there's a decent variety of organic meat, produce, and breads to purchase.  They even have knife sharpening while you shop!

4.description: The Andersonville Farmers' Market is just like the neighborhood (quaint, cozy and friendly). There's great selection for produce and other items (breads, meats, eggs, treats, etc.).The prices from vendors could be cheaper, but I guess the standard prices for Chicago farmers markets are marked up in general. Another recommendation would be if they had more vendors with made-to-order food. I love the market and it's a staple to my Wednesday evenings throughout the summer.

24.description: One of the best farmers markets in the city. Great variety of vendors from veggies and fruit to tofu and grass-fed beef. It's nice that this market is in the evening and more relaxed than crowded Saturday farmers markets.

6.description: This was my first time at the Andersonville Farmer's Market. It had most of the items that I was looking for.  Typical farmers market. The market is compact since it's only couple of blocks long.  There are plenty of options for veggies and fruits, but organic and non-organic.  The only item that I didn't find was corn.  The red and black berries are delicious.    The Bruni-Uusto cheese stand is incredible which you can taste before you buy a packet or two.It's great to have this market during the week to replenish your fruits and veggies that you have bought over the weekend.  The evening hours is a plus.Looking to return.

22.description: You can't beat the hours at this farmer's market - 3-9 for the working man.  Add in Phoenix Tofu w/the amazing tofu noodles for a few bucks, the stand that sells garlic dip to die for, lots of fresh produce, and music to accompany your buying frenzy = best way to spend an hour on a Wednesday.  I look forward to it every week!

15.description: Ok...Admittedly, maybe I'm just easy (when it comes to Farmers Markets), but I love this one.  Andersonville is a great area, the vendors are always super friendly, I meet fun people there, and they have goParking:  Street (meter) on Clark, but there are plenty of other options around (Ashland, Rascher, etc.) with free street parking in the neighborhood.Gluten Free Friends:  They have yummy GF options too.  Side Note:  Right nearby is Andie's.  They now have GF Pita to go with the hummus!  ;)

7.description: Sometimes, I forget that I live in the nation's third-largest city... and that sometimes usually happens when I'm perusing the Andersonville Farmers Market.As expected at a farmers market, there's free samples for the taking. I'm talking in-season jams, glorious cheeses grilled on the spot, handmade tofu, cardamom blueberry granola, banana foster-flavored popcorn, quickly-snapped-up ears of Iowa corn and juicy apricots. But, bet you didn't know real smiles were up for grabs, too! I'm wearing my ear-to-ear Sunday grin on a Wednesday... hump day, my dears, has never rocked this hard. Where's that apron?And when I awake tomorrow, I'll have my way with organic eggs, sweet gypsy peppers, oranges juiced by the hands of yours truly and a slice of zucchini bread. I believe this is what we Americans call "stopping to smell the roses" though more accurately, I'll be stopping to smell the heady fragrance of fresh-cut lilies (also purchased at the AFM).If you forget your cash, don't despair - you can buy tokens on your credit/debit card and they basically work like cash (you'll get hard change back). This small, easy-to-navigate open air market is open 'til 8pm every summer Wednesday, and they keep it going into the borrowed days of Indian summer, too.LOVE. That is all.

36.description: Is it Wednesday yet? Is it Wednesday YET (pants like a dog in anticipation)?!?!?! My tummy longs for the abundance of free samples and my eyes wish to feast on the all the super fresh veggies & fruit these farms have to offer. Oh and my wallet wishes to ache (yup ache) at being emptied at said farmers stands. You cannot see it, but I am doing the "raising the roof" gesture in my eagerness. Oh boy, oh boy do I get excited about Farmers markets--I absolutely LOVE them. To me it is a treat to talk to the farmers who are ever so proud of their wares & they should be. Nothing like fresh, local and in most cases organic produce. Plus, (HELLO!) you get to try all the stuff. The extrovert that resides in this body loves the crowd as well, they all seem pretty happy to be there & there is nothing I love more than things that foster community. This one does not fail in that department. I have to give it up for the A-ville farmers market, each week it gets better & better (I do agree with Nick--John B needs to give this bad boy another chance). For their 1st year in operation, they are running a very swell market. More farms get added & the organizers are getting a wee bit better with their spacing of the booths. Plus, now some of the farmers take credit card (phew!) which is a nice plus since I do not like carrying lots of cash. Now, there are some bad things about the market as well: *it gets massively crowded (especially after 5pm since the after work crowd starts arriving). *You could possibly get run over by a child or run on over in your rush to get to a booth. The kids are everywhere--so watch out. *The booths cannot be on the sidewalk, so it can be tough to maneuver around the market. Prepared to be jostled--that is the way it goes folks. I do look forward to this every week & highly recommend you check it out if you need some produce midweek and like Kelli said--especially if getting up early on a Saturday morning is not your thing.

30.description: I was walking down Clark St. on the hunt for post-work beer and not wanting to venture from my hood, and I happened across the farmers market. Did I NEED salsa? Nope. Did I NEED two types of grapes? Nope! Did I need bread? Nuh-unh! Did I NEED corn or apples? Well, I'm sure they're productive to a healthy diet....but no! And no, I didn't know what Kombucha even was before yesterday. And yet, there I was, 30 minutes later, hobbling back to my apartment with my hands full of bags of random produce. Never even got my beer. Had Kombucha instead.

3.description: I stopped by last week.  The Andersonville Farmers Market is a decent size with lots of samples to taste, and is far bigger than the tiny one in Edgewater and the so-so one by the Loyola el.  It might be around the same size as the Rogers Park one by the Morse el.  Like other Farmers Markets, they offer a LINK matching program.  In Andersonville's case, this means that they'll charge your LINK card a certain amount (say $10), and then give you $20 in cardboard tokens.  You then use the cardboard tokens to buy goods.  While this of course doesn't let you spend in denominations smaller than $1, so you can't buy taste portions, it avoids the nonsense I saw last night in the Rogers Park Farmers Market.  There, the two women operating the LINK machine couldn't figure out how to correctly bill the customer, and kept overcharging her.  In the end, I'm pretty sure they underpaid the vendor by $1.50.

14.description: Great way to spend a summer evening! Andersonville is such a great neighborhood so you can venture out to shop or dine when you are finished shopping.  Great produce from local farmers is the perfect match.  From farm to your table is a great feeling.

58.description: Toasted Sandwich Cubano To Taste with  Smoked Ham, Roasted Pork, Swiss Cheese, Pickles, Mustard & Mayonnaise served on fresh, crispy French bread.  Delicious!

56.description: I wish I had known this was a lunch spot!  This place should be named La Unica Restaurant because there's no way you would go there for groceries.  They have maybe 3 or 4 things in their produce section and the rest seemed to all be 2 liters of soda.  The reviews for the food are great, so I plan on stopping in for a good Mexican meal soon~!

29.description: Don't order from here.  Ordered Chicken Flautas with Yellow Rice, and a side order of Yellow Rice.  Both rice dishes were delivered with WHITE RICE.  The only thing I like about this restaurant is the Yellow Rice.  Well, I've only ordered from them once before, but this will be the last time.  Grubhub said they were out of Yellow Rice and they credited me $4.00 on the order, but the rest of the food sucked.  I took a picture of the soggy pile of white rice that they sent with the order.  Disgusting.

42.description: I come here all the time and haven't had a chance to write a review. Great cuban food. Great prices.Try the fried pork or stewed turkey leg. Most of the entrees come with rice and beans and either yucca or plaintains. Cuban sandwich is a must! Flan is amazing.

23.description: This place is nothing short of amazing. My wife is Latino and when it comes to any type of Latin cuisine she is very picky. Let's just say it's been two days since our meal and she is still raving about this place. Happy wife = happy marriage. Thanks for helping me towards a happy marriage La Unica!

47.description: Hell to the yeah! Authentic and delicious cuban sandwich. Ive been looking for a really good cuban sandwich all over this city.  I would say only thing missing is the pickle and some mustard. Moving on...Congris is yummy,  peruvian green sauce is banging, ham croquette was great.   Only thing that sucked was the cuban bunuelo.  This place is really well priced.  I think I found my new fav spot to order from.

8.description: Such a good restaurant! Their special is really good also the Colombian style empanadas are the best I ever had! Great service great food all in the back of a grocery store but hey I don't judge I think that's what makes the place stand out and authentic.

31.description: The ox-tail here is great and the portions are big! This dish also included sweet baked plantains, rice, and black beans.  Also included was a spicy green sauce, that was awesome sauce! Hahaa! I recommend this meal to anyone that loves Latin American food!I also got the Colombian empanada, which was alright, I prefer the Argentinian and Cuban empanadas. Also got the bread pudding, which was the most unusual bread pudding I've ever had. But it was very good! It was made with coconut and I think some type of sugar or honey native to Colombia, not sure! But I liked it, and I also recommend this if you are looking for a great dessert to try.Overall, solid Latin American food, and I will order again. I got the food delivered, and it was quick.

34.description: I really wanted to like this place! It's always these weird grocery store/restaurant/whatever places that have some food gems. But wow, were we disappointed. We ordered two cuban dishes for delivery. One was a steak dish with an egg and the other was a steak with a fried chicken leg. Both came with white rice and black beans. (These two were the best part of the meal)When the food was delivered (in about an hour) we were hungry and ready to eat. The delivery guy was great! Very kind and thanked us for ordering. I opened up my styrofoam container and the smile was wiped right off of my face. What I saw was an unseasoned piece of skirt steak with an over-easy egg covered in onions on top of white rice. I kept my faith. Maybe presentation isn't their strong suit. After all it's a plated dish that was delivered. Ok I took a bite of the egg. Ok. Egg. You mess that up and you aren't even a real person. Moving on to the steak. I truly think that they just tosses this on the grill raw, unseasoned for 10 minutes and said ok, steak is brown. It tasted like cow. Like beef. Like the actual animal. (Maybe sounds weird but you'll get it if you try and unseasoned pics of meat). I was so thankful we had the rice because we would've starved otherwise. So in the end we paid $30 for two sides of white rice and a very disappointing meal.

16.description: Fried YuccaYes!  The pathway to my heart may just be paved with fried yucca and chocolate (probably not together).La Unica does it right, for real.  In addition, Their empandas have the best crust, the one most similar to what I was used to while living in South America- I just wish they included cheese inside.I love the Cuban Sandwich, I always order one for dinner the next day.The shakes?  You cannot go wrong!

13.description: The food is excellent!!! Great customer service. Everyone is friendly. I'm glad we came across this neighborhood gem. We had the chicken  rice and plantains! So delicious! We were in food comas after lol. Will definitely return and they deliver too!

11.description: Ordered the beef stew, which at first glance is nothing to gaze upon. However, once you take a few bites, you understand. The plantains, with the beef stew, with the potatoes, with the rice....the food never ends. They are more than generous. I can't compliment their Cuban sandwich, which was pretty disappointing.The beef stew plate earns a 4 star rating though.

39.description: What a great surprise to find this place in back of a supermarket. I had a Cuban sandwich with a mamey shake and it was great. My friend had pozole and it was delicious. Victor Perez our server went out of his way to entertain us and make us feel welcome and comfortable. If you want to try authentic Cuban and Mexican cooking hit this place. It is awesome!

37.description: Ordered off grubhub, the description said the tacos came with lettuce, sour cream and cheese. Got my order, there was only meat and tortilla on the taco. Not too upsetting but def a bummer. Called the restaurant, let them know what happened, the owner or manager said he would be happy to redeliver the food. I didn't want to wait another hour to eat so I said it wasn't a big deal- he then told me to call back when ever I decided I wanted those tacos. Called back, like the asshole that I am today and he wanted me to pay the delivery fee again and tip(which I would have anyways). Ended saying I didn't want to do all that and hung up. Super frustrating managing style for a restaurant that people seem to like. Not into it.

0.description: Take your pants off at the door.There will be sex.Mostly in your mouth, but it's always good to have your wizards staff accessible.You will enjoy blessings from the Lord through the divine conduit, La Unica.

38.description: food was phenomenal-as were the people and they have menus  in english for non spanish speakers. well worth a visit and a second and a third and a fourth.

51.description: All I can say is the food is from heaven! The spices the chef uses o this reminds me of my days in NYC.  I had to move live here for $%^& years for find this place. I went then turned my cousin Ms S onto it and we are hooked!!

27.description: In high school I used to run over to La Unica during my lunch break to get some tasty yucca and a liquado before I had to get back to class. I was usually 5-10 minutes late anyway! Favorite Cuban/Colombian/Mexican restaurant and grocery I've been ever to. Affordable, traditional, and fast! Siempre es un placer.

32.description: I've been coming here since I was a child. My grandparents would make this trip all the time from the suburbs.  Although it has a variety of latin american food and a good amount is cuban, this place is COLOMBIAN. There are very few places where you can find the real colombian food that I grew up with and this place has it all.  The prepared food is also great :) we always ordered it to go. I would highly recommend this place :)

54.description: Stopped by this place because Restaurant.com offered a gift certificate for it. The food was AMAZING. We felt bad about using the certificate because it was so freakin' good. I got the Hearty platter and I barely could walk around afterwards. Whatever they put on the potatoes - again - my god. My mouth is currently watering and we're hoping to stop by here once a week.

48.description: The menu here is in Spanish, and no one who works behind the counter (this is based on 2 experiences) knows--or acknowledges--how to speak English, even to the extent of translating the menu and taking your order.  So I ordered what I knew how to order in Spanish--arroz con pollo with black beans and sweet plantains--and that's what I got.  I asked for dark meat and I got it, but I suspect it was either luck of the draw or they always serve it.The heaping plate of yellow rice, pimentos, & peas couldn't have been tastier, and the fall-off-the-bone chicken seemed poached in a pot of chicken soup.  There were 4 whole bay leaves in the small dish of black beans, so seasoning was not a problem.  Hot sauces on the table were hot. The only miss were the plantains.  They should be moist, glossy, and sweet.  the one's served here were inert, dry logs of banana, not sweet at all, and semi-burnt.  Maybe they're always like that here, or maybe they were dried out from long hours on the steam table.  Not good. At all.This place serves some good food and it's fun to find it in the back of a grocery store, but let's not get carried away. No-one has taken the time to prepare an English menu. Hospitality--along with good food--counts in the restaurant business.  So 3 stars instead of 4.

44.description: This place has fabulous and harder to find Central American and South American groceries. I was in for quesarito, masarepa and yucca flour (which it turns out, is tapioca flour!) to make bunuelos. I was so pleasantly surprised to see that their meat department is also top-notch, they have carnitas on offer and that there is an excellent super cheap cafe with both Cuban (awesome Cuban sandwiches here) and Columbian food on offer, along with espresso-based coffees. I had one each of the Cuban and Columbian empanadas, and they were both so good and very different. The Columbian one, which will be the less well-known, was made with a cornmeal-based dough, stuffed with yucca, beef and a greenish sauce. It was undersalted a bit until I poured in the chimichurri they served alongside and then it was perfect. So moist inside and crispy outside. The Cuban empanada had less in it -- basically just meat seasoned and onions -- and a crisp flour dough that was thinner than the Columbian counterpart. Still very yummy, but the Columbian had more going on. At $1.30 each, you should do your own taste test and try the coffee while you're there!

24.description: I have to say that this is, by far my favorite Cuban food on the North Side of Chicago, that's right I said it!  I love the flavors of the ropa vieja, the empanadas, the croquettas, the Cuban sandwich, yucca, plantains.. I can go on but you can see I love everything about this place.The place is simple, set up like the Cuban cafeterias in Miami, nothing fancy, great service and great food, that's all I really need!  And when you do go here, make sure you order a cafe con leche, I am not sure what they put in it but it is not to be missed!

7.description: Must say this is a hidden gem. It's a restaurant grocery store weird huh but not weird for Chicagoans. Well I always get the pollo empanizado ( breaded chicken) comes with white rice and fried plantains. I order a Extra side of yuca Frita ( fried cassava). Must say the people who dine here are diverse, which makes me happy a lot of people are willing to try Latin American food.

49.description: I feel bad for being kind of a wet blanket on this place, but I really felt that the food was mediocre.  I have significant Cuban sandwich experience, and these just weren't worth coming back for.  They were surprisingly dry and there was virtually no mustard; I really didn't taste any at all.  Perhaps I got a bad one, but I was just not blown away.  The service was really nice and they make a great cup of cafe con leche.

40.description: Fried YuccaYes!  The pathway to my heart may just be paved with fried yucca and chocolate (probably not together).La Unica does it right, for real.  In addition, Their empandas have the best crust, the one most similar to what I was used to while living in South America- I just wish they included cheese inside.I love the Cuban Sandwich, I always order one for dinner the next day.The shakes?  You cannot go wrong!

53.description: The definition of a hidden gem.  Delicious food, good service, huge portions, and a low cost.  I've only been here a few times, but each meal was excellent.  The Cuban sandwich is the best I've had in Chicago.  The sancocho was delicious!  The broth alone was great, but it also comes in a large bowl filled with fall-off-the-bone tender chicken, yuka, potatoes, and a side of rice.  The portion of soup is huge and it's more than 1 meal.  I also thoroughly enjoyed the oxtail.  It's sooo tender and carefully slow-cooked in a delicious sauce.  It comes with a large side of black beans and rice and I think a sweet plantain side as well.  They offer a nice selection of sodas from Colombia, Peru, and Mexico in addition to the usual US sodas.  One of the main reasons why I know that La Unica is legit is because I'm one of the few, if not the only, gringos in the place.  I look forward to eating here again and again.

30.description: i have been going here for over 20 yrs but it will never be the same . it was a cuban store and cafeteria with different  foods but now its just like a mexican restaurant. and those are every where .the service is a joke and dont call in your order bc they won't start it till you get there .some of the food is good bc they have one cuban cook. and he is off on Monday and they might give you Mexican rice.miss the way things were : (

46.description: I was really disappointed that their so-called "El Cubano" (the Cuban sandwich) was not very authentic. What makes a Cuban sandwich an "authentic" Cubano are the pickles and mustard piled high with the shredded pork and ham. Then, it is put in La Plancha which really makes it "El Cubano." The sandwich was not horrible, but it certainly lacked something. I lived in Miami, FL many, many years ago (it was a job transfer for me) and I can honestly say I know an "authentic" Cubano when I taste one. While living in Florida, I would oftentimes visit "Little Havana" for a Cubano y cafe con leche. I have also had similar Cubano sandwiches in only two restaurants in Chicago. There are very few restaurants that know how to make one. They can imitate it all they want, but it misses the mark in most cases. To be honest, the sandwich here was just "OK." You can definitely find better places in the heart of the city to experience a delectable Cubano. BTW, the prices are very reasonable and for this alone I will give it four stars. I love the fact that they have spices from different countries (central and south America) so this gets five stars. Would I come back here for the food? No.  Would I come back here for the spices? Yes. Would I return for their unique items? Yes. However, I wouldn't make a special trip here for their hot food items.

1.description: I love their restaurant! They have plates from all over Latin America: from Cuba to Mexico. I had the flautas and were tasty and my husband has the milanesa (breaded steak). Both were great! The prices are also very affordable. Please note that this place is nothing fancy, so if you are looking for a better ambiance, I would suggests ordering takeout.

55.description: We live in Rogers Park and never would have known there was a restaurant in this place. La Unica was recommended by a hispanic neighbor who goes for the food and for some grocery items. We go here for the Cuban sandwich, haven't tried anything else yet, but plan to. They have 3 great salsas on the table. My favorite is the creamy green one. Simply delicious, never any fatty pieces on the meat. Service is excellent and friendly. The Cuban coffee is awesome.

9.description: I was hoping to be a little more impressed. I stuck with getting a couple Cubans and some flan. Good meat on the Cubans but not enough mustard or pickles...a bit dry. Flan is good, again not blown away.

26.description: This place can do NO wrong.  Everything here is so delicious. My boyfriend lives in the neighborhood, so I find myself slowing going through the menu, I've never eaten anything that I did not like and they are so accommodating when I want to substitute rice for salad.  The chicken fajitas with tostones are great as are the oxtails.  My boyfriend always get the enchiladas and he loves them. We've also gotten the cod and loved it. I LOVE LOVE LOVE this place.

25.description: I kinda love this place.  It's nothing fancy.  I don't think it's cuban, I think maybe columbian?  Either way, it's so inexpensive, and the portions are gigantic.  They are so nice.  My five-year old daughter loves going to La Unica, and always orders the flan.  This place is a staple.

12.description: Food is probably good, but I didn't receive it on time.  I ordered through Groupon and everything seemed ok.  But the delivery got messed up (they had the wrong apartment apartment number).  At anyrate, the food didn't get delivered.  Groupon told me to call the restaurant directly, I did, and they told me that they will deliver the food if I paid for the delivery fee (again), which was now higher than what Groupon had on its page.  No apologies.  But I did pay the fee on top of what I already paid the first time around.  I really wanted to give them a chance because I wanted to taste their food.  Fifteen minutes passed, the delivery guy called  me to confirm the delivery.  He did say he was at the building but got turned away (our doorman said nobody came).  I gave him the address again and also talked to our doorman to send him directly to my apartment.  It's been awhile.  I still haven't got my food.Update: I finally got the food I ordered after I hit the submit button.  It was good (I ordered the steak),  tender and nicely spiced and had good acidity in the marinade.  The chicken soup was excellent and spicy.  There was a lot of food actually, so I am happy.  It was unfortunate that there was a mix up and I had to pay extra for the delivery.   But will I order again or go to the physical restaurant?  I probably will.

59.description: After living in Rogers Park for over 3 years, I am disappointed that I didn't hear of La Unica sooner. I had seen an article in the Red Eye months ago and decided to check it out. Not only did I think the chicken flautas were amazing, but so did my Cubana friend.If you want avocado added to anything you have to buy it from the convenience section first and then bring it to the cook. My friend thought this was a little weird, but I thought it was great! You actually get to see how fresh the ingredients are!Can't wait to go back and try a more traditional Cuban dish.

21.description: This place rocks! Everything i've had her is amazing. The cuban food her is authentic home cooking but what really blew my mind is that they sell menudo Mexican stile and its perhaps the best i've ever had.

17.description: I don't know what to tell you but... I like this place.I happened upon this restaurant looking for something different to eat late in the evening.  My initial experience was not good but I cannot blame the La Unica's team because I ordered through an outside agency and was disappointed when I didn't get my order.  After waiting around for over an hour, because I got caught up doing other things and was not watching the clock, I went back on line to find that my order was cancelled.  The bad thing was that I did not get a call or text letting me know and by then I was starving and the restaurant was closed.A few days and a couple of restaurants later I found myself looking at their menu again and thought let's try this again. It was earlier in the evening so I thought it would be okay.  Well this time i received my order and I was happy with all but the steak sandwich, it appeared to be over cooked or I was just expecting something different.  Now I am no novice to latin food so I did get to enjoy a couple of empanadas (Cuban & Colombian),  I also had the opportunity to try something else that I had never had, a breaded stuffed potato, not sure if this is a latin dish because I had never had one.  My lady friend informed me that her mother prepares these for her all the time, can't wait for Dona' to make me one for me to try.Now La Unica redeemed itself on my last and most recent visit as I walked into the restaurant to order and not sure what I wanted other than the stuffed potato.  Now here is where it get good.  I was ordering from the printed menu, but as I was looking at their board I noticed a couple of things that didn't make the print and one item was one of my favorite dishes... Bacalao dinner with yuca con mojo, black beans & rice.  Enjoyed this meal and had enough left for leftovers.

10.description: The ox-tail here is great and the portions are big! This dish also included sweet baked plantains, rice, and black beans.  Also included was a spicy green sauce, that was awesome sauce! Hahaa! I recommend this meal to anyone that loves Latin American food!I also got the Colombian empanada, which was alright, I prefer the Argentinian and Cuban empanadas. Also got the bread pudding, which was the most unusual bread pudding I've ever had. But it was very good! It was made with coconut and I think some type of sugar or honey native to Colombia, not sure! But I liked it, and I also recommend this if you are looking for a great dessert to try.Overall, solid Latin American food, and I will order again. I got the food delivered, and it was quick.

5.description: Although the cuisine options were overwhelming (pick by country, then by specials), and confusing (thank goodness for those high school Spanish classes, because very little was in English), AND the service and dining environment was a little too Twighlight Zone for my tastes (What's with all the staring?!) , the butter chicken and plantains were amazing, and there was more than enough for next-door leftovers.

3.description: I asked the staff what they liked and they recommended the La Unica special. It was definitely not a wrong choice. The dish has white rice, beans, steak and onions and fried chicken. The skin of the fried chicken was very crispy and tasted great, while the steak was tender despite being well-done. I also ordered chicken soup, but this was not on par with the La Unica special. It was seasoned well, but I think it needs more chicken flavor.

35.description: Wow. Just wow, this food is amazing! I ordered the super plate with steak, onions, sausage, plantains and rice. The serving was HUGE. It came with a nicely sized serving of black beans too. The steak was tender and very flavorful as well as the sausage. My friend ordered the oxtail dinner and it was the most tender oxtail we've ever tasted. We also tried the empanadas which were amazing. Absolutely excellent food. We will definitely be ordering again soon!

19.description: Great food!  I had the bistec y cebolla con arroz y frijoles negros y maduras.  I'll be back!

28.description: Never fails with this spot! Delicious food no matter the time or day. Super friendly quick. The food is amazing and mouth watering. they accommodate me and deliver us our favorite soda jupiña!!!!!! Best place ever!!!

45.description: Got delivery today. The Cuban sandwich was ok, I've had better, but the ox tails were absolutely amazing!. We could not make it better ourselves. Mom loved it. I mean, she REALLY loved it. We got quite a bit for the price. I've gotten her hooked on plantains in her old age, so it was win-win for her.We will certainly be ordering from here again, in fact, we were talking about ordering the next time my brother comes by for dinner.

33.description: I split a dish with another person, and the yuca con mojo and arroz congri were amazing. Everything is so affordable. You can get a meal for 2 people (share one of the specials) for 6.99. Coffee is good too.

43.description: Really wanted to like this food but it didn't agree with me. First and last time having ox tail.

2.description: La unica has been around for a long time and I hope they never go out of business.  I love their chuletas, pernil, lomo salteado, and of course the congri.  They serve a variety of plates from all over the Caribbean, central and South America. Would recommend any time..

18.description: I have to say that this is, by far my favorite Cuban food on the North Side of Chicago, that's right I said it!  I love the flavors of the ropa vieja, the empanadas, the croquettas, the Cuban sandwich, yucca, plantains.. I can go on but you can see I love everything about this place.The place is simple, set up like the Cuban cafeterias in Miami, nothing fancy, great service and great food, that's all I really need!  And when you do go here, make sure you order a cafe con leche, I am not sure what they put in it but it is not to be missed!

41.description: Everything I've tried from here (I usually get a cuban sandwich and a colombian empanada) has been *fantastic*, and I would literally *bathe* in their chimichurri sauce if I could -- it's that delicious.  The yellow rice isn't my favorite, but the plantains are to die for, and you know the empanadas are freshly fried because they often melt the container they're delivered in.  I can't wait to try the oxtail!They're cheap, fast, courteous, and most importantly, delicious.  AND they have a good delivery radius, too.

52.description: I love this place, if only for their fully-stocked aisles and their congri (Cuban rice and black beans). I like their flan, too, but the rice is just amazing. They even carry Peruvian spices in this store. Kenny O. and I were searching all over Chicago for the Peruvian aji amarillo, and we found it at the Peruvian Corner Market, but La Unica has it too, and their aisles are actually fully stocked. It's not dinky like the Peruvian Corner Market, so that's even better. We actually came here for the flan, after watching Steve Dolinsky's youtube video review on this place. But the first time we came here, my boyfriend was hungry, and I was just recovering from a stomach virus and so I wasn't in the mood for food. He ordered a sandwich, and it looked really tasty. The second time we came here, he came for the flan, and me still feeling weak, didn't want to risk trying it just yet, so I ordered a small box of the congri, which seemed safe to me. OMG, the rice is delicious! I immediately asked Kenny if he can learn how to make it so that he can make it for me at home. Haha. I had a small bite of the flan, and that was delicious as well, but I'm not a fan of sweets, so I'm a bigger fan of the rice and beans. There's only so many places that does rice right--this place is one of them. I can't wait to come back to try their other more savory dishes.

50.description: This is medium sized latino/hispanic grocery store, you will find items mostly from  Central America and a few from South America, specially Colombia. They offer a good service, although their prices are not very competitive. The visit is worth it, you won't be disappointed.

4.description: I am not one to be put off by the lack of décor of a place as long as the food is good and customer service backs it up, I will eat out of a shoe box. While LA UNICA certainly has a lot of diverse Latin American dishes, I have to say not all of them are great. For example, some of the people in my group ordered the jibarito  ( a Puerto Rican Plantain sandwich) (and gave me a tiny bit to sample) my thoughts?it was just not very flavorful..no sight of the garlic and the meat was totally unseasoned, guess I will go to my reg. place on Fullerton Ave for my jibarito fix. However, the Peruvian dish I ordered, Ceviche de Pollo was quite tasty. So I guess some of the dishes are just hit or misses. They do seem to have a lot of orders for delivery and take-out so clearly they have established themselves within the community and must be doing something right. I was slightly disappointed at the customer service as they seemed to be overly preoccupied (went around 6 pm on a weekday) and not really acknowledging our needs (napkins, utensils, to-go containers when we were done).We had to hound them for these things and it was hard to get their attention because there were not alot of them (2) and both seemed busy with the to-go orders. I have mixed reviews about this place and your experience will probably depend on what time of the day you go. The only thing that I will mention is that their coffee is STRONG..which is exactly what I needed..although they served it in a small styrophone cup with no lid...(not good if you are accident prone like me) the coffee certainly had that wake you up jolt I was looking for.  I would give this place another chance just because it does seem like they have some solid dishes that they specialize in but will not go with necessarily super high expectations.

6.description: Gritty, real, authentic, hidden, affordable.If you can't handle any of those, just don't come.

22.description: The food here is incredible... I had the pollo frito here...all I have to say is WOW

15.description: My favorite Hispanic place in Chicago so far, especially considering Caribbean dishes. Very tasty! I have been missing Cuban food since relocating from Miami, this place hit the spot.

57.description: For weeks I had really been feenin' for some Cuban oxtail stew from my fave hometown Cuban restaurant, Versailles (West Los Angeles). Then a friend of mine texted me about this great pan-Latin restaurant she had gone to near her apartment.  She mentioned that it was inside of a grocery, which may be off-putting to some, but intriguing to me. (Some of the best food comes from the most random places.) So I did a quick yelp search and found that they serve Cuban food, so it was game on from there--had to get there that night or else.My friend and I hightailed it to La Unica from Boystown, arriving literally 15 minutes before closing.  I was glad to find that they have a parking lot, which you never find on the north side. We made a bee line towards the restaurant, and the server was nice enough to take our order, even though they were clearly cleaning up for the night. We were presented with an expansive pan-Latin menu including Mexican, Colombian, and Cuban (score!!!) dishes, all listed in Spanish.  Good thing I had yelped the menu ahead of time, otherwise I would have had to ask my friend to translate. I ordered to oxtails of course, and substituted the yuca with the fried plantains. The meal came with steamed rice and black beans. The whole meal was only $8.95 + tax.  The oxtail stew at my LA restaurant is upwards of 13 bucks (well worth it, but seriously?!?!), so I knew I was on to something.  My friend ordered the chicken enchiladas verdes. Unfortunately, the credit card machine wasn't working, so we ordered at the restaurant counter but had to pay at the store counter (no big deal).We waited about 10 minutes, and the server brought our food out. Man oh man! What a feast. The plate was overflowing with savory goodness. I had four oxtails, half a plate of rice, a bowl of black beans, and about 4 slices of fried plantains.  The oxtails had a good meat-to-fat ratio, fall off the bone tender.  The sauce/gravy was incredibly flavorful, and was perfectly sopped up by my white rice. The black beans were equally delicious.  The plantains did leave something to desired--not the sticky, caramelized morsels I'm used to (they weren't as ripe as they could be), but edible.  I gobbled up the whole plate, like a true glutton, and had a great night's sleep because of it.I've been back to La Unica once for the oxtails since then, and look forward to introducing others to this hidden gem.

20.description: I have gone here with my family since I was a kid, my family is Cuban and let me tell you this is some real Cuban cooking. It has never once let me down. The atmosphere is pretty quiet with some Spanish soaps in the background normally. I almost always get something new and it's all great!! Their shopping mart is also great to pick up something for the next day.

36.description: I love this place!!! Yucca con mojo, yes please! Arroz congri yes please! I have been coming here since the 90s. I honestly recommend everyone to try this place out. You won't regret it!

14.description: This place can do NO wrong.  Everything here is so delicious. My boyfriend lives in the neighborhood, so I find myself slowing going through the menu, I've never eaten anything that I did not like and they are so accommodating when I want to substitute rice for salad.  The chicken fajitas with tostones are great as are the oxtails.  My boyfriend always get the enchiladas and he loves them. We've also gotten the cod and loved it. I LOVE LOVE LOVE this place.

28.description: This is a go to spot for delish food when I'm in A-villle. Everything I have had has been spot on. And the little shop is irresistible...I never need any of those things but yet always find a few things I *have* to have. If you are in the area, stop in you won't be disappointed

1.description: Made an account just for this. There is ONE waiter for the whole place. Poor guy.The panini I ordered was disgustingly salty, with clearly frozen ingredients.My child's french toast order came out long after mine did, it was mushy and undercooked. I looked back into the kitchen just to see a dark greasy grill  and a couple of microwaves.I have a microwave at home. And I can cook better with it. No thanks Kopi.

39.description: Fool me once, shame on you.Fool me twice, shame on me.Fool me three times . . . I've been to Kopi several times over the past year (2013-2014) without updating my review. Until now. Each time I've visited Kopi, the quality of food and service have been hit-or-miss. I've been going to Kopi for 20 years, so I was willing to overlook a few mediocre experiences. After years and years of enjoying Kopi's food, service, and atmosphere, I have a history with this business. It's like an old friend. Sometimes that friend is a little moody, but you forgive her and continue with the friendship. There comes a time, though, when that friend abuses the relationship so much, you have to say good-bye forever. That time has come for me and Kopi.The atmosphere is still good. When I went in for breakfast recently, I noticed that some updating had been done, but it still held the same artsy vibe it always had. I sat down and was quickly given menus and waters for two, since I told the waiter I was waiting for a friend. When the friend arrived, she and the waiter exchanged a friendly hug and familiar greetings. Clearly, she'd been going to Kopi even more than I had, over the years.Despite that friendly greeting, once we ordered and received the food, the waiter disappeared. Not in a Halloween-type way, like vanished into a puff of smoke. No, he hung around the bar area, he chatted with another employee, he went into the back for some mysterious purpose. He never checked with us on our food, never refilled coffee or tea, just never did much waiter service at all. There were only three other tables occupied while we were there. It's not like he was so busy.Then there's the food. I ordered a tofu scramble with vegetables for $6.95. I got a tiny soup cup -- you know the kind, what you get when you order a cup of soup in a restaurant instead of a bowl? -- of entrée, and a piece of French bread. That's it. That wasn't even appetizer size. I also ordered the vegetarian sausage. For $3.00, I got three over-cooked pieces of something, each of which was the size of a silver dollar. For $3.00. There were so hard, the tines of my fork actually bent trying to pick one up. I tried eating it just by putting it in my mouth. Burned. Dry. That was $10.00 worth of breakfast.My friend ordered a bagel and asked for extra cream cheese. She did get her bagel, and she did get the cream cheese. The waiter gave her two packets, charging her $.75 for each. She didn't know about the charge until we looked at the check.I was still hungry at the end of breakfast. I saw a treat in the counter, a peanut butter/chocolate muffin. That was $5.50. I scarfed it down on the walk to the car, because I was still so hungry. With tip, I ended up paying $20.00 for a poorly-cooked, tiny portion breakfast. $20.00!!  I am not kidding or exaggerating when I tell you, the tofu scramble and sausage were not enough to feed your 3-year-old. You get a small amount of mediocre food for high prices.No more second chances, Kopi. It took a year of bad experiences, but now, after this final visit, I'm done. From now on, it's M. Henry or Taste of Heaven. I get better more and better food, and better service, for less money.

9.description: This is literally the first coffee shop I went to in Chicago, 20+ years ago, and it has absolutely held up.Now that I live in the neighborhood, it's my go-to spot for vegetarian comfort food.  It actually took me a number of years before I noticed that they were veg.Favorite items:* Salmon Tartine Sandwich* Carrot Cake* Mexican Hot Chocolate Latte

29.description: I had there croissant which was delicious!! I like this place but one time I had a lox bagel which was 12.95 and that's to pricey for a damn bagel... But it's a nice little place
