3.description: Very nice toy store. Great mix of higher end brands (Haba, Plan Toys, etc) and the classic Fisher Price stuff. Good gift options at different price points. The staff were super helpful and willing to answer questions and suggest gifts. There is a lot packed into this store! If you are looking for kids books for 5 and under I'd suggest going to Women and Children First (feminist book store a bit south on Clark) instead though.

1.description: I live right by timeless toys so that's usually my go to toy store for unique children's gifts but yesterday, I was looking for something very specific and timeless did not have it but toys etc did. They were very friendly over the phone and said they'd have it all gift wrapped and ready to go for me before you getting in the store.That is exactly how it went down! I walked in there with my four kids and the gift was gift wrapped and bagged and ready to go they were very very very friendly! My baby was wailing quite a bit because he wanted to get out of the stroller so the sales associate started to play guitar and sing softly which calmed my baby down!I loved the customer service so much that it makes me want to support this local businesses and make a point to drive the extra mile to this store because they went above and beyond :)Thanks toys etc.

2.description: OMG. I parked in front of this place on my way to Women & Children Bookstore. The toys in the window enticed me to venture inside.. $150 later.. I found some of the most unique gifts for people in my life. As a former art teacher.. I was so thrilled to find the most awesome 6 sided contemporary & fine art puzzles not even seen at any art museum!!! LOVE this store!!!!

9.description: What an awesome neighborhood toy store. Toys et Cetera has such a variety of toys for all ages that it was hard for me to decide what to buy as a gift for a toddler! Everything seemed great. The selection is not lacking at all. In addition to newer toys they also carry some great classics. What truly makes this store awesome though is the staff. They are so helpful, not pushy, and seem to enjoy working there...but why wouldn't they ? Its a toy store!  Last but not least, gift wrapping is free. Good times.

10.description: Such a cute, independent shop for last-minute gifts and collectibles. My friend went crazy over the lego's and will be bringing her nephew in here when she wants to take him shopping.

4.description: I like shopping local, and when it came time for another nephew's bday...I thought, Toys et Cetera would at least be my first stop before Target for another Lego set.  We got an air hockey table ($30), which the 7 year old loved!  Their stuff is more pricey than what you're going to find at Target or Toys R us, but they have optional gift wrap and really know their toys.  The staff is friendly, and you can find a bigger selection of younger kids toys, but they do carry some science games, some Egyptian chess laser game, and things like that.  You might not be able to afford all of your Christmas shopping here, say, but it's a great place when you have some dough and want to get a nice gift.

6.description: I love independent toy stores. This place has a great selection of toys and games that go beyond your usual plastic crap from the big stores. There's a nice selection of puzzles that Lenny jr is now into. Lots of Melissa and Doug stuff, craft kits, train set and much more. The staff is really nice. Prices are on par with other independent toy stores.

0.description: Awesome store! My husband and I shopped at the Hyde Park location often when we lived there. We went into this store the other day to look at games and buy a kite. The salesperson was very friendly and informative. He knew about a lot of the games. As we were checking out, my husband mentioned we were "poor students" and they took a couple dollars off of our total :)

5.description: Once again this store provided that last minute gift we needed and with excellent advice and the free wrapping took them less than a minute.  It would have taken me 30 minutes and would never have looked as good as theirs did.This store carries a more unique variety of toys and games for various ages.  If you are looking for the run of the mill Toys R Us stuff you will not find it here.The staff is very helpful and equally friendly and don't seem to midn the screaming munchkins roaming their store.

13.description: Fantastic independent toy store in the heart of Andersonville. I had to stop myself from running around the store to explore all the goodies and I'm three decades old...I know that any kid younger than me would have an equally good time.I bought a gift for my 3 year old nephew that helps to inspire some creative storytelling but it was a tough decision with all the beautiful toys and gifts. On top of everything there was free gift wrap. Love it!

11.description: Adults in this store will find themselves playing as much as the children with the hands-on educational and developmental toys on hand. The store carrys a lot of unique specialty items that you may not find a big box retailer or toy store. We will warn you, the store is small, cramped and can get busy - but its all worth it to find that perfect unique gift for the little one on your lists.

8.description: This place is a true gem. I love the variety of toys here, a great selection for various ages. Perfect place to shop for gifts for the little ones. But the thing that stands out the most is the outstanding customer service. I had a toy that I purchased 9 months ago stop working and was able to go in and exchange for a brand new one. There's also a music time Tues at 11:30 and again at 4 - the children could play along with the instruments while the musician (store employee) play. Will definitely be supporting this business again and again.

14.description: This place is small, but stocked full of good quality items. My daughter and I love to pop in and see the new selections. The people that work here really make all the difference. They are helpful and super sweet with the children. This store also has a frequent buyer program, which comes in handy with a child who makes frequent trips.

7.description: When I need a toy for "the Viking" (Sorry, inside thing with Mama K) this is always where I go. One because I don't really know a lot of kids to buy toys for. Two because it's a small business in my hood. And third because I know that they have loud obnoxious toys to drive his parents nuts with. Sorry, I'm evil that way (evil laugh begins here). But seriously, they have anything you can think of when you're not going for major labels. Toys for all ages and a ton of smart toys for kids to learn. The staff is always nice and helpful which I don't know how they do it. There is always kids running around when I'm there. Prices aren't so bad here and they do free gift wrapping. I can't wait till "the Viking" needs some drums (evil laugh ends here)!!Shop local!!!

12.description: So for my birthday dinner I had so many restaurants to choose from and I picked the Edgewater Beach Cafe, even though I had never been there. The reviews looked promising and I couldn't resist the appeal of it being located inside the "pink highrise"  on LSD (some think it's tacky, I think it's quite charming).On our way there I was having serious second thoughts. We walked in (on a Saturday night at 7:30) to see the place maybe 1/3 full. We were the youngest ones by about 30 years but I was expecting this. Even though the guy on the phone said jeans were acceptable, I'm glad we were a little dressed up.The decor, which was recently re-done, was cozy-modern-classic. An older man, possibly a resident, was playing the piano. Our waiter was friendly and inquired how we had heard about EBC (we must have looked out of place!). The menu isn't large but includes red meat, chicken, fish & duck. We ordered the specials--NY Strip and Chilean sea bass. Both were delicious and came with soup or salad/ vegetable/ twice baked potato or rice pilaf. Went great with the bottle of wine we ordered. When I asked to see the desert menu, they didn't have one but the waiter said his cousin had just made tiramisu, which we got and was also fantastic. Total bill came to $90.We perused the old photographs in the hall and I learned that the building once had a private beach. The north part of LSD, is relatively new and was built on a landfill! Check out my pictures.If you're looking for a good meal away from the hustle & bustle, I strongly recommend EBC. I'm trying to start a revolution of young "whippersnappers" frequenting this great restaurant;)

7.description: Inexplicably and inexcusably it took us over 9 years to try this place even though we live no more than 100 yards away.   A couple weeks ago we finally had circumstances align for what we hoped would be perfect trial conditions : a snowy Friday night when we could make the short walk over here, grab a window table inside this allegedly quaint neighborhood place and have a nice meal while enjoying the picturesque wintry scene outside.  Maybe we had built up our expectations too much, but the actual experience left us feeling only okay.  First, and through no fault of the restaurant, the view of the snowstorm through their windows wasn't that great.  Streetlight glare plus exterior building light glare just kind of washed it all out.  So much for that. Focusing on the food, service and atmosphere, then, here's my take:Atmosphere was pretty sleepy.  This wasn't one of the live performance nights, so it was just the three or four quiet tables eating in a mostly quiet room.  Service was pretty helpful.  One guy seemed to be running the whole show, waiting on the tables and handling the bar orders.  He was friendly.Food was good.  The menu is limited and the prices aren't inexpensive, so the food quality is a make or break element here.  My wife enjoyed her shrimp cachonette and tournedos of beef.  My onion soup gratinee and filet mignon were tasty too.Bottom line, though, is if I'm going to spend $130 for dinner in Edgewater, I'm going to head over to Francesca's.  Twice.  I'm glad I tried EBC, but it's hard to justify the premium prices unless you really, really value a dark, extremely quiet atmosphere.

19.description: This is an odd little place. Overall, the food has some strengths and some flaws and the ambiance is really perplexing...Food: Some items were outstanding. The French Onion Soup was delicate, savory, and rich without a being overwhelmed by burned cheese; exactly how it should be. A+ for that. The asparagus soup was also quite good: yes the asparagus is soft but it's soup people, don't you know how to make soup (i.e. cooking everything together for a very long time so blend the flavors, so of course everything will be soft)? The house salad was fresh but otherwise unspectacular. For the entrees, the first thing they need to work on is presentation, it's just sloppy. I felt like I just got three big spoonfuls of food on my plate. Also, just throwing some random sprigs flat leaf parsley on the plate, why? Garnish should be aesthetically appealing AND serve a culinary purpose. I'm not going to eat raw parsley at a French restaurant. The rice and potatoes are quite good, and the jasmine is a well executed nod to the Asian roots of the owner (who is truly very nice). Though the carrots? They almost ruin the whole plate: just boiled carrot sticks. It saddens me when sides are neglected... The center of the "plat principaux" was ok. My beef was cooked well and the sauce was good. However, the salmon my companion had was underwhelming: indeed it's just a regular salmon filet with lemon she could have made at home. The lemon cheesecake dessert was nice in part. The filling was outstanding: it didn't have that "institutional cheese cake taste" that so many have, and it was very delicate and subtle. The almond graham cracker crust was not quite adequate: the almonds were not ground quite enough, thus giving the crust an oddly lumpy/granular texture. And again, the presentation was just sloppy, just a slice of cake with a messy dollop of whipped cream that was slightly liquidy and was immediately pushed off to the side. Serivce: Nice but slow. They had one server for the whole place. The owner helped out every now and then (again, who is very nice). One final note, it's obvious that this is a family run place (I think the wife of the owner actually does the cooking) and for that they get kudos. French food is not something you can ordinarily just pull out of your hat and do well. So while the homeyness of the food can be charming, the lack of sophistication is also readily apparent, i.e. from the presentations to not paying attention to every side with scrutinizing detail. And when I'm paying $90+ for two people, I want some more sophistication...

1.description: Our little secret restaurant for celebrating special moments. The brunch is excellent, always a hit with visiting family; and the dinners are carefully prepared. The presentation is right for the price. Slow paced, plan to relax and take your time.

2.description: This place is a neighborhood treasure.  It is a bit upscale and old-fashioned.  The food quality is great.

9.description: I've seen some reviewers exclaiming the EBC as perplexing and I can't really argue with that.  The place is sort of camp in a non ghey sort of way and I think the best way to describe the atmosphere is (insert Asian restaurant of your choice, ie Thai, Chinese, Korean...) trying to do fancy or upscale...leave that to the Japanese as they can pull off stylish and sophisticated but EBC, however, just lands on its face.  It's a place that you'd expect circa your GP's of yesteryear and the clientele, few as they were, and aptly of that demographic, just added to the enigma that is the EBC.BUT that is not to say it's a bad thing.  In fact, I found it to be part of its charm.  Add in the owner/operators who are so genuinely nice, accommodating and informed, it's hard to say a bad thing about the place.Apart from the atmosphere, the food was decent, it won't blow you away obvi but it's decent and price wise right in line.  I had the shrimp entree turned into the app dish that was on the lunch menu (see accommodating) and she had the salmon which was well prepared.  Can't say i'd return on the surface but you almost want to bc the ppl who run the place are so genuine and nice and make you want to support them.

6.description: Cardiac Rehabbers Holiday Party is going wonderfully!This is a lovely place for dinner.On December 9 there was live entertainment.A good time was had by all.The food was delicious, the atmosphere delightful, the service very good.I recommend this place.

18.description: Just like high school students at a fancy restaurant the first time, we felt sophisticated.My friend and I try new places once a month and we decided to splurge a little this time.   My friend (dressed in a nice sweater and slacks) and myself in a shirt, tie, slacks combo arrived to the underground parking lot for the restaurant. (3 dollars to park, but remember to get the ticket validated at the Cafe.  The security guy gave us a bit of huff LOL).The atmosphere was warm and inviting.  It was low lighting with a piano player gently tickling the ivories in the background.We were seated on time for our Saturday 7pm reservations and promptly served by our waiter Brandon.  He was very good at telling the specials and everything we needed to know (and not to hard on the eyes either.)  We started by ordering a bottle of the Grenache.  He brought the bottle over and this is when I started feeling like a high school student.  My friend and I were talking when he brought us the bottle for me to look over.  I glanced at it and said "Yes, that's the one."  He then gave me the cork (I sniffed) and then poured me a small amount (I tasted.)  I felt so sophisticated for a 32yo male who is not used to doing this. Haha!I then (like a good boy) ordered for myself and my female friend.  We started with the Escargot (me) and the Shrimp Cachonette.  They did me proud with the escargot.  I am a fan and still am to this day due to their take on them.  My friend said the shrimp was excellent, but I could not tell you for I am allergic.  She ordered an appetizer I couldn't try.  I say it's bad form, but what can you do.  :)Then came my house salad (I chose Honey Mustard dressing) and she chose the Cream of Asparagus soup.  Our waiter said he doesnt care for that kind of soup usually but that this was an exception.  He was right. The soup was excellent.  (Not as good as my mom's, but then again that is one of her specialties.)We then had our entrees.  I ordered the Roast Duck in the Apple Brandy Sauce, which came with green beans and rice.  Everything about this dish was awesome.  I sopped up every last bit of the sauce after the duck was finished.    She ordered the Filet Mignon.  I am not allergic to this so I got to try it.  it was cooked to perfection.  She had the baked potato and green beans with that.  She didn't like the green beans.  It was not because of the taste (they were cooked perfectly) but she doesn't like how they squeak against the teeth.  She is an odd duck.Our bottle of wine was finished.  We were feeling good.    We were then asked about desserts.  We were like, why not?  We both agreed that the two best sounding ones were the chocolate cake and the pecan pie.  So we decided to order one of each.  GOOD CALL!  The pecan pie was perfect and the gooey part was not to sweet, nor chewy.  The chocolate cake that looked heavy like a poundcake was anything but.  It was airy and delicious and I got to have the strawberry which came with it.  She didn't want it, I thought her insane.  We were having coffee alongside.  Our waiter Brandon, remember the one that was attentive and easy on the eyes, was only around the proper amount of time.  He did his job very well.  The food was brought to us at the proper intervals, and we were quite happy with the whole package.Total for whole evening was 115.00 for the two of us, excluding the tip.  Since our waiter was attentive and handsome he was compensated nicely.So seeing as my friend and I rarely get to splurge like this, that is why we felt like high school students.  We were laughing and enjoying the change of pace we usually go for.Then we went home and changed into street clothes to go drinking at the local gay bar.  Woohoo!

10.description: I don't understand how the other ratings for this restaurant are so high?!?!The service was terribly slow.We were told the place is family owned. They also work there, The  mom is in the kitchen and the father and son are doing everything else. If you are charging $29 for a meal and it takes an hour to receive it, it should've outstanding. It's not. Get a cousin to come in and help...that's not our problem. It should not take 1/2 an hour to get water and bread and another 10 more minutes to place your entree order. The portions were small and the food wasn't  great. The service was equally slow...everyone seemed to be waiting on something for a while. The beef tenderloin was not cooked well and was much colder in temperature than the potatoes. Very disappointed. Been there done that.

13.description: I give this place 4 stars for the food but 2 for the ambiance.The duck breast with apple brandy sauce was absolutely delicious. I love myself some duck, since you don't see it too often on American menus. It came with soup, but I was pretty disappointed when they brought out some Vietnamese pho broth. I know the owners are Asian, but that kind of clashed with the heavy French fare I was about to have, and was not the kind of soup I had in mind.As for the ambiance, it was pretty empty on a Friday night, and the only other table was a group my grandparents' age (not counting the "complimentary magician" sitting by himself, I kid you not.) There was a man playing piano live, which is why we went, so that did not disappoint. But overall the strangely dead environment made me feel like I should not be paying as much for my meal.

16.description: If I could give this place six stars I would.  We went on a Friday night around 6:30pm and walked into a dim restaurant of about 25% occupancy.  We ordered the escargot, the shrimp with goat cheese, the filet steak and the duck.  The food was delicious!!   The service was great and I even got a free glass of wine!Unfortunately, we were too full for dessert, but were already talking about the next time we go.  We both walked out of there with big grins on our faces.  Parking is $3 in the heated garage below.

17.description: I love this place.  Food is good and good value.  Very quiet.  I went a week or so ago and we were they only people there when we arrived for a 730p dinner.  The menu could have a few more options - especially if you just want something small/ simple.    But everything was done to perfection.   A great neighborhood find and a place that needs to get the word out.Check it out.

15.description: I have a love/hate relationship with surprises. Sometimes, they are TOTALLY sucky. Like, a boyfriend breaking up with you out of nowhere, a fellow motorist taking off your rear bumper, a family member dying suddenly...okay, you get the point. But sometimes surprises can be lovely. Edgewater Beach Cafe was just the kind of surprise a girl wants. Ever wonder what that HUGE pink stucco building on the north end of LSD is? It's the historic Edgewater Beach Apartments building, built at the end of the 1920's as a part of the Edgewater Beach Hotel complex. Well, now you know, and so do I. For Valentine's Day, my thoughtful gentleman-friend brought me to the Edgewater Beach Apartments, through the indoor heated garage (validated parking is only $3), past the doorman, through the lobby, down to the arcade, and through the door of the Edgewater Beach Cafe. And just like the EBA, the EBA Cafe brings you back to old Chicago.The atmosphere is lovely. When we walked in, there was a man playing jazz tunes at a piano--now that's old school--for the patrons at their white tablecloths sitting in dark wood chairs. The only thing I didn't appreciate about the atmosphere was that they had these beautiful heavy velvet drapes at the large windows that were street level, and every once in a while, the bus would drive by. For a place so intimate, it seemed weird to NOT close the rest of the world out.Being Valentine's Day, we were offered a 3-course pre-fixe menu. For mains, our options were fliet mignon with garlic butter, duck breast, or Chilean sea bass. We both went with the filet mignon--mmm, my steak was juicy, medium-rare, buttery, savory goodness. Unfortunately, my man ordered the exact same thing, and his was not cooked nearly as rare as it should have been. A small shame.Our server was the only one on that night--yes, it's a small restaurant, but that kind of shocked me--and although he had like 10 other tables, he always seemed to check in at the right times. Way to go, man. Okay, and this is going to sound snobby, but I think EBA Cafe would seem even more upscale if the waiter presentation sounded more sophisticated and less bouncy. Our waiter was really excited to tell us the menu, but the atmosphere of the place is far more reserved than he was.Overall, our evening was beautifully low-key. It helps to have dinner in a place without hype or pretension and be served great food all the while sitting across from the love of your life. I'll take this kind of surprise anytime.

0.description: One of my own and our family's favorite and special dining spots for delicious offerings, intimate setting and gracious service. My favorites are the whitefish and the  tournadoes of beef. The deserts are lush!  Always feel so welcomed here.

5.description: Coming here is like stepping back into another era! From its historic location - the arcade of the Edgewater Beach "pink" building - to the comfortable atmosphere of the dining room, you are free to imagine yourself far away from Sheridan and Bryn Mawr.  I wrestled with writing a glowing review for fear that too many will discover this gem and intrude on this oasis of vintage hospitality. With the encouragement of recent dining companions and after a second visit, I am prepared to get out the word: want great French food and warm hospitality, try EBC!  Serving dinner only Tuesdays- Saturdays and brunch only on Sundays, the Dao family are gracious hosts and immediately make you feel like you're dining in their home.  From our first visit in January to our latest on Feb. 15, we were impressed by the consistency and careful attention to the menu's entrees.   The 9 entrees and 6 starters on the menu are supplemented by daily specials.  My friends and I enjoyed a generous and perfectly pan-seared portion of Tournedos of Beef ($29) served with a Burgundy reduction with green peppercorns, in addition to the broiled sole (special) and grilled pork chops ($17). On the second visit, two of us tried the daily special - a succulent rack of lamb from New Zealand ($29) with 4 ribs cooked to perfection. Another enjoyed his Filet Mignon which was topped with a red wine herb butter.  Their starters  - for those who need more than the included soup du jour or house salad - range from a terrific Escargot Bourguignon ($9) baked in red wine herb butter to a satisfying Onion Soup Gratinee ($6).  One of my friends, asked if they would do their Shrimp de Jonghe ($26 as entrée) as an appetizer which Mr. Dao graciously accommodated.  It was divine and made us want to order it as an entrée next time. Another visit, we shared or fought over the Shrimp Cachonette ($13) where baked jumbo shrimps were slathered with goat cheese & served on sautéed spinach.On a weekday evenings, Mr. Dao may be the sole presence as server, host, bartender, and do whatever needs to be done.  After 30 years in the business, he seems to be the type where he handles everything with a smile and with a true joy of welcoming new and old friends to his "café!"  He made a number of martinis for us, just to our liking, as well as offering a modest number of whites and reds by the glass.  His equally charming son, Quan, is usually there on weekends when a piano man enhances the scene with popular tunes.  Mrs. Dao graduated from the Cordon Bleu and while she stayed in the kitchen, was eager to meet special requests. So if you want to have a truly unique experience with traditional French favorites at a charming, family-run bistro, try Edgewater Beach Café!  While the signage on Sheridan is not easy to find and street parking is minimal, just look for the garage entrance on Sheridan south of Bryn Mawr.  Parking is a mere $3 and you don't have to step outside which this winter is a big plus!  Bon Appétit!

11.description: This is still hands-down, the best place in Chicago for escargot.They recently remodeled and now, EBC looks classier and even better than before.  A tip for parking - there's a parking garage/valet underneath the building and it only costs $3.  And they were recently featured in 190 North!Our group started off with the escargot and shrimp de jonghe which was jumbo shrimp sauteed with garlic, onions, butter and white wine.  The sauce was so amazing - we had to request another plate of their warm french bread to sop up the buttery wine sauce.  The atmosphere was cozy and the live piano playing added to the mood.  The crowd does tend to be a bit older but service is friendly and really fabulous.All dinner entrees come with either a soup or salad, choice of potatoes or rice and a side of vegetables.  Their duck is still something out of this world.  It is slightly pan seared and then, roasted - yum!  My husband devoured his whitefish which was specially prepared for that evening.  Our group also tried the NY strip steak, porkchops and Tilapia.  Overall, everyone enjoyed their meals and couldn't believe how stuffed we were afterwards.  We had also brought a cake from Buns Bakery (they're actually relatives of the owner of EBC) and they brought that out for us towards the end of our meal.I'm definitely looking forward to another treat out at the Edgewater Beach Cafe - a glass of their Cabernet and their filet mignon next time.  Or maybe even for their Sunday brunch?

8.description: Really like this place. Romantic scenery with some delicious food prepared in a very elegant styles. Great wine selection as well.The owner is very helpful with a lot of knowledge about the food and wine. Must try the escargot! Very, very good. Also, the duck is delicious.

3.description: Excellent service, small quaint atmosphere. Awesome for date night. I recommend the Escargot.. WOW :) ask for EXTRA bread to dip in that WONDERFUL sauce.  I had the Shrimp Entree and it was ahh-mazing.  They didn't have a children's menu but they made chicken fingers for my 7yr old daughter and they were delicious. Very relaxing, slow paced. 2 thumbs up. Awesome experience. Thanks so much.

14.description: The guy I'm currently seeing hit a home run with his choice of EBC for our second date- what a fantastic, intimate setting with amazing, perfectly cooked food! We popped in at about 8:00 last Friday night for dinner and we were one of only a few occupied tables. We started with the escargot- WOW. I'm not a huge seafood eater, in fact, my dad loves escargot and has, for about my 35 years of existence, been begging me to try it, with no luck. But after dipping some (surprisingly dominicks-grade white bread, the only downside to the whole meal) into the mouthwatering butter-garlic-red wine-onion bath they were swimming in, *plus* a little coaxing from my date, I had to try one. Incredible!! (Thanks babe..)I then had the most perfectly cooked, juicy salmon filet, sitting perfectly on top of a bed of cooked spinach with a side of jasmine rice and green beans. I ate almost every bite. My guy had the sea scallops which he loved, and before I knew it, he had jumped up from the table to play the piano a bit while the regular pianist took a break. *sigh*Finally, toward the end of the meal, the owner came and sat with us and bought us a glass of wine, and we had an interesting chat with him and the pianist- lovely lovely place. What a gem- no question!We'll be back, and soon...

4.description: The Edgewater Beach Cafe is the restaurant in the big pink hotel at the end of LSD on Bryn Mawr and Sheridan. The food is delicious and it's a lovely place; white tablecloths, a comfy vibe (though you would not feel out of place if you came dressed up).  The owners are lovely people (original owners for over 25 years). Zung hosts and his wife Kim is the chef (French / Indochina cuisine). Classic dishes like escargot and hollandaise from scratch - and gorgeous deserts!They have live music several nights a week - which makes it very special.A pianist Friday & Saturday nights and Third Thursday a Jazz trio or quintet with some sultry tunes with a bit of humor. Zung always makes you feel welcome, and you can always be sure to have great glass of wine, a full belly and a memorable evening Brunch is GREAT too.)I've been there for several group events/parties. They handled everything with grace and finesse. Come for the food and friendly atmosphere, stay for the music and grea wine selection.

58.description: Went to this place last week, Saturday afternoon for lunch.This place is pretty friggin' great. The food is definitely fantastically made, with low prices and large portions. I ordered the lengua huarches (as per the namesake of the restaurant) which was so big I couldn't even finish. Between two people the meal was about 15 dollars, including a cup of decent joe.The only problem I have with this place is the noise level--it's rather small, therefore very noisy when there are a lot of people--and the other patrons.While our waitress was a delight and very friendly, everyone else in the place was staring at us. Definitely awkward.

56.description: Huaraches = pronounced "wah-ra-ches" but you have to say it fast like it's all one syllable.  Got made fun of by the bf for over enunciating lol.We got the Huaraches de Tinga:  a huge homemade, thicker-than-normal tortilla with shredded pork in a chipotle sauce topped with onions, cilantro, cheese and green salsa.  I already had high expectations but it still blew me away by how good it was.  The super fresh tortilla was the star of the dish....it tasted like a mexican grandma had just spent the whole day making it just for you.  And lo and behold it was!  you can literally see the old woman behind the counter hard at work putting elbow grease into churning them out.  all of the toppings were great as well - the tinga was tender and juicy and the chipotle sauce/green salsa went perfectly with the rest of the dish.  i think they let you split toppings too so ill definitely have to ask for that next time and try some of their other meats.  My boyfriend and i split one huarache and we didnt even come close to finishing it so if you're looking for leftovers this is definitely the right dish to get.  All this along with a steak taco (super flavorful) and an horchata for around $11 (plus a nice tip for the old lady for working so goddarn hard even though we didn't eat in).  cheap, delicious and only two blocks from the house....ill definitely be back here soon !

29.description: This review is going to be simple and direct. The huaraches are home made. The tortillas are made from scratch, and the chili sauce used is motherf$%^# great. Do yourself a favor and try it out.

42.description: This is my favorite Mexican joint in the city, maybe anywhere. The homemade huaraches are just heavenly. Everything tastes fresh and healthy and isn't bogged down with a lot of unnecessary oil. I am a stickler for delicious food that's also good for my body, and I love that I can eat a massive huarache stuffed with all sorts of yummy ingredients and feel satisfied but not stuffed or food-comatose.I always get the same thing, because it just makes me so happy - the quesadillas! Made with huarache (instead of flour tortilla - this is great), meat, cheese, and I always add lettuce, tomato, mushrooms and onion. Their salsas are great, as well.The wait staff is super friendly, and on a few occasions I've seen family members and friends of the employees at their own tables, giving this location a feel-good neighborhood vibe. I do believe this place is family-owned and run, and it shows! Lots of heart goes into the making and serving of this amazing food, and I always feel comfortable and welcome there. There are 5 tables, I believe, so be prepared for a small space. Great for a date!

23.description: We are pretty serious regulars here - we stop by most weekends and get an absolute feast, usually for under $25 including tip. We can usually find a seat, but there are only 4 or 5 small tables. The house-made mesa tortillas are amazing. Favorites are the huaraches (green or red chipotle sauce - again, house made and the red is usually a bit spicier), tacos, tostadas (I think these are on a more standard tortilla - not sure if they're made in-house; but they do usually come with lettuce, sour cream and avocado which is a nice thing to mix up with) and a rajas (roasted poblano pepper - again, they roast in-house). Favorite fillings are tinga (YUM), pastor, picadillo and asada. Burritos are okay, but nothing special - go for the huraches, tacos or quesadilla if you're looking for something special.

47.description: Amazing is all I can say. Their hauraches are as authentic as you can get and they do them Mexico City style. I have also had their menudo  and it was out standing. It reminded me very much of the small stands in Mexico city that I used to go to. Also old Mexican ladies that remind me of my grandmother make the food. In my opinion this is better than a lot of the over priced high end Mexican restaurants I have been too.

8.description: Ordered steak enchiladas with the green sauce. Got my order, took it home, opened it (I should've checked it before I left). There was no sauce on the enchiladas, the steak was on top, they didn't look like enchiladas, just 3 tortillas rolled with cheese on top and burnt steak on top of the tortillas....I've never had enchiladas that look like that. Maybe thats another way of making them, but I'm highly disappointed. I prefer my meat inside my enchiladas. Also, I got no salsa on the side. I'm not happy. Will not order from here again.

31.description: This was pretty good! I happened to get the veggie options this day. I was taking a little break from meat. My man got the steak. His tasted way better. Once you go meat, I guess you can't go back to being a vegetarian. I'll try the meat one next time. Overall, though, the service was great. It was a cute like "take out" type taco place with a few tables. Overall, good experience; we were happy.

34.description: A coworker of mine recommended this spot after learning that I live in The neighborhood. On a cold Saturday night after finding nothing in my fridge but white Zinfandel and milk, I decided to give doña chio a call. My plan was to order for pick up but hoping to save myself the 5 minute drive in Albany park traffic, I asked if they delivered. To my surprise they did. Yay!!! Probably less than 15 minute later the delivery man showed up(sounded like the man who answered my call). Very pleasant man he pointed out how chilly it had gotten and its not until this very moment that I realize that he must have walked to my apartment...I'm glad I tipped well :) So we ordered a "huarache de carne asada", "enchiladas de pollo con salsa verde" and "un liquido de chocolate". The huarache was HUGE, the steak was fatty and the flavor was just okay. What made the huarache decent was the mixture of the chipolte and green sauce. However, the steak was too fatty for us to attempt to finish. Now the enchiladas were a lot better; the green sauce once again the star of the dish. It was served with yellow rice and refried beans, the beans were well beans and the rice was better than average. The milkshake as my husband put it was "weak" and it "taste like nestle quick." Overall, I give doña chio 3 stars, the service a 5 and the food a 2. I'm tempted to try them again for I want to find a local gem, however, I think I should keep yelping for this isn't the one.

16.description: This was pretty good! I happened to get the veggie options this day. I was taking a little break from meat. My man got the steak. His tasted way better. Once you go meat, I guess you can't go back to being a vegetarian. I'll try the meat one next time. Overall, though, the service was great. It was a cute like "take out" type taco place with a few tables. Overall, good experience; we were happy.

13.description: Good food here. Always consistent and always on point. The only thing that stinks sometimes is finding parking. This is place always has freshly made Huaraches!

11.description: Run...don't walk for your Huraches is what I was yelling while running to Huraches Dona Chio (I had to run there, literally, because they earlier the most other Mexican restaurants). We had a Carne Asada Hurache.... What is a hurache you might ask? Well, let me tell you. That masa that apparently doesn't sit so well in my stomach, well, that's the tortilla and then a whole buncha other ingredients on top of it. It's like a HUGE Mexican pizza. The carne asada is delicious! The cheese is melty. The salsas are delicious. Honestly, it's a huge mess of Mexican deliciousnesses exploding in your mouth. The  horchata  is DELICIOUS! Not too sweet...not too whatever else...just perfect! I wish they stayed open later...or maybe I should start eating earlier. Either way, Huraches Dona Chio is great, the staff is SO nice, the food is pretty damn good, and the horchata is the 'ish.

39.description: Recently, I was able to try this place, after a fail on another Friday night when they decided to close at 8pm (their sign and posting say that they are open until 9pm).  So yes, call ahead to confirm they're still open.The huarache I had was freshly prepared, and homemade yumminess.  I had half tinga and half peppers and cheese.  Both sides were delicious, though I think next time I would get chorizo and tinga.  That tinga was mmm mmm good.I think the sauces could have been a little hotter, and I'm no spice fiend.  I asked the waitress which sauce was hotter and said, "Today?  I think the red one."  :)  I love it that the table sauces are freshly made!  But I'd say that they could go ahead and kick that heat level up one notch.  I'm surprised because I see that there are many reviews that talk about how hot the food is, and I had someone I know tell me that the food she had here was "face-melting hot".  Hmm.  So apparently the heat level of the sauces varies quite a bit day to day.

37.description: I just ate a carne asada taco on a freshly-made huarache and was heavenly!The place is small and they take their time, but the product is just amazing! A hidden gem on the north side of Chicago. Highly recommended!

0.description: This is the second time I ordered from this place... I must tell the food is pretty good. I did try so far Pozole soup, Menudo soup ... Those are soooo goood. The huaraches are huge and the gorditas also... Highly recommend!!!!

38.description: The best mexican food in the City. Very consistent and cheap.

51.description: This was probably a basement apartment at one point - you have to step down a few stairs to get to it and it's in an otherwise residential building on an otherwise residential street.  You'll turn down the street not thinking you're going the right way, but you are, so don't worry!This is impossibly tasty food in impossibly huge portions for a fraction of what it should probably cost.Had we ordered one huarache al pastor (for two people), that would have been more than sufficient.  A masa cake that takes up a whole widescreen oval plate, covered in spicy pork, cheese, crema, onions, cilantro, and green sauce, it seems to swell the more of it you eat.  Just spicy enough to make your nose run without making your lips and tongue burn, it settles at a medium sizzle.But we knew not the massiveness of the portions before we ordered, so we also ordered the chilaquiles, which, despite my general dislike for steak, got me all filled up with tasty blackened but tender steak pieces, beans, soft tortilla chips, and that same spicy green sauce.As if that weren't enough, we had horchata and agua de mango to drink.  This is one of the only not-too-sweet horchatas in the area and I think they used champagne mangos in the agua!Bring a friend, feed the both of you for $5.(Quick tip for the small-bladder-havers like me: the sign says there is 'no baño publico' but if you ask, they'll let you use it.)

27.description: This is totally a rinky-dink, no frills sorta restaurant but the food is solid. With a tasty half beef/half chicken huarache for less than $5, you can't go wrong. The restaurant seemed clean and the guy behind the counter was nice.

32.description: Run...don't walk for your Huraches is what I was yelling while running to Huraches Dona Chio (I had to run there, literally, because they earlier the most other Mexican restaurants). We had a Carne Asada Hurache.... What is a hurache you might ask? Well, let me tell you. That masa that apparently doesn't sit so well in my stomach, well, that's the tortilla and then a whole buncha other ingredients on top of it. It's like a HUGE Mexican pizza. The carne asada is delicious! The cheese is melty. The salsas are delicious. Honestly, it's a huge mess of Mexican deliciousnesses exploding in your mouth. The  horchata  is DELICIOUS! Not too sweet...not too whatever else...just perfect! I wish they stayed open later...or maybe I should start eating earlier. Either way, Huraches Dona Chio is great, the staff is SO nice, the food is pretty damn good, and the horchata is the 'ish.

54.description: Homemade corn tortillas like I haven't had since I left California.  Ask for the homemade cheese, which is very tasty.  Not much atmosphere, but we took our tacos to go and ate in the park next door.  Cash only.

48.description: The huaraches are bigger than your head and the fillings smarter than what you got going on up there.  Don't be intimidated by the basement location and homemade signs en espanol.  You are welcome here!  The different prices on the menu represent different sizes of the huaraches.  The large size can fill up two people easily, and you can even split the pie if you want to try different fillings.  Try the tinga, it's delicious with salsa.

44.description: Before coming in here, I had no idea what huaraches were. I just knew that it was a new (to me) ethnic food that looked delicious and that I needed to get in my belly. The name was promising as well. I like restaurants that imply they have a legion of old ladies in the back working it out and making food that's old school, crazy delicious, comforting, and that will stick to your ribs. I was the teensiest bit scurred, however, because my latest run-ins with donas in the Chicago area had not ended well. At all.I shouldn't have been worried because this dona, likely, chased the other donas out of town. Delicious. This is delicious food without pretense or markup. Come here because you're hungry and appreciate home-cooked food for days. Don't come here to be seen or pontificate on foolishness. This is real. Come here to be real. As others have mentioned, this looks like a refurb'ed garden apartment, complete with steps that go down and low(er) ceilings. There are only, about, 5 tables in the joint and the majority are two tops. This isn't a spot that's good for large groups. It is, however, good for folks who like to eat. And, because the food is so affordable, you can eat a lot.Not knowing what huaraches were prior to coming, I thought it a good idea to order two kinds. Luckily, my dining Girl Friday was up to the challenge. Purpley agua frescas in hand, we settled in for al pastor and chicken huaraches, one with red sauce and the other with green. Do this. Try both sauces but be aware that they also come in bottles if you need more than what comes with the dish. As for huaraches... do you like gigantic pizza shaped orders of masa loaded down with meat, veggies, spice, sauce, and cheese? Do you like knowing there's a real live dona in the house going to town on your food (rather than having one in name only)? Do you like varieties of agua served in Big Gulp-sized jugs? Do you like being able to eat like a king on a pauper's budget? Do you like supporting true mom & pop establishments? Do you like exploring your city? If the answer to any of these questions is si, get your booty to Edgewater and get ready to do it to it.

24.description: Had the pork tinga huaraches, which were spicy and obviously made with love. Highly recommended!

7.description: We (2 random gringos who were hungry and in the neighbourhood) wandered in here mostly because of the Yelp reviews. You Yelp reviewers did not mislead us. Not sure if it was Doña Chio herself who served us up 2 delicious slabs of the fresh, tasty, delicious, and shockingly inexpensive mexi-gasm known as Huarache, but mother of god I wanted to hug that sweet old lady and hand her the key to the city or something. It was like the entire nation of Mexico was high fiving my tastebuds. Recommendations: The Huaraches are HUGE. If you're average-portion eaters, like me and the fella, SPLIT ONE. Also, don't be a scroogy stingy penny pincher, woman up and get all three toppings. Chorizo was magnificent, rajas were even better than L'Patron (IF ANY L'PATRON EMPLOYEES ARE READING THIS, I STILL LOVE YOU) and the al pastor was probably the best I've had in the city-- perfectly simmered, perfectly seasoned prime pieces o' pork, not the third-rate gristly dumpster-meat you sometimes get. Man, I wish I lived closer. Anyway, keep making magic, Doña Chio.

49.description: This is the kind of place that you would never find if you weren't just wandering around. It is the very definition of hole-in-the-wall. It says a lot about their food that people even manage to find it, and then go out of their way to come back. It's not near anything else to make it easily accessible.It. Is. Delicious.The food is ridiculously good, ridiculously cheap, and ridiculously large. All other Mexican food places bow before it.

40.description: If you like authentic Mexican food you will love this place. Every thing is made by hand. If you ever been to Mexico and have experience a Fonda this is basically what it is. Every thing is made fresh every day. You can actually see them cooking every thing from behind the counter. Awesome it reminds me of home!!

53.description: When I was around 9 or 10, I was enamoured with huaraches, a type of woven Mexican sandal that was hip in the late '60's/early 70's. My parents got me a pair in response to my pleadings, and they ripped up my tender girl feet. After that, I did not think or speak of huaraches until yesterday, when my love affair began anew.My brother and SIL found this little joint. Yesterday afternoon, feeling peckish from lack of food, the Greens picked up a six of Schlitz (taste the cheapness, 'cos it's BYOB!) and we all headed here.OMG. This is a palace for my cheap, broke ass. The food is unbelievably inexpensive and delicious. I had only $5 in my wallet, and that was enough for what I ate - or maybe I stuck my brother with the rest of the bill. Anyway . . .They serve huaraches here, which I had never thought about eating until this day. They look like a Mexican pizza, served on a giant corn tortilla. I am partial to flour tortillas myself, but these were delicious, so I happily consumed. I got the al Pastor - spicy pork, yum - with everything, and green sauce. YUM. This is the delicious Mexican food that I left behind in LA. Take that, overpriced Topolowhatever! A giant, pizza-looking affair that I was only able to finish about 1/3 of. As I write this, I'm noshing on same for breakfast, and I still haven't finished it all. That's 'cos I'm a damn petite flower, but still . . . it's a lot of food, for what . . . $6?The meat was delicious, juicy, well seasoned. Green sauce, cheese - and I smeared a little of our guac over the whole creation, between swigs of Schlitz. Mmmm! That's eatin'. We were the only gringoes in the joint on this day, the rest of the people were families with kids. An adorable feisty little girl ran squealing with joy around the restaurant. Cuuuuuuuuute! We had a cute, friendly waitress, quick service in a spotlessly clean little storefront, tucked in a residential area of Edgewater.My broke ass will be back, living large on my frugal fashionista budget. Yum! That's how I like it!

30.description: This was my first time "Huaraches" experience.  The place was so small but packed, food is fresh and made from scratch.  Vegetarian Huaraches was good (both taste and portion size).  I would like to try other menu sometime in near future!

46.description: Hurray for Huaraches. Great food, freshly cooked. I love it and would recommend to everyone. Warning, small seating area.  Owners need to realize, you can't continue like this! Your food is too good and you will be overrun with customers soon.

1.description: This was an unexpected find, and the food was amazing. We got it to go, and the food traveled home well and was so delicious! I recommend the Horchata especially!

55.description: Go, GO, GOOO!!!!  Stop at the ATM and head over to 1547 West Elmdale now!  Parking can be easily found on Clark.I don't understand why there are not lines out the door.  What an incredible little restaurant.  If my next visit is as good as this one, Huaraches Dona Chio will be my new and favorite Mexican go-to!  This five-table restaurant will blow you away.  There is nothing canned about this place. All homemade food - you can see and taste the love and care that goes into each dish.HDC offers the best in home-made Mexican.  All the tortillas are hand-made to order.  And, don't order too much - the portions will astound you.  I am a hearty eater, but it was all I could do to eat 1 gordita and 1 taco.  They use high-quality meat - we found no fat - and homemade sauces that will rock your world.  The tortillas are THICK - about 1/4 inch - and flavorful and could be an enjoyable meal on their own.

9.description: This place is legit and super delicioso. I came here with family and left feeling totally at home with how the staff was. It's a total mom and pop restaurant with fresh and authentic cuisine. I got to check a food item to try off my bucket list: Huitlacoche. It was flavorful with a silky outside finish and creamy inside. I ordered that with my Huarache and also got their chicken tinga along with a horchata. Best horchata I've ever had, tasted milky and not overkill on the cinnamon. For dessert I tried the flan and that was a rather large slice (ended up splitting it with the sister) and it was pretty yummy, not amazing, but still very good. Can't wait to come back again!

26.description: As soon as I walked into this place, I felt like I was taken south of the border. The horchatas, hibiscus drank, and other concoctions all seemed authentic enough to keep a solid base of people coming back and I thought that this place must be pretty amazing since it kinda is off the beaten path but it has a ton of reviews.I didn't know what a Huaracha was until coming here either, and they were interesting, but I am not sure they are worth all the rave. That being said, its an authentic spot with some really great vibes and some unique options you probably won't find anywhere else.

25.description: This is a little-known gem with delicious food at VERY reasonable prices. I would go again and again. I'd be there every day if it was closer to me. I had their tacos and tostadas, and both were fabulous. The dining area was no-frills, but the food there makes it worthwhile, and you don't have to wait long for your meal.

12.description: Go to Huaraches Dona Chio for some serious business. For under $8, you will receive a delicious gigantic huarache which literally folds over an entire dinner plate. My favorite is the huarache with two toppings, flor de cabaza (zucchini flowers) and al pastor (marinated pork). Now, the al pastor is a little different here and is more like a cross between tinga and al pastor, which results in a more stewy version. However, the sauce perfectly soaks into the masa. If you are not in the mood for a huarache, their tacos are also excellent in part because Dona Chio makes all of their tortillas by hand. And, who in their right mind does not love a hand made tortilla?

59.description: The huaraches are great, huge and delicious. I've been there a couple of times, the service.is ok.It could be better if the restaurant was bigger, and the food took less time to be served.

21.description: I dunno why the heck I don't go here more often, since it's only a half mile away from where I live. But the tinga is really darn good here on the huarache!It's hidden off of Clark and on Elmdale, slightly east of the Clark/Peterson(Elmdale east of that intersection) intersection. Tiny storefront, but it's the last one you see before the alley, and directly west of a park. If you drive here, I'd recommend parking on one of the residential blocks slightly north of here, and walking back. The diagonal spaces just east of here and by the park are often totally filled up, for whatever reason.

17.description: I ordered the salsa verde chicken enchiladas and I must say they were the best enchiladas I've had in a while definitely going back! lil hesitant in walkin in but went for it and glad I did. It is very small but very clean. Best random spot I've hit up by far.

10.description: I dunno why the heck I don't go here more often, since it's only a half mile away from where I live. But the tinga is really darn good here on the huarache!It's hidden off of Clark and on Elmdale, slightly east of the Clark/Peterson(Elmdale east of that intersection) intersection. Tiny storefront, but it's the last one you see before the alley, and directly west of a park. If you drive here, I'd recommend parking on one of the residential blocks slightly north of here, and walking back. The diagonal spaces just east of here and by the park are often totally filled up, for whatever reason.

5.description: love their thinga huaraches. The restaurant itself is small but the food is so worth it. Would definitely recommend  this place :)

3.description: All I can is wow. Had a chicken huarache and wow talk about fresh. This taste homemade and delicious. Am def coming back.

35.description: 5 stars! Here's what you need to know: It's tiny.  It's easy to miss if you don't know what you're looking for. There are about 5 tables inside. It's cash only. It's FAN-FREAKING-TASTIC authentic Mexican food. And las senoras hand-make the tortillas. I just ate and now I'm hungry again talking about it. It's a hidden gem and you need to go now.

19.description: This was probably a basement apartment at one point - you have to step down a few stairs to get to it and it's in an otherwise residential building on an otherwise residential street.  You'll turn down the street not thinking you're going the right way, but you are, so don't worry!This is impossibly tasty food in impossibly huge portions for a fraction of what it should probably cost.Had we ordered one huarache al pastor (for two people), that would have been more than sufficient.  A masa cake that takes up a whole widescreen oval plate, covered in spicy pork, cheese, crema, onions, cilantro, and green sauce, it seems to swell the more of it you eat.  Just spicy enough to make your nose run without making your lips and tongue burn, it settles at a medium sizzle.But we knew not the massiveness of the portions before we ordered, so we also ordered the chilaquiles, which, despite my general dislike for steak, got me all filled up with tasty blackened but tender steak pieces, beans, soft tortilla chips, and that same spicy green sauce.As if that weren't enough, we had horchata and agua de mango to drink.  This is one of the only not-too-sweet horchatas in the area and I think they used champagne mangos in the agua!Bring a friend, feed the both of you for $5.(Quick tip for the small-bladder-havers like me: the sign says there is 'no baño publico' but if you ask, they'll let you use it.)

28.description: By far the best tacos I've had in Chicago! This is definitely not a trendy place, but the food will not disappoint. It's very small with only a few tables, and hard to find, but worth the effort. The staff are very friendly and you can tell a lot of love goes into the food.A real gem.

45.description: This is the second location (I believe) of the much loved huaraches spot that started in Edgewater. Their huaraches are stuffed with a thin layer of beans and griddle fried before being topped. There are two "sauces" you can choose from: red (tangy chipotle) or green (jalapeno tomatillo). The word huaraches means sandals, but these babies are much larger than any non-NBA player size foot. I'm giving it four stars because of the diversity of vegetarian toppings choices (you can get two or three toppings on your huarache for ~$7). But Mr. W did not think the al pastor and tinga was as good as the versions he orders at another local taqueria (he gave it three stars but I'm the one with the Yelp account). I alos think it's a great value. I took half of mine home but Mr. W. managed to polish his off (and then slipped into a food coma an hour later).It's a cozy, bright and friendly spot along Lawrence. I'm not sure how it compares to the other huaraches place a few doors down, but it's worth a stop if you are nearby or looking for a good deal.

33.description: Hand made tortillas... What more do I need to say?

43.description: This is probably the best, freshest mexican food I have eaten outside Mexico, and better than most I have eaten IN Mexico. Seriously. Fresh, made to order (from fresh-ground corn masa) tortillas, huaraches, sopes, etc. Fillings to die for, particularly the Barbacoa (goat stew), Asada, Tinga (spicy chicken), Flor de Calabeza (Sunflowers!). It's all good. All made by grandmothers. And all at terrific prices. Only a few tables, so nearly always crowded.Now stay away. I still want to be able to eat here.

2.description: I heard about this place because the bf's hair stylist, a transplant from Mexico City, said Huaraches Dona Chio was his favorite Mexican place in Chicago. Neither of us had ever heard of a huarache, so we paid this hole-in-the-wall a visit. Turns out a huarache is basically a Mexican pizza, with a corn tortilla for the base, refried beans for the "sauce," and your choice of meat or vegetables, onions, cilantro, cheese, and red/green sauce as the toppings.We tried the pastor, (chicken) tinga, and chorizo. The pastor was bland, the chorizo was very flavorful, and the tinga was fine. The red sauce was spicier than green sauce. The huarache should be eaten relatively quickly because the tortilla gets soggy from the refried beans and or sauce and then falls apart. The prices are very cheap considering the amount of food you get. We waited about 30 minutes for our food, and there were 3 orders in front of us. This restaurant is very small, maybe 10 seats, and doesn't have the greatest eat-in atmosphere, but it's a clean hole-in-the-wall establishment. In the future I would order take-out.

18.description: Best Mexican food! Hands down! The staff and cooks are really nice. Highly recommend this place if you like tacos.

41.description: I stopped by for lunch on Sunday.  The dining area was hot and tiny, with about six tables crammed into a small space.  There is a park nearby.  It looked like it had some benches, but I didn't see any picnic tables.  Still, if you're visiting any time near peak meal times, I'd recommend ordering your food to go.Most of the signs and the guests' conversations were in Spanish, which speaks to the cuisine's authenticity.  The waitress spoke perfect English, sparing me from needing to exercise my rusty Spanish skills.I ordered the Huitaloche (corn smut) Huarache.  I aim to eat vegetarian when I can, and the ingredients as presented seemed pretty close.  I can't vouch for the huarache masa itself, but it didn't taste particularly lardy.  The portion was large enough that I felt a bit over-full after eating it, so I'd recommend splitting it unless you're really hungry.  The ingredients tasted fresh and worked very well together.  I'm not fond of cilantro (it tastes a bit soapy to me), but it actually worked quite well in this dish.  I got the green salsa and was very pleased with my choice.  There were both red and green salsa bottles on the table, and I definitely preferred the green.

52.description: Fantastic little divey Mexican place in an off-beat location. Some of the best Mexican I have had anywhere - including Mexico... and if I understood it correctly, they get their mole sauce right from Mexico directly from some mole guru (probably some old lady in a tired little village who just knows exactly what mole is all about!)So great. Go here soon if you haven't already.

50.description: Best kind of hole in the wall where you see tables overfilled with food and people just chowing down on all sorts of corn wrapped dishes and piping hot soup.  I had their huarache with chorizo.  The filling was as expected - good, but the kind of stuff you can get at any Mexican place.  But it was the corn masa, which was made from scratch right there that made it special.  They are huge and they're generous with the fillings.  For $6, it's a great value.  Parking is tricky in the neighborhood.  It might be easier to find something on Clark.

4.description: OMG..... fresh Huaraches made from masa!!!!  Fresh masa tacos!!!!!!!  It just doesn't get any better than this if you like FRESH tortillas made right in front of you.  This place is TINY.  they only have 4 very small tables in a space that would do better with 2.  The food is super fresh.  It is sort of a dump........OK, it really is a dump in a basement, but the food is outrageous.  BYOB.

6.description: Ay Mi Huaraches Doña Chio ----- Los extraño mucho!!!!Can't wait to get back home to Chicago.... This will be our first meal when we get home for sure. Whether it's Chilaquiles for breakfast, un taco for lunch, or un huarache for dinner....We love everything. Yes, sometimes you have a wait a tad longer than you would expect, but the place is small, everything is handmade, and fresh. Has the same feel as some of our favorite taquerias back in Mexico. Just an absolute fave of ours! :)

22.description: Came here for lunch, the huracha was monstrous. The salsas and the tinga were ok, the cactus and the poblano were very good. The prices are very reasonable. It's a good place to go for a quick meal, but not necessarily worth going out of your way for.

15.description: As soon as I walked into this place, I felt like I was taken south of the border. The horchatas, hibiscus drank, and other concoctions all seemed authentic enough to keep a solid base of people coming back and I thought that this place must be pretty amazing since it kinda is off the beaten path but it has a ton of reviews.I didn't know what a Huaracha was until coming here either, and they were interesting, but I am not sure they are worth all the rave. That being said, its an authentic spot with some really great vibes and some unique options you probably won't find anywhere else.

57.description: Food+price was 5 stars, atmosphere was 1 star.Hardest thing is that there aren't enough tables and have to wait. Is there any other Mexican restaurants make as good food as here with better atmosphere?! I am dying to know if exist..

20.description: They make their own tortillasThe tacos are $3-$3.50 and SO worth it.I have not found weird stuff in my chicken.The huaraches are GIGANTIC.

36.description: Not so impressed.  I had eaten from here once before and I thought it was better then.  My main issue is that they got my carry out order wrong.  They were not busy. there were two tables in use and they already had their food.  So it was just my order being prepped.  I knew I wanted nopales on my huarache, and I asked the waitress if there was something she suggested to go with the nopales. She said steak (in very clear English.)  I said great.  She then asked if I wanted everything on it.  I said sure.  So I get it home and it is the plain huarache with the beans (?), a very little bit of cheese, onions, and cilantro.  Of course I paid for the loaded one.  Oh well.  It tasted ok, after I added the salsa verde they put in the bag.  Nothing special.  I have other places down Clark street that deserve a look.

14.description: Keeping it simple:  Great homemade mexican food that is actually authentic and tastes homemade.  The best part, portions are more than enough and incredibly affordable.

58.description: My husband and I came here on a chilly afternoon, sat on a couple of old couches and relaxed for a while.  Pros:His cappuccino was one of the best in the cityI could see that Loyola students or others could easily study/meet here with the much-mentioned outletsCons:No outside food.  I completely understand the policy, but I had bought my husband a croissant for his b-day so we snuck it in.  Just be aware for the future.My regular coffee wasn't much to talk about plus, expensive to refill - I might as well have gotten a "fancy" coffee for the cost.  And, again, it wasn't great.It's loud - with the aforementioned studentsThe couches are a bit dirty - they maybe could use a cleaning.  I mean, I sat on them, it's fine, but it might be time for a rotation.I recommend going in if you're on your own, want a cappuccino or the like, and would enjoy people watching or working.

56.description: There be hipsters about.And I don't mean that in the perorative. The term "hipsters" can refer to people who see themselves as annoyingly superior in their cultural tastes, but as applied to Metropolis I'm talking about the people who work there. Low-key. Unassuming. Slow to anger. Quick to smile. Nothing seems to faze them. I've seen total assholes move up to the register and by the time they are through ordering they've calmed down because how can you stay angry in the face of such calm  imperturbability? That so many have ponytails and wear flannel and skinny jeans is secondary and irrelevant. What matters is that this is one of the best coffee houses I've been to anywhere, much less in Chicago which has decent-to-nice independently owned coffee houses every few blocks. The hot beverage selection is unmatched whether you drink coffee, tea or something else. The coffee is delicious and cheaper than Starbucks for basic coffee. (Order a Red Eye!)The cold beverage selection is a bit lacking and slightly expensive (diet soda, please!) The snack and pastry selection, while not extensive, is perfectly fine for someone who comes to a coffee house to do serious work. And this is the place for serious work or just have a coffee with friends. Two and one-half large rooms of seating with free wifi and electrical outlets nearly everywhere. Don't let the fact that this place is huge (for a coffee house) fool you. It's large but it's also crazy popular. Get there before 10:00 am and you should be OK. Later in the evening closer to closing time and you might snag a table on your first cruise through the place. There is communal seating in some places and two comfy sofas, so finding a place for one person is easier. Two or more and you take your chances. You  learn the ebb and flow of the crowd after a while.I love this place. I'd bet you will also.(This supplants my previous short review.)

29.description: Amazing coffee while somehow having a cozy and non-pretentious atmosphere. This seems like a rarity nowadays in Chicago. Seriously this is the perfect place. Located right down the road from home and not as crowded as some other coffee shop experiences.

42.description: I went here on a Sunday morning and it was packed, almost out the door. The service was good, but the coffee was alright. It was not worth the wait, but it wasn't bad either. An alright experience. Their house made pastries are delicious though!

23.description: Amazing! Excellent place to study, talk, read, think, relax, or just chill. I love the local artwork and the staff is incredible! Very cool place. I am grateful they are here!

47.description: This place takes pride in making great coffee. They are the younger and cooler version of starbucks. They are cheaper then starbucks and they have better customer service. They have free wifi and a lot of places to sit. I like their mocha ice coffee and would suggest to avoid this place during midterms and finals because it gets packed with college students that cant afford wifi lol.

8.description: At the recommendation  of someone I'm following on Instagram, I decided to try out Metropolis. The hipster vibe is very much 2010, but the coffee is fantastic. I got the ginger coffee brewed with Kenyan Weithag as a pour-over. I liked it a lot. The coffeehouse is a nice size and seems to pack quickly. I will go for takeaway in the future.

31.description: I am not the biggest coffee drinker. I only started drinking coffee in the past 2 years, but I can honestly say this place has AMAZING coffee! I usually get a small sugar free vanilla iced coffee, put a little skim milk in it, and I'm good to go! The people who work here are always friendly, helpful, and patient. I don't ever feel rushed when I'm ordering a coffee here, which I sometimes feel at other coffee shops. I also love that I can sit and do work here. They play music, but it is relaxing music and not too loud - more of background noise. I think Metropolis is a hidden gem in Chicago and I am so glad I stumbled upon it one day!

34.description: I came here to use my groupon deal - two coffees and two breakfast sandwiches for $15. Which turns out to be a terrible deal. There was ONE sandwich available - a egg muffin something something and my barista was definitely high. Bahahha

16.description: This coffee shop is quaint and has really good coffee. They offer a few pies and quiches that are also delicious. I ordered the green tea latte here and it was slightly foamy on the top with the smooth feel in the middle I like. Added bonuses:1. There's currently a deal on Groupon here. 2. If you buy coffee here often, they have a deal where the 8th (?) coffee or so is free. I've only seen others use this as I haven't done it myself.

13.description: I recommend this place for people who want to get some serious work done!First of all, there are enough outlets for your laptops, tablets, and cellular devices.  Although chances are that you may be sitting with some working strangers diagonally across you at a large table, you will still have your own privacy.  Clientele is consisted of college students (Loyola), working professionals, and career yelpers like myself.  The entire place is comfortable to sit for a considerable amount of time.  Toward the back of the coffee shop, there is a couple of cozy sofas with a small coffee table just in case you want to snuggle.  Well, it's a coffee shop.  I know the coffee has to be good, correct?  I had the 12 oz. chai and green tea latte.  Even though the chai wasn't the best I've had (Bridgeport Coffee Company is more superior in the chai category), I couldn't really complain because it was still quite good.  I'm fond of the green tea latte though.  I liked it that it was savory, but not at all cloying.  The prices of the coffee are pretty reasonable.  You can get a cup of regular for a little over $2.  Mr. SB and Miss DD: retreat your footprints in Chicago; your coffee is subpar.  They didn't require the password for the free wifi, and I was able to log on it after registering with an e-mail address.  They do have some profound, philosophical books for you to peruse, but I will pass because I've had my life figured out.  It's located two (2)-minute walking distance to the CTA Granville Red line station.  The surroundings seem to be safe because the Loyola dormitories are in proximity.  I saw the Chicago Police and the Campus Patrol Unit constantly going around to watch suspicious activities.

11.description: This coffee shop feels like a nice quaint local establishment, with lots of great options of good coffee. We each had something different, and each was done with a lot of love and artistry. It's a pleasant change from the normal Starbucks that we normally get.The Green tea latte was definitely a highlight. Obviously it doesn't have as much caffeine... but it was superb.

39.description: Great customer service, good pies, amazing coffee. Convenient location, comfortable seating, free wifi.

37.description: A perfect balance between being rundown/shitty and cool. Whoever put this place together was clever - minimal art on the walls (much of which is by local artists and for sale), a large space to utilize, and some pretty good coffee. I enjoy coming here for these reasons.  Understandably, every time I come here it's pretty packed.  The crowd seems to be mostly students and friends hanging out. Be prepared to get overwhelmed by the amount of hipsters that are within a 20 foot radius of where you're sitting.  Whatever, though, they don't bother me.As far as drinks go, I have tried their iced chai, regular coffee, and Italian soda.  All were good.  They don't carry almond milk, sadly, but they do offer hemp milk for those who don't do dairy or soy.  Parking is plentiful.  Out front is regular paid parking.  Further down the street, in the residential areas, there's free parking (just a short walk away), and the company provides a small lot next door for customers (but good luck finding parking there).  I am a big fan of coffee shops and the environment they provide when I'm studying for school.  At the moment, I'm taking a break from a 20 page paper that's due in...oh...two weeks (only 16 more pages to go!).  Places like Metropolis provide just the right amount of human contact for people like me who don't like working in total silence.I'll definitely be coming here for a long time to come.

0.description: This is probably one of my favorite coffee shops in Chicago. The coffee is excellent! The shop has a hippy feel to it with a welcoming environment. It's usually crowded with students probably from Loyola since it's close by. It's also close to the lake. So my friends and I like to grab coffee from here and walk over to the lake nearby. The lake also has a playground that the kids can play at while you enjoy your coffee and the view. In terms of parking there's a good amount of free street parking. The service is always excellent!I like to get the house blend of the day, mocha and my friend got the Mexican hot cocoa( I think)it was excellent. In terms of coffee my three favorite places  to get a good cup of coffee are from metropolis, intelligentsia and ipsento. Definitely check this place out! They also sell there house blend coffee beans at target if you can't make it out to the store.

38.description: I like their green tea latte. Creamy n smooth in consistency. Not a huge fan of coffee

51.description: LOVE!!!!!! I'm a barista and I totally cheat on my cafe with metropolis constantly. High quality coffee and tea and a very sweet, knowledgeable staff! The latte art is always phenomenal. Not a coffee or tea drinker? No problem. One of my favorite things is the large cooler filled with rare, amazing sodas. Metropolis has a great environment for hanging out with friends or even quietly studying. The cafe is always filled and somehow kept clean and pristine at all times. Ok just writing this review convinced me to head there for my afternoon cup. Bye!

27.description: A classic urban coffee shop; eclectic, mellow and welcoming.  Delicious lattes and one of the best bagel and lox sandwiches around. The side salad is a welcome touch.

32.description: Nice coffee place...i love their tea and how it is served. Very good customer service...i like this place

54.description: I am in town visiting and came across this coffee shop. I ordered a caramel latte and a bagel and loxs. The staff was very nice and my order came out pretty quick. The cafe was filled with people but the line moved quick. I'll definitely be coming back when I'm in town again.

48.description: I took the family on a walk around Edgewater, and I knew I wanted to stop in here  for a snack before we headed home. While I was there, I figured I'd get some iced coffee too.I can't tell you much about the Kyoto process, but I can say that it makes some fine iced coffee, one I'm very happy to drink black (okay, with a little bit of simple syrup). It's strong, definitely bold but not that bitter. We also had a blueberry crumble bar and a piece of apple cherry pie. The bar, which is made in-house, crumbled nicely and wasn't overly sweet. The blueberries were fresh, and the texture was excellent.The pie was even better, though I wish I knew which bakery it came from. The crust was flaky but sturdy all the way through, from the bottom of the crust out to the edges. There was an ample amount of fruit, and the pie topping reminded me of a great brown sugar crumble. I think a piece of pie runs $4.50... it's definitely worth it.A coffee house like this deserves to be well trafficked.
