There's many nooks and crannies for people to sit, and it's nice and quiet on the inside. I wish I had one of these closer to home!

44.description: Outstanding coffee, easily the best around. The vibe of the place is super chill. The only thing holding me back from dropping a 5* is sometimes the staff acys a little to cool for school for me. Its a solid 4.5 * spot for sure.

24.description: This coffee shop feels like a nice quaint local establishment, with lots of great options of good coffee. We each had something different, and each was done with a lot of love and artistry. It's a pleasant change from the normal Starbucks that we normally get.The Green tea latte was definitely a highlight. Obviously it doesn't have as much caffeine... but it was superb.

7.description: Two stars.  Coffee is fresh roast but their gimmick seems to involve playing around with different varieties of beans and mixing light/dark roasts together to make some of their signature blends.  Not a huge fan of this sort of apostasy--having a coffee with both a loud citrus (underdone) and a scorched plywood flavor (well done) is just not palatable, IMO.Facility is good sized and hipsterish in decor, replete with cafe tables, weird furniture and avant-garde artsy pictures on the walls.The baristas seem aloof and forcibly nice, and act like they all belong to some exclusive coffee guild that only tolerates customers if they genuflect and pay proper homage to their skills. They appear to communicate with each other using eye rolls, smirks and odd looks, usually while you're ordering. Not sure of the exact dialect, but if you're into having your coffee made by a guild-like group of folks then you're all set.Despite having a cash tip jar on the counter they will SHAMELESSLY AUTO-TIP YOU on your bill if you use a CC to pay.  This tees me off, especially when I'm just buying a coffee and leaving the premises--what service am I needing to tip them for?  There is no real service involved.  And if you dare to check "no tip" on your receipt then they get kind of short with you--zero to bitch in 3 seconds.The desserts are usually creative in nature and reasonably priced--had a great oatmeal pie there once.Two stars.

49.description: Metropolis is a mainstay for me.  I can count on Metropolis to provide great coffee, truly free wi-fi and a cozy environment to read, write or procrastinate.  I can't say I have ever had a less than delicious cookie, cinnamon roll (with a generous amount of icing), slice of cake or some other treat here either which is a plus when I need to indulge while studying.  The cafe is pretty spacious, seating spans two rooms and the stream of patrons ebbs and flows somewhere between steady and overflowing.  In other words, I have never seen the place less than half-empty during the various times I've popped by for a "spot" and a squat' I've generally been lucky to snag a seat during peak times provided I have time to wait patiently.  The music played here is truly "eclectic."  Sometimes it's more conducive to dancing on a table than relaxing with a book or staring at a laptop screen vigilantly and waiting for inspiration to hit so you can finish that paper.  Bring headphones.  The end.

40.description: Breakfaest eggs are good and affordable.

53.description: So delicious! Comfy, cheapish, and cool. Doesn't hurt that its right by my aptmt too :)

30.description: Seth and other staff members helped me repeatedly by giving me used coffee grounds that I could use in my garden.  I'm extremely grateful for this.Also, at the main office, I was able to get giant burlap bags for free.  Yay for recycling!In addition, I like their hot chocolate and that they have cinnamon sticks among the complimentary items you can add to your drinks.  The space is large and not too crowded, and they also have a small sidewalk area where people can sit with their purchases and friendly dogs.Thanks again!

46.description: If Metropolis exchanged places with Starbucks and there were zillions of MCC's and 1 Starbucks, I would be okay with that. This perspective is coming from a Starbucks devotee. There is something  special about Metropolis. From the attention to detail of every single drink creation to the carefully selected espresso, coffee beans, tea leaves, unique sodas; there's something refreshing, aromatic, caffeinated and simply divine, for everyone to quench their thirst or merely wake up. Metropolis has the competition in the bag as far as quality, delicious tasting baked goods. Some are homemade, others are brought in from a bakery - all are simply delicious and worth every caloric bite! Several months ago, they advertised on Craigslist that that they were giving away free coffee bags. I got a bunch of these cool cloth bags - in fact, several of them. Not because I had an immediate use for coffee bags, but because I wanted the aroma of Metropolis in my house and I do want to find an art project where I can use the most interesting coffee bags.

1.description: I hung out all day here and it was great for studying! Although it was hard to find a table in the morning, by the afternoon there were plenty of open seats. A bonus is that they have lots of outlets all over so it's a great place to study. Their chai is so delicious too! A little pricey but definitely worth it on a cold day.

55.description: This is just the type of quirky coffee house that every college town/area should have. A great mix of hipsters, old-school hippies (that's me) and a gaggle of chic little gay boys and feminists ---- coffee is better than most and the outlets are great for finishing that project at work, or school.

9.description: About as cool as an independant area coffee shop can be. Comfy seats, lots of room, excellent coffee, an all around excellent societal setting. The folks are friendly, the food is great, but the java is the star of the show. Roasted on premise, this really is as fresh and high quality as there may be, also it reveals. From their espresso based beverages to the entire bean coffee to bring home, everything tastes wonderful.

26.description: I love Metropolis. I moved and I still get my coffee from them every week. Open a shop in Avondale ;)

25.description: Damn. The stereotype about Japanese "salarymen" working late into the Tokyo night must be true, if the Kyoto-style, cold-brew iced coffee having a groovin' house party on my tongue right now is any indication. This stuff is good and strong, good AND strong--all three combinations.I don't know what's with the folks in Kyoto, though. I once travelled there, and it was a mellow city with a rich history and a relatively slow pace of life, at least compared to the major cities of Japan. Maybe they are like the drug dealers that source & sell the stuff, but have a rule not to use the stuff. They just ship it to shaking addicts in Tokyo and beyond.I'm not up this way too often, but Metropolis has been on my 5-star cafe list since the first time I set tongue on it, about the time that it opened. The coffee is good, and I especially appreciate the ambience: the big couches and small and group tables; the multiple rooms, both quiet and with music; and the diversity of people here: a many-bean salad of ethnicities and earnings, students and salary-(wo)men, the young and the still-youthful, paper- and pixel-lovers, the engrossed and en-gossiped, those alone and accompanied... Stop me if I'm boring and belaboring you. The counter staff has always been friendly to me, and they've always had a sense of humor in this oh-so-serious world of coffee, where they clearly know beans about beans. When I've seen Jeff, the owner, he's regaled me with stories of his trips to Brazil and the large stacks of sacks of coffee we were standing by, and about the virtues of making espresso with a not-so-dark roasted bean. While I wish they were closer to my abode, I'm glad that they're not, because this place is one-of-a-kind.

12.description: A perfect balance between being rundown/shitty and cool. Whoever put this place together was clever - minimal art on the walls (much of which is by local artists and for sale), a large space to utilize, and some pretty good coffee. I enjoy coming here for these reasons.  Understandably, every time I come here it's pretty packed.  The crowd seems to be mostly students and friends hanging out. Be prepared to get overwhelmed by the amount of hipsters that are within a 20 foot radius of where you're sitting.  Whatever, though, they don't bother me.As far as drinks go, I have tried their iced chai, regular coffee, and Italian soda.  All were good.  They don't carry almond milk, sadly, but they do offer hemp milk for those who don't do dairy or soy.  Parking is plentiful.  Out front is regular paid parking.  Further down the street, in the residential areas, there's free parking (just a short walk away), and the company provides a small lot next door for customers (but good luck finding parking there).  I am a big fan of coffee shops and the environment they provide when I'm studying for school.  At the moment, I'm taking a break from a 20 page paper that's due in...oh...two weeks (only 16 more pages to go!).  Places like Metropolis provide just the right amount of human contact for people like me who don't like working in total silence.I'll definitely be coming here for a long time to come.

59.description: Stopped in for a quick breakfast and a coffee. Service was fast, staff was friendly and the food was wildly delicious. The breakfast sandwich is highly recommended. Will be returning for round 2 when back in he neighborhood.

21.description: Love the espresso drinks and the vibe. In the morning they have pastries from the Middle Eastern Bakery!

17.description: I took the family on a walk around Edgewater, and I knew I wanted to stop in here  for a snack before we headed home. While I was there, I figured I'd get some iced coffee too.I can't tell you much about the Kyoto process, but I can say that it makes some fine iced coffee, one I'm very happy to drink black (okay, with a little bit of simple syrup). It's strong, definitely bold but not that bitter. We also had a blueberry crumble bar and a piece of apple cherry pie. The bar, which is made in-house, crumbled nicely and wasn't overly sweet. The blueberries were fresh, and the texture was excellent.The pie was even better, though I wish I knew which bakery it came from. The crust was flaky but sturdy all the way through, from the bottom of the crust out to the edges. There was an ample amount of fruit, and the pie topping reminded me of a great brown sugar crumble. I think a piece of pie runs $4.50... it's definitely worth it.A coffee house like this deserves to be well trafficked. There's many nooks and crannies for people to sit, and it's nice and quiet on the inside. I wish I had one of these closer to home!

10.description: Minus two stars for rude staff. Seemingly chaotic as to what station to go pick up items. Bagels come from the kitchen window quiches come from the cash register coffees come from cash register and espresso drinks take 20 minutes and come from the espresso bar. There really is zero sense of urgency from the baristas which is annoying because not all of us live the life of Riley and can afford to waste the entire day hanging out at the coffee shop.  Less than pleasant staff, really no accommodation to help the customer or deliver items, just rude instruction on where to go fetch everything.  Probably won't make it back here.

5.description: I love going to Metropolis - strong internet connection, plenty of seating, they'll give you more hot water for your tea as often as you want. What is there not to like? I usually get the weekly pairing, because why not? Also because it saves me the stress of trying to pick a tea off what I think is a very substantial list, and then deciding whether or not to get a pastry. Just get the pastry and the tea they suggest. You won't be disappointed. Protip: if you have 500+ followers on Instagram, download the app Popular Pays for a free weekly pairing once a month! Literally MY FAVE thing.

3.description: I cannot find a place like this serving sophisticated latte and nice intensity and flavor of coffee :) I enjoyed my latte with free wifi.Two things, I want to suggest this place are 1) spacing and 2) cleaning. I think they can organize interiors to fit more people and be wise to use space efficiently. This large crowd of people fighting for seating leads my second concern. It won't let any staffs to clean up the tables and floors because as soon as table is open, It was taken in a second, so it kept uncleanliness all the time. I hope they will fix these soon.

35.description: Just moved into the neighborhood and am so happy I came across this coffee nook. Great for a good cup of coffee and delicious pastries.

19.description: Thank you Jennifer Greenburg and Melissa Sands for recommending this spot!The cold brewed Kyoto style coffee is wonderful. Plenty of seating. We joined the coffee club.

28.description: This coffee shop is quaint and has really good coffee. They offer a few pies and quiches that are also delicious. I ordered the green tea latte here and it was slightly foamy on the top with the smooth feel in the middle I like. Added bonuses:1. There's currently a deal on Groupon here. 2. If you buy coffee here often, they have a deal where the 8th (?) coffee or so is free. I've only seen others use this as I haven't done it myself.

45.description: I'm normally pretty unimpressed by most coffee places. But I was here the other day for a meeting, and for the first time in a while I had a delightful experience.Most coffee places I find the service to be a bit smug and standoffish. Here I found the staff to be enthusiastic and informed. I had some questions about their tea selection, and even though it looked a little busy, one of the baristas took the time to help explain the differences and give his opinion. There were no rolls of the eyes, or terse responses, it was helpful and considerate.The atmosphere was relaxing, and had a good buzz about it. If you're in that northern area of Chicago--and are either trying to find space to get some constructive work done, Metropolis is the place for it!

33.description: Of all the local roasts, Metropolis is by far the best coffee in town, and perhaps the best coffee period. It is brewed in such a way as you can really taste all the various flavors which almost seem to be translated in to "tones".  They all complement each other and give a really full flavor.  I buy them by the pound for my espresso machine.  The cafe is awesome.  The bakery is incredible. I had the Dutch apple pie made with sour cream.  Yuh-Ummmm!  So incredibly rich.  I don't get in the area very often, because I live downtown, but I try to detour my way over to Edgewater so I can pick up coffee, and enjoy the atmosphere. The coffee is spectacular.

43.description: The hazelnut latte is AMAZING. I really like this Metropolis location --lots of seating, friendly barristas. The only downside is that on the weekends, it can get too crowded. Otherwise, great location with free wi-fi.

2.description: I really like the atmosphere of this place. It's your usual cafe with great wifi. There are many seats and there are a lot of people, but it's not noisy, just the soft background chatter. I find this place perfect to study or get work done individually.I would definitely come here again, and take advantage of the free parking! I didn't know there was one, and ended up parking a couple blocks away in the residential areas because I didn't want to pay for parking! The lot next to the cafe is for MCC customers as well as those going to the thai restaurant across the street.

18.description: Great space serving stellar coffee and with tons of comfy seating. Great creative drinks and I love the blueberry thyme muffin they had.

41.description: I love Metropolis so much! I love walking in and smelling the coffee. I don't drink coffee, but I still love the smell! (If I could drink coffee I would start here! My BF & most of my friends are obsessed w Metropolis coffee.) Every time I come here I find my experience here so delightful. Awesome staff, delicious hot cocoa & whipped cream, great atmosphere, fun location, and yummy pastries! Support local business and check this place out. You won't be sorry!

52.description: This is the best coffee in Chicago.  We are longtime residents of Edgewater and have been loyal to Metropolis since they opened on Granville. The coffee is exceptional, friendly service,great selection of food, and lots of seating (yet always full!). Now that we've moved to West Ridge, we make special trips to Metropolis for our coffee. I would love something similar within walking distance of our new home, Metropolis is such a wonderful anchor to our former neighborhood.

50.description: Their pastries are to die for and their mochas are the best I've had in Chicago! Oh, also, all of their breakfast items (egg sandwich, oatmeal, and parfait) ...SO.GOOD! Seriously, if I didn't have time to make breakfast I'll head here and leave so satisfied.

4.description: Damn. The stereotype about Japanese "salarymen" working late into the Tokyo night must be true, if the Kyoto-style, cold-brew iced coffee having a groovin' house party on my tongue right now is any indication. This stuff is good and strong, good AND strong--all three combinations.I don't know what's with the folks in Kyoto, though. I once travelled there, and it was a mellow city with a rich history and a relatively slow pace of life, at least compared to the major cities of Japan. Maybe they are like the drug dealers that source & sell the stuff, but have a rule not to use the stuff. They just ship it to shaking addicts in Tokyo and beyond.I'm not up this way too often, but Metropolis has been on my 5-star cafe list since the first time I set tongue on it, about the time that it opened. The coffee is good, and I especially appreciate the ambience: the big couches and small and group tables; the multiple rooms, both quiet and with music; and the diversity of people here: a many-bean salad of ethnicities and earnings, students and salary-(wo)men, the young and the still-youthful, paper- and pixel-lovers, the engrossed and en-gossiped, those alone and accompanied... Stop me if I'm boring and belaboring you. The counter staff has always been friendly to me, and they've always had a sense of humor in this oh-so-serious world of coffee, where they clearly know beans about beans. When I've seen Jeff, the owner, he's regaled me with stories of his trips to Brazil and the large stacks of sacks of coffee we were standing by, and about the virtues of making espresso with a not-so-dark roasted bean. While I wish they were closer to my abode, I'm glad that they're not, because this place is one-of-a-kind.

6.description: Great place close to the beach. It has a great walking distance. I find that the service is wonderful

22.description: Was a patron for seven solid years. When I told them I was moving, they packed up a ton of their pastries for the day to send me off with. They get to know you FAST here and they love familiar faces. The coffee is the best in the city, although anyone can tell you that. Conveniently located next to the L on the west and the lake on the east. Decor is fun and hasn't changed vibes in years. Loved it then, still rave about it now. Conducive to instagrammers that love taking shots of their cappuccinos.

15.description: Of all the local roasts, Metropolis is by far the best coffee in town, and perhaps the best coffee period. It is brewed in such a way as you can really taste all the various flavors which almost seem to be translated in to "tones".  They all complement each other and give a really full flavor.  I buy them by the pound for my espresso machine.  The cafe is awesome.  The bakery is incredible. I had the Dutch apple pie made with sour cream.  Yuh-Ummmm!  So incredibly rich.  I don't get in the area very often, because I live downtown, but I try to detour my way over to Edgewater so I can pick up coffee, and enjoy the atmosphere. The coffee is spectacular.

57.description: Metropolis is that rare specialty coffee shop that also serves baked goods and other foods prepared on sight. The kitchen is wonderful, hatching up delicious tea-infused cakes and nourishing salads. Everything, including the baked goods from other businesses (such as pies and quiche from Hoosier Mama Pie company), is always fresh and generously portioned. The coffee and espresso--and my favorite, the Kyoto-style iced coffee--is invariably well-prepared by skilled baristas. My favorite indulgence: Kyoto-style iced coffee with a slice of Hoosier Mama chocolate cream pie. Not for the faint of heart!

20.description: I've never been in a Metropolis coffee before, and I'm more than pleasantly surprised! I'm not from this area, but I feel at home here. The staff is friendly, the soy almond latte I got is excellent and they have sooo many flavours. The internet process is easy to work. But, best of all, I asked for a quiche and the staff called me over to say, "The quiche pieces are really small." I thought they were just fessing up about it (I worked in a coffee shop where the quiche was often tiny and I felt really bad), but they gave me two pieces! I'm considering making the commute from Sheridan just to come here again and try their other coffees. (Also, fun fact, they have my exact same address number. It's fate.)

36.description: Thank you Jennifer Greenburg and Melissa Sands for recommending this spot!The cold brewed Kyoto style coffee is wonderful. Plenty of seating. We joined the coffee club.

14.description: I liked this shop, even before the expansion, because of the great coffee and the ample seating. After 7 years, I find myself struggling to continue to make it part of my regular routine, since exchanges with staff can definitely be enough to make you want to take your $6 coffee to go and forget you ever went in.Pros:Really great quality coffees and teasExcellent variety and selection of beveragesSpacious and conveniently arranged seatingCons: Shockingly pushy and rude men at the front of the house (It's every Monday now and it's a real bummer.)Pricey

58.description: Best. Dessert. Ever. Seriously. EVER!In fact, I can't even go here anymore. It's just not safe for my diet. And they've actually managed to ruin dessert anyplace else. It's just  a bitter disappointment when I order from another restaurant and I get a huge plate with a tiny slice of store-bought cheesecake. Everything at Taste is freshly prepared and delicious, the portions are huge, and the service is friendly.The cheesecake is truly heavenly, and you get a slab of it  - A FREAKIN' SLAB!!!

56.description: I went here for brunch since I haven't been back for a long while. This restaurant is not that big but a good enough size to eat at. I like their food and order a quiche which is so good accompanied a side salad. The waitstaff is attentive coming back from time to time to make sure we have everything we need. The service was great so I will come back here when I am in the neighborhood and I love this neighborhood.

29.description: I'm not usually one for sweet breakfasts but so happy I tried the coconut almond cakes! They were incredibly flavorful and came with banana slices and fresh whipped cream. Iced coffee refills were free and much appreciated during the hot morning. There was somewhat of a wait for the food but not appalling my any means. With the intriguing items on the menu, I will definitely come by for breakfast again.

42.description: Im here! I came to brunch with my family and people did not treat us right! Food are "whatever, nothing amazing"...

23.description: Not that great.Service was sloe even tho there weren't many customers. The food is WAY over priced. I think I paid almost 11 dollars for plain pancakes. Won't be back most likely.

47.description: One of the best diners in the city. Every meal I've had has been wonderful and the sweets are excellent. I'm always so full after the meal (read: great, big portions) that I have to get a sweet to go. Service has always been good. If we ever have friends or family visiting, this is where we take them for breakfast or lunch (or-if it was up to me-both). Try the hot chocolate- tastes like liquid gold. Check it out- you might see me there.

8.description: Simply delicious food! The atmosphere is cute and small and diner-like, but with a lot of cupcakes. It's great for sitting and hanging out, and the owner and servers are really nice, quick, and chill.I tried the roasted pear salad and iced coffee (both recommended from the server). The salad was awesome--big and filling, with crispy roasted chicken, delicious roasted pears, and goat cheese and cherries to keep things interesting. Salad dressing came on the side (which was thoughtful). The iced coffee was big, delicious, and FREE because it was a Wednesday! What a pleasant surprise!The prices seem high ($12 for the salad) but the quality of food was well worth it. Definitely check it out if you're in the area!

31.description: I had the steel cut oatmeal with peach compote. Who knew oatmeal could be so delicious! It was very filling as well. Everyone's dishes looked so good and hearty. It was a clean restaurant and our waitress was very friendly. I hope I can come back and taste the chicken and biscuit breakfast.

34.description: What a great find! I've walked past this place at least 100 times and have to say I should have ventured in sooner! No wait on a Sunday at brunch time and the biscuits and whipped cream was the best I've had in so long if not ever. This gem is well worth traveling halfway across the city for breakfast.

16.description: What a great breakfast! Great coffee and tea (although way too pricey for such beverages!). I had the Mike's Pesto Sandwich and it was amazing. Egg, tomato, spinach, bacon and pesto! Yum! The folks with me had the quiche and the omelet of the day. Once again, great portions, generous ingredients and fantastic flavors. We could've gone for less of the sides and a lower price, though. Very friendly service! And scrumptious looking baked goods and cupcakes if you're looking for something on the go!

13.description: Overall: Great little cafe with delicious eats and friendly service.The good: Great bakery treats to choose from with specialty cupcakes, cakes, brownies, etc. All were great. Good coffee and plenty of other options. Service was friendly and attentive. A good amount of seating. Cute decor.The bad: Not much!Atmosphere: 9/10Service: 9/10Food: 9/10

11.description: Everything is, was, and always will be the culinary equivalent of having your taste buds pass through them pearly gates.  As a customer you are paying for quality and ATOH delivers.  All of their desserts seem like a winners at least in the taste department if not caloric.  It's like stepping into a dessert brothel, there's a little something for everyone.  We chose the cream puff because we always choose the cream puff.  Wow!  I'll leave it at that.  I had this thanksgiving wrap which was as advertised minus mashed potatoes.  Solid.  The food is top notch but for three folks it'll be over sixty after tipping.  Support local businesses like this one owned by Dan, a swell guy who actually cares about his customers.

39.description: Get the coconut almond pancakes, you will NOT regret it! They are super generous with the whipped cream. Also: the cornmeal biscuits are AWESOME.

37.description: Great breakfast. I had the chorizo skillet - so tasty.  My boyfriend had the Carmel pancakes- sugary treat. Friendly staff. If you haven't tried this place give it a try.

0.description: I used to live down the street from Taste Of Heaven and would always stop in for dessert on the weekends but never ate an actual meal here. I finally did this past weekend after 7 years. Their menu isn't large but I wouldn't expect it to be for sure a small place. It's cozy and smells great inside. I ordered the Thanksgiving dinner Wrap. It was unbelievable! They brought the wrong dressing for my side salad but it was still good. As for their dessert, you can't go wrong. Their cakes are made in house and are sooooo good! Get something to go even if you aren't hungry. Downside was there was only one bathroom tucked away in the back for both genders. I waited about 15 minutes to use the bathroom.

38.description: Lovely meal that's perfect for a quick bite with a friend. Overall the service was nothing remarkable - the waitress checked in once or twice but we waited a bit to get our check. Water flowed quickly and often. I ordered the quiche and was satisfied. The quiche of the day was steak and cheese. The portion was generous and the side salad was fresh. The crust was light and flaky and had a hint of sweetness that complimented the salted egg and steak filling. The pie top wasn't as crunchy or chewy as I would've liked but still was nice!

51.description: We came across this place by accident one Sunday. Our original plan was to go to Big Jones but the wait time was almost two hours. Upon arrival, we were seated at the corner near the cupcake display. The place is some what small and very crowded. My boyfriend ordered some sandwich with peaches, it was okay. I had the steak and eggs, the steak was cooked medium like how I like it. I could only eat a couple of bites, it was too heavy for my taste. When we received our bill I'm was surprised at how much this breakfast had cost. For a sandwich, steak and eggs, coffee and tea $42 definitely was not worth our money. I'm not sure what the hype is all about maybe people haven't had real good breakfast. Nothing was special about this breakfast, glad I tried it. I would probably not come back. Overpriced.

27.description: I pass this place all the time and decided to check it out on a whim. I have a sweet tooth and this place was exactly what I needed. I tried the Oreo ice cream and oatmeal, cherry, white chocolate cookie. The ice cream was silky and just the right amout of sugar. I orded the cookie  because it had the three things I like the most in cookies. The cookie did not disappoint. Sweet from the white chocolate and little tart from the cherries. Perfect cookie.

32.description: The food was good the service was good neither great but all in all a good experience. I would definitely go here again. I would, however have to say that their banana pound cake was amazing, so 5 stars on that. Oh, and they never rushed us out the door, so my friends and I were able to catch up for 2.5 hours.

54.description: Breakfast all day is always a key to my heart. But breakfast all day AND PASTRY? That will get me every time. (Note: it will look just like a pastry shop when you walk in. The boards will say nothing about food, just pastry. But if you say you want to dine in, they will give you table service and a menu of delights. The best thing we tried was, surprisingly, the almond and coconut pancakes. Actual coconut. Actual homemade whipped cream. They were amazing. The grilled cheese sandwich was also great - lots of flavors and fresh bread. The roasted potatoes had almost no flavor, so skip those in favor of another side. For dessert we tried the cream puff with whipped cream (heavenly) and the moon pie cupcake (very good). I will admit, these cupcakes didn't stack up to Molly's or Sugar Bliss for me. They had just a little less flavor and creativity. But for a meal AND a cupcake, I was quite impressed.

48.description: Just love it here! Every single thing I've ever tried has been delicious, from their coffee to their entrees to their desserts....heaven.The servers are always very friendly and we've never had a problem being seated.We like to stop in here for brunch and we always get coffee(me-fancy coffee, him-straight black). I usually order the quiche because it's so good, but I have gotten their Durbin sandwich before, too. Both were so good. The quiche is my to-go-to though because they are such a pain in the ass to make yourself and they always get the texture right. They are always light and fluffy. My husband usually goes for something a bit more hearty. The last time he got a portobello sandwich which was really good. I never can leave without getting a cupcake, which I have a love/hate relationship with. Love, because they are so good. Hate because then I have to go to the gym later. It's worth it.

44.description: I had just moved into the neighborhood, and my sister decided to take me to brunch here. The restaurant decor is very eclectic, and gives it a "Grandma's house" vibe. Not to say this is a bad thing, because it is quite endearing. We both ordered the Mike's Pesto Sandwich, which will go down in history as one of the best breakfast sandwiches I have had. Our waitress was friendly, but towards the end seemed to be losing steam. Since I am a server, I understand. She didn't close out our check, but one of her colleagues did instead. Overall a very positive experience here.

24.description: What a great breakfast! Great coffee and tea (although way too pricey for such beverages!). I had the Mike's Pesto Sandwich and it was amazing. Egg, tomato, spinach, bacon and pesto! Yum! The folks with me had the quiche and the omelet of the day. Once again, great portions, generous ingredients and fantastic flavors. We could've gone for less of the sides and a lower price, though. Very friendly service! And scrumptious looking baked goods and cupcakes if you're looking for something on the go!

7.description: Dan's customer service (the owner) was incredible - upon reading my first review, he immediately contacted me to make my experience at Taste of Heaven right. He sympathized with wasting money and calories at a restaurant only to be disappointed and invited me to come back and give Taste another chance with a guest. I appreciated how FAST and KIND he was when responding to my concerns. GREAT CUSTOMER SERVICE!  I was not disappointed during my return visit! Mike's pesto sandwich is hands-down one of the best breakfast sandwiches in Chicago. The thick cut, slightly sweet brioche is perfectly toasted and complemented by a mountain of goat cheese, pesto, tomato, bacon, spinach and 2 eggs. It is definitely big enough to be shared (or hoarded for second brunch later in the day)! It comes with a side of fresh fruit and potatoes. I also tried the sparkling lemonade - served in a big mason jar and not too sour or sweet, with the right amount of fizz. Perfect for a warm day! The place gets crowded during the weekend, but they also have a pretty big patio area on the southeast side of the restaurant to accommodate more patrons. It's nicely shaded and worth checking out!

49.description: I thought the food was decent.  My wife did not like her food at all.  She thought it was way too heavy.  Three stars from me and one star from my wife.  Therefore, two stars.

40.description: Simply delicious food! The atmosphere is cute and small and diner-like, but with a lot of cupcakes. It's great for sitting and hanging out, and the owner and servers are really nice, quick, and chill.I tried the roasted pear salad and iced coffee (both recommended from the server). The salad was awesome--big and filling, with crispy roasted chicken, delicious roasted pears, and goat cheese and cherries to keep things interesting. Salad dressing came on the side (which was thoughtful). The iced coffee was big, delicious, and FREE because it was a Wednesday! What a pleasant surprise!The prices seem high ($12 for the salad) but the quality of food was well worth it. Definitely check it out if you're in the area!

53.description: I have been wanting to try out this place for a while now and I finally did. We came on a Sunday around 1:30 and didn't have a problem getting a seat. The place is pretty small, but has a lot of homemade goods from cupcakes to cakes and bars, etc...My husband got the Steak and Eggs and I tried the Havar Ya Sandwich with a side of soup. The steak and eggs were ok and the potatoes were tasty, nice and crispy on the outside and soft on the inside. My sandwich was okay as well. The homemade baguette bread was good and held the sandwich quite well. But it was kinda dry and perhaps could use some sauce to make it tastier. Service was also okay. Overall, this place is okay.

30.description: MMM- Been here 2x now and really impressed. Both times were for brunch. Great dog friendly patio, service is good and the staff is really friendly. The food is so fresh and tasty. I'm looking forward to trying lunch and dinner.

46.description: Great treasure of good food and coffee plus amazing deserts. Very cozy and warm environment with a twist of hip. Great place to meet a friend. Expect to wait for a table for weekend brunch times...but not very long.

1.description: Stopped here for after dinner desert last Sunday evening.    What is better then coffee and cupcakes?   About a dozen tables.   Very comfortable atmosphere.   The coffee was good.   The cupcakes were great.   They had a big selection, so we ordered 4 different types.   My favorite was the malted milk ball.   It was really yummy.   Next was the salted chocolate.   Pretty good.    Third was the key-lime.   Outstanding.   Fourth was a triple chocolate.   Not bad at all.  Cupcakes and coffee.... This place slam dunked it.  They have a full menu, so I'd like to go back.

55.description: Oh my goodness the Jeanine cake....just get the Jeanine cake! I think for the last (at least) 5 years I've requested a slice of the Jeanine cake here for my birthday and it never disappoints! And you can easily share one piece with several people because they're huge.Honestly there hasn't been anything from here that we haven't liked - they always have a good selection of cupcakes and they're ALL delicious. Can't say we've ever had anything else but sweets from here but who needs food when you can have cake?

9.description: Seriously amazing chocolate chip scone! Great Americano! Wonderful service with a smile! Wish I lived close by!

26.description: Biscuits and gravy are to die for.  Plenty of love from this place. Must go to in Chicago

25.description: Still the best breakfast place in Andersonville. Get the skillet. Or better yet an omelet w/caramelized onions, ham, asparagus and goat cheese. I was sad it ended. Can't wait to come back on our next visit!

12.description: This place strikes a difficult balance between being a popular brunch destination and a small community oriented place to get coffee and home style food.  Yes, if you come here for brunch at peak brunch time, be prepared to suffer all the inconveniences that come with getting brunch at peak time. This place is casual enough you can eat here alone with a book and sit with coffee afterwards.

59.description: Insanely good food in a simple, cozy cafe. Everything is fresh and homemade.. including their roasted turkey in their sandwiches...and their bread.  It's a must try.  I know we will be back!! Have had the egg, pesto, &bacon sandwich, the turkey , pear & havarti sandwich, great salad with homemade dressing,  and the to die for German Chocolate Cake!!

21.description: Love this place!! Have been here more than several times and I enjoy everyone one them. They have the best stuffed cupcakes which I get everytime I go! Their biscuits and gravy is amazing but, honestly so is everything else on the menu

17.description: I had just moved into the neighborhood, and my sister decided to take me to brunch here. The restaurant decor is very eclectic, and gives it a "Grandma's house" vibe. Not to say this is a bad thing, because it is quite endearing. We both ordered the Mike's Pesto Sandwich, which will go down in history as one of the best breakfast sandwiches I have had. Our waitress was friendly, but towards the end seemed to be losing steam. Since I am a server, I understand. She didn't close out our check, but one of her colleagues did instead. Overall a very positive experience here.

10.description: My mother worked here years ago they've changed a lot of stuff sense but the food is still top notch.

5.description: Plentiful of ridiculously delicious sounding Daily Specials.  Price is relative to food portion, ingredients, quality and preparation.FRENCH ONION SOUP ($3.75) -- comes with 3 pcs of housemade bread. Delicioso. Good balance of ingredients.  Broth is NOT dark brown. Yay!QUICHE ($10.75) -- a risky custard combination of ham and pineapple. Hawaiian pizza in a pie. Skip it! Soggy crust. Comes with default mixed green salad with vinaigrette.LEMONADE ($4.75) -- expensive with an impressive strong lemon flavor that is not sour.ELVIS CUPCAKE -- peanut butter icing was a tad sweet with banana cake. A version of Elvis' favorite food.COFFEE -- La Colombe brand.SERVICE -- excellent, well-informed, friendly, charming.VENUE -- the relax atmosphere of a cafe.  Lots of stuff that is neatly organized. Comfy. Welcoming.1-star less:- presence of housefly- box your own brown bag

3.description: One of my family's favorite places for breakfast. They are usually crowded and its difficult to get a table. Parking is notoriously bad in Andersonville, so be aware. The food is great though! The last time I was there we split the bacon, egg, and pesto sandwich, and the caramel apple french toast which had a mound of whipped cream. It was really sweet, but so good. Even with a half portion it was too much, so I would definitely share with the table next time!

35.description: Plentiful of ridiculously delicious sounding Daily Specials.  Price is relative to food portion, ingredients, quality and preparation.FRENCH ONION SOUP ($3.75) -- comes with 3 pcs of housemade bread. Delicioso. Good balance of ingredients.  Broth is NOT dark brown. Yay!QUICHE ($10.75) -- a risky custard combination of ham and pineapple. Hawaiian pizza in a pie. Skip it! Soggy crust. Comes with default mixed green salad with vinaigrette.LEMONADE ($4.75) -- expensive with an impressive strong lemon flavor that is not sour.ELVIS CUPCAKE -- peanut butter icing was a tad sweet with banana cake. A version of Elvis' favorite food.COFFEE -- La Colombe brand.SERVICE -- excellent, well-informed, friendly, charming.VENUE -- the relax atmosphere of a cafe.  Lots of stuff that is neatly organized. Comfy. Welcoming.1-star less:- presence of housefly- box your own brown bag

19.description: I have been wanting to try out this place for a while now and I finally did. We came on a Sunday around 1:30 and didn't have a problem getting a seat. The place is pretty small, but has a lot of homemade goods from cupcakes to cakes and bars, etc...My husband got the Steak and Eggs and I tried the Havar Ya Sandwich with a side of soup. The steak and eggs were ok and the potatoes were tasty, nice and crispy on the outside and soft on the inside. My sandwich was okay as well. The homemade baguette bread was good and held the sandwich quite well. But it was kinda dry and perhaps could use some sauce to make it tastier. Service was also okay. Overall, this place is okay.

28.description: Three things:Space. Service. Food.Space Inside: I live a block away from here, but seldomly go because it's always crowded. Also, it's really small and tight; elbow to elbow. So I always eat outside.Space Outside: barley comfortable metallic chairs and unsteady tables makes the experience a bit off-putting.Service:The staff is really nice, but, often, they look stressed out, always seems like they're trying to comfort the people there without much success.Food:Delightful. Delicious. Well prepared. It's literally the only reason I like this place. If the aforementioned problems weren't there, this would be a 5-star joint. If you're in the area and it's not crowded, I'd say try the food. You won't regret it.

45.description: First experience at Taste of Heaven was disappointing. I had a Niçoise salad that was just not fresh. A throw together of pre-prepped items that had been in the walk-in several days too long, all tossed in a tarragon dressing that was supposed to be creamy, but which, extraordinarily, was dry. I ate about half of it and got a candy bar and protein shake on the way home. My husband's basic bacon and eggs breakfast was quite good, so he liked the place. On the whole, the ambience is good and I rate the service okay even though our meals were pretty slow coming out (probably took a while to find the salad makings in the back of the cooler ). I might go back if in the immediate area, but definitely would not order a salad there.

33.description: Poor service. Waited an hour for food. And waiter never refilled water until he gave the check. Waiter also didn't come by to ask how we were doing or how the food was.

43.description: Overall: Great little cafe with delicious eats and friendly service.The good: Great bakery treats to choose from with specialty cupcakes, cakes, brownies, etc. All were great. Good coffee and plenty of other options. Service was friendly and attentive. A good amount of seating. Cute decor.The bad: Not much!Atmosphere: 9/10Service: 9/10Food: 9/10

2.description: Found this gem under breakfast and brunch spots. It's a very cozy place that serves delicious foods. I ordered the almond pancakes and it definitely fulfilled all my sweet needs. What I enjoyed most about the pancakes was that it wasn't overly sweet. I think a lot of places have flavorless pancakes and depend on the syrup to drown out the flavor. However I didn't even use additional syrup on my pancakes. After ordering the pancakes I did regret not getting something more savory. I drooled with each dish that came out as the servers delivered it to surrounding tables. I already decided I would be back to try their pesto sandwich. There are also a plethora of breads, muffins, and cupcakes one could hope for. They web have a counter where you can order coffee and a muffin to go. I highly recommend taste of heaven. Although the name is a bit corny, it does deliver.

18.description: Just love it here! Every single thing I've ever tried has been delicious, from their coffee to their entrees to their desserts....heaven.The servers are always very friendly and we've never had a problem being seated.We like to stop in here for brunch and we always get coffee(me-fancy coffee, him-straight black). I usually order the quiche because it's so good, but I have gotten their Durbin sandwich before, too. Both were so good. The quiche is my to-go-to though because they are such a pain in the ass to make yourself and they always get the texture right. They are always light and fluffy. My husband usually goes for something a bit more hearty. The last time he got a portobello sandwich which was really good. I never can leave without getting a cupcake, which I have a love/hate relationship with. Love, because they are so good. Hate because then I have to go to the gym later. It's worth it.

41.description: Dan's customer service (the owner) was incredible - upon reading my first review, he immediately contacted me to make my experience at Taste of Heaven right. He sympathized with wasting money and calories at a restaurant only to be disappointed and invited me to come back and give Taste another chance with a guest. I appreciated how FAST and KIND he was when responding to my concerns. GREAT CUSTOMER SERVICE!  I was not disappointed during my return visit! Mike's pesto sandwich is hands-down one of the best breakfast sandwiches in Chicago. The thick cut, slightly sweet brioche is perfectly toasted and complemented by a mountain of goat cheese, pesto, tomato, bacon, spinach and 2 eggs. It is definitely big enough to be shared (or hoarded for second brunch later in the day)! It comes with a side of fresh fruit and potatoes. I also tried the sparkling lemonade - served in a big mason jar and not too sour or sweet, with the right amount of fizz. Perfect for a warm day! The place gets crowded during the weekend, but they also have a pretty big patio area on the southeast side of the restaurant to accommodate more patrons. It's nicely shaded and worth checking out!

52.description: My favorite brunch spot with my girlfriend. Omlettes are amazing and always get a side of the brioche bread. Very friendly staff!

50.description: I guess it all depends on your perception of "heaven" - but there is something quite  heavenly about this place. Excellent service, great food, tea and coffee and I have NEVER had to wait for a table! EVER! Its always busy, especially on the weekend but never seems to be a wait.

4.description: I came in after stopping at the stop light intersection and seeing lots of sweets inside the store. So like a true foodie, I found a parking spot and decided to explore what they had to offer. A Taste of Heaven is actually a restaurant (cafe style) that has a variety of options for sweets. The owner happened to be behind the register and was very sweet. I was craving something creamy and I love whipped cream. When I saw the piece of Chocolate Whipped Cream cake, I knew I couldn't leave without a piece. He said that it was his best cake so I was sold :) The piece of cake was $5.95 and is a good healthy portion that lasted me two days lol. The chocolate layers were not overly sweet - kind of reminded me of German chocolate cake. The whipped cream layers were heavenly and the frosting is nice and sweet for those who like their desserts a little sweeter. I can see why this place has such high ratings and I can't wait to come back and try more!

6.description: While doing some city shopping this weekend, my friends and I were looking for a quick brunch spot and A Taste of Heaven was our first option. With only a 10 minute wait, we decided to stick with it!The place is TINY, that is for sure. There are maybe 15 tables in the whole storefront and tables are packed in. It also didn't help that the thermostat was showing 84 degrees. During our wait, I asked if they had mimosas which they didn't but the waiter pointed to a "liquor store" across the street that I would get champagne to bring in. I was able to take a quick trip for some champagne and come back when the table was ready. The wait staff was super friendly but seemed a little disjointed. It took a while to get some OJ but everything seemed pretty smooth after that. The portions are huge, and the prices are pretty reasonable. I ordered Mike's Pesto Egg Sandwich which was incredible! If I'm in the neighborhood, I would definitely come back from some brunch and mimosas!

22.description: $3.50 for a cup of coffee? Is there gold in it, seriously? Also, got the corned beef hash and felt like crap afterwards; it that was around $13! Overpriced, mediocre; however, I would like to try their grilled cheese: it has three cheeses and I'm a fan of that.

15.description: I stopped by this place just for desert on the go. I bought a big peanut butter cookie a bit pricey $4! But I must say it was really good it lasted a few days. They offer breakfast and lunch as well including baked goods. Overall ok spot for a snack on the go.

57.description: I love their breakfast menu.. Everything made so delicious and fresh.. Workers are so sweet and helpful. They have the best cup cakes ever... They make everything from scratch.. I would recommend to anyone this wonderful place ..

20.description: Taste of Heaven is exactly that. The food is exceptional. I don't understand how the owner can possibly remain thin! It's one of my destination spots when I have out of town guests. I'm generally not a cake eater but all of their cakes are divine. These are seriously solid cakes. The best I've had. I've been a customer since they were located on Foster Ave.

36.description: This place is a hidden gem. Good service, good food, great location and the best lemonade in Chicago.

14.description: One of my favorite places in the neighborhood.  Brunch, lunch or coffee with friends it is small and cozy.  I typically go in between busy times so it's not too crowded or loud.  Nothing on the menu has been disappointing, but I tend to gravitate towards the quiche of the day or the lemon butter bars!

58.description: This is a fantastic asian grocery store.  It is bright, extremely clean, and remarkably well organized.  Every item is perfectly faced and stocked in a tidy manner.  If every person, company, city and government ran their operations as well as the owners of Golden Pacific Market, the world would be a wonderful place -- and this is not an exaggeration.GPM has almost the full selection of the full-on asian grocery stores on Argyle, but like everyone has said here, it doesn't have the smells and questionable sanitation of the the Argyle stores.  It doesn't have those crazy live crabs, like the places on argyle, but that's about it.  From panko crumbs to basil to fresh rice and egg noodles to whole fresh shrimp to frozen eels and frogs, this place is well stocked. One note -- it is amazing how cheap the fresh basil is at this store, and any other asian store, for that matter.  You go to Dominics, and they have some bogus little "gourmet" plastic case of basil at $4 for a few sprigs -- what a rip-off!  I suspect that as more people start discovering basil at literally 1/15th the price at the asian stores, Dominics will eventually have to lower their price.  Also amazing -- the prices on sesame seed oil.Another note -- most people like to live in places like Chicago, New York, San Fransisco, etc, because of the streets like Argyle, and those sorts of interesting grocery stores that you can't find in say, Des Moines or Schaumburg.  We don't want the crust cut off our bread -- in fact, the crust is the best part!  Golden Pacific Market is not as crusty as the places on Argyle, but it's still 100% authentic -- and they've got parking!  So all in all, it's a 5!

56.description: Wow, this is a great Asian market.  Now although my heart belongs to Chicago Food Corp. (I'm Korean so CFC is geared towards Korean food), this Golden Pacific Market is terrific for other Asian cuisines.  Whenever I make Thai, Japanese, Chinese, or Vietnamese foods , Golden Pacific is my market of choice.  This store is pretty clean, neat, and user-friendly.  The people who work there are so nice and knowledgeable.  If you even tell them what you want to make, they will tell you the ingredients you need.  However, they often push the sauces (bulgogi sauce, pad thai sauce, etc.) but I would not recommend these all-in-one sauces because they don't taste authentic and are not that good.  They have a decent array of produce and fruit, a place where you can purchase fish in back, and a lot of items in the frozen section.  You can even purchase your green/jasmine teas or even little Asian tchotchkes for a housewarming gift.The best thing?  If you can't find what you need, tell someone who works there and they can order it for you and stock it for your future shopping needs.  Also, they have a nice big parking lot in back and a little one in front.  Oh yeah, very reasonably priced, too.

29.description: I keep forgetting what a gem this place is. It's neat and clean, and the staff could not be more helpful.Fresh fish, seaweed salad ready to eat, great variety of powdered Miso soup, tea, noodles, eel, weird drinks. Fascinating.And they have DURIAN. I'm still not brave enough, but one day . . . one day. Maybe I'll start with the Durian sorbet.

42.description: I was definitely expecting much better, and much worse all at once from the reviews on Yelp. I kept my eyes peeled for the notorious faux expiration dates some reviewers mentioned, and was ready to be blown away by selection.I saw neither forged expiration dates nor a mind-blowing selection. Chicago Food Corp on Kimball is much bigger and that's still not the massive Asian mart I'm accustomed too. I'm more used to Asian marts that are sized comprarbly to a Jewel/Dominicks/Whole Foods... you know an actual supermarket... that this sized store seems like a neighborhood grocer.The thing about this place that was great is that they stock the produce that you will never in your life find at an average American supermarket like green papaya, fresh bamboo shoots, young coconut, holy basil, or the myriad of herbs/spices that have yet to be given an English counterpart.The packaged food is dominantly Thai foods with a lot of Japanese, Korean, and Chinese thrown in but because of that, there are some items they really only carry a couple of brands of like dried seaweed. For seaweed, they only had the seasoned Japanese kind, sushi kind, and some dried soup variety. I prefer toasted seaweed that's oiled and salted, and they only had the overpriced individual package for kids snacks. I really hate the kind with soy/msg seasonings in tons of wrapping.The frozen department was really lacking. They had gyoza and a bunch of potstickers. Unfortunately, their potstickers were mostly pork and chicken blends.There was a couple of beef types and veggie types, but none of them were stellar. All of them seemed to be the kind with lots of MSG, artificial flavors, and preservatives with no real variation in dough. I like potstickers with a thicker dough with only 5 or 6 ingredients (and no MSG).Frozen meats and seafood on the other hand... what didn't they stock? Obviously, it's better to get it fresh, but there are some cuts and species you won't find anywhere or unless you take a trip to a specialty market.Conclusion:All in all, this is not my one-stop Asian grocer, but it's definitely my stop before/after a trip for stuff I'll never find at the Jewel only a block away.

23.description: I have been going here for a while, and it is reliable, well-organized. I have had problems with other Asian markets in the area communicating my needs to employees, whereas at Golden, I have no problems. I especially like the cheap, pre-packaged chicken bones and galangal (galanga), which are both hard to find.

47.description: Love this place!They organize the store pretty well.  And they do have various choices of foods/ snacks to choose from.  Near by the El and 36 is a plus!

8.description: Every time I see the guy who runs the place, he greets me like we're old friends. I've only been there maybe a dozen times at most, but he makes me feel like I'm his favorite customer. Last time in, I took advantage of a posted deal where you buy 3 packages of frozen spring rolls and get a free dipping sauce. The boss gave me what he called a "better" sauce than the one advertised, in addition to making it known that this particular promotion had ended but he'd honor it nonetheless. Well played, sir.This is my go-to spot for kamaboko, somen noodles, fresh rice noodles, shrimp-flavored chips, Thai chilies, Thai basil, and any other Asian ingredients or products. I don't even know what half the stuff is, but if you want it, they probably have it.The cashier is friendly, there's no language barrier, and prices seem reasonable. My only real gripe is the weird, fishy smell permeating the store. It's hard to ignore, but I guess it comes with the territory. Parking lot is cramped but accessible. All in all, a great small business I'm happy to patronize.

31.description: I've been going here for a while now and I just lovee this store. The owner is really nice which is a big plus.  He would give us free stuff every now and then (yesterday he gave my sister and I 2 small snack items for free!).  The aisles are wide and organized, the place is clean, my sister can get all the seasoning&spices she needs without having to pay $4 per spice...AND they have Indonesian snacks (among other things)!!  Will def keep coming.

34.description: I wrote a review 5 years ago on Citysearch.  I almost can't believe it was that long ago, and I still stand by my 5 star review.SUPER CLEAN, affordable, and friendly service. It is a great market for your basics in Oriental cooking. They have a great selection of everything. I especially like the various sauces, noodles, imported drinks, candies, snacks, and produce (baby bokchoy and chinese broccoli!! YUM!). This is also the perfect place to introduce a friend to Oriental cooking without worrying about them being turned off by strong odors or cluttered aisles. The only thing I would caution is low turnover on SOME of their products. I've come across this problem twice in five years. They carry so many hard-to-find products it's bound to happen.  Even though I need to pay some extra attention to this, it pales in comparison to the great finds, service, and prices I have gotten over the years.  I absolutely love the staff because they are so helpful.  It's obvious they know food when they guess what I'm cooking by what is in my cart.  They have a small parking right in front. (Yay!) If you are a loyal customer, they give you new products to try for free! (Another Yay!)

16.description: My 2-year-old and I made a trip to Golden Pacific on a cold rainy Wednesday, because my pregnant self is craving sushi and decided to give it a shot on my own, knowing my own will be cooked and safe to eat.  Mind you, I have no idea how to make Japanese food.  So I did a little net research, found a recipe I wanted to try, and decided to check out Golden Pacific, since it's relatively close to my house. I was so pleasantly surpised by how clean the place is, and how friendly and helpful the staff is. While my daughter proclaimed the place "stinky" upon entrance, making the employees giggle (and it does have an unfamiliar, pungent scent by the door/produce, I was not dissuaded. Within 30 seconds, an employee asked if I needed help, and I told him my plans to try sushi at home, and the fact I have no clue what I'm doing. He took me aisle by aisle showing me products and handing me stuff I asked for, since I had no idea what most of what I was asking for would look like.  And there was no pressure to buy more/upsell anything. In fact, the employee was apologetic b/c the store was out of one type of rice seasoning (keeping in mind there were 6 or 8 others on the shelf).So I have no idea how my sushi is going to turn out, but if I get good at this stuff, I'll be back to Golden Pacific for more ingredients and super friendly servce.

13.description: I've finally found my new, go to, Asian grocery store.  I'm so glad I found this place thanks to all the great Yelp reviews.  I called ahead to ask if they carried Thai chili flakes.  I've been having a hard time finding some as good as I purchased in Thailand.  The clerk was very nice on the phone.  When I went to the store that evening, he remembered my phone call and showed me all the different varieties.  He asked me what I wanted to make, and I said papaya salad.  He grabbed all the ingredients for me since I didn't have a recipe in hand.  He even suggested ingredients you normally don't find on Western friendly, recipe sites, like fermented, raw fish, rice paddy crabs and dried, little shrimp.The parking lot fits 8 cars uncomfortably.  I know if the lot was full, I'm not a good enough driver to pull in or out without a minor mishap.  The grocery carts are teenie, tiny.  Mine was overflowing in 15 minutes of browsing.  The prices are similar to the other Asian grocery stores in Vietnamese town, but the products here are neatly arranged, there is enough variety without being confusing, and there isn't that Asian grocery store smell of things being a little bit too fresh, fishy or just plain pungent. The best part of the store is the super helpful gentleman who is happy to have your papaya shredded for you, answer all your question, and generally make you feel welcome.  Customer service means more when you don't know what you're looking for.

11.description: I keep forgetting what a gem this place is. It's neat and clean, and the staff could not be more helpful.Fresh fish, seaweed salad ready to eat, great variety of powdered Miso soup, tea, noodles, eel, weird drinks. Fascinating.And they have DURIAN. I'm still not brave enough, but one day . . . one day. Maybe I'll start with the Durian sorbet.

39.description: Nice place, and not nearly as crowded as the places on Argyle.  I have been coming here weekly (at least) for about two years...BUT...........Today they just lost my business for good!On a whim, I stopped in for some snack food and picked up a bag of veggie chips (Aji "Fabulous").  Every bag on the shelf was marked $1.95. The register scanned at $2.49. I confronted the cashier (a young girl, not the usual guy who always checks me out), and asked me to pay first, signaling that she'd get the manager.  While I waited, the manager discussed it with the cashier, went back to the shelf for a while, looked at the bags some more, scratched the price tags with her fingernail, scanned the item again, looked at me and said confidently "it's $2.49"  I explained that they have to charge what it is marked... wheat they ALL are marked.  She just stated that the price tag is wrong, it's $2.49.  And proceeded to just stare at me.  I looked around for my usual cashier (who has always been very helpful - including finding specific items many times over), but he was not around.  Finally, the manager asked "You don't want?".  I just took it anyway, figuring that it is "only $.50" -- but what really upsets me is the principle of the thing, and the sad part is that if this part is that for a mere $.50, any business should not hesitate to fix things for the customer.  Not here -- I am completely appalled and offended that this woman basically made me feel like I was wrong!Sorry, you lost my business -- from now on I wait in line on Argyle.

37.description: I just went to this place a couple of nights ago and this place is great. The staff is very friendly and try to go out of their way to help you out. Anything you want, you can find it here and the prices and amazing. Had a sushi party at my house, Had all the ingredients (Sushi grade Tuna, Salmon, Yellow tail and Shrimp to tempura) from the local fish market. I wanted to step a bit outside of the norm and try some eel, but I was unable to get it anywhere... Well, this was the only place in my side of the town that i was able to get Unagi.

0.description: Golden Pacific exemplifies exceptional customer service. Their employees are always so helpful and go out of their way for their customers. During our last visit here we saw they started carrying Maggi noodles. We had to travel to Milwaukee for these before so I'm sure you can understand our elation. As we were filling our basket with Maggi Tom Yam we saw there was a label for Maggi Kari as well, and we were searching on the shelf for it. While we were doing this one of the employees asked us what we were looking for, so we let him know and he scoured the store to see if they still had any boxes from their recent shipment. Unfortunately they did not, so he let us know their next shipment date. We asked if they carry Heng's Udang Ranggup. He had me spell it for him and he texted one of his other staff asking about it. He then took down hubby's number and told us he would order it and call us when it is in. Are you kidding me?! I was floored by his exceptional kindness and exemplary customer service! When he saw our Madison area code he chatted us up about a lot of Indonesians he meets who make the journey to Golden Pacific from Madison to pick up items unobtainable elsewhere. I am kicking myself for not getting his name, it deserves to be known. When he calls we will get it and be sure to update this review.

38.description: OMG, I love this place. My friends and I sometimes like to be foodies and cook asian food - and have the fun is getting to shop here. They have anything you could want to find (granted, you may need to speak japanese/thai/etc in order to figure out what exactly you're buying). The tofu is local, good and cheap. If you're veg, they have fake meats you never dreamed of - abalone? for real?But the best part is the owner - this very sweet asian man who will start off helping you find something and end up giving you a tour of the store and menu recommendations. Seriously, he went through our cart last time, guessed what we were cooking and helped us find the remainig ingredients.It's fun, it's good food and it's a bargain.

51.description: Let me say first that I have refrained from reviewing Golden Pacific because I knew I would have gushed- before today.Today the sheen on Golden Pacific's plastic pagoda sign was gone for me. There was an audible pop when my heart broke, sort of like the one you hear when you press the button on the lid of a jar that has already been opened. This brings me to my next point. Where's the friggin' freshness?!This place has been spot-on for some time, so maybe I caught them on a bad day. After shopping here for many years, I feel let down lately, but overall a pretty average, well-stocked asian market 5 minutes from my house is nothing to bitch about. So I have to give them a pretty average review, with some major exceptions. I'll list all the stuff they carry that is fabulous, but first, know that it ain't cheap and it ain't getting any cheaper. Some stuff is not so fresh, but other stuff is amazingly fresh and very reasonably priced. I'm thinking of the asian greens-- fresh baby mustard greens, gai lan, long beans, seasonal melons, many types of eggplants, taiwanese, napa and savoy cabbages, green papayas, etc. for CHEAP.Oh, and their selection of tofu products is usually good (there's lots), packaged noodles (fresh & dry), and frozen meat analogues. The aburage's fresh from Phoenix Bean Products across the street. Then there's miso "fish," kungpao nonchicken, chickenless nuggets, and muttonless mutton chunks. All of the other fake meaties have whey or some other potentially beak-like byproduct in them, so I can't speak to those.Look, I don't care what you say Morningstar's pulled off this week, the Taiwanese have fake meats figured, and Golden Pacific's got it in spades. Expensive, but very good.However, that miso veg fish is out of control. Eight dollars, are you f*ing kidding?! It was $5.50 not a year ago. Oh wait, it might've been expired.

27.description: Tiny super market with questionable perishable selection

32.description: This place is a definite hidden gem. At first glance, it looks like a little hole in the wall Asian store but when you go in, you're greeted by a big, well lit, clean store, and a surprisingly helpful and cheerful owner.We came in and forgot our grocery list and had to leave and as we were leaving the owner cheerily told us to have a good day instead of giving us a cold or suspicious stare (which some smaller grocery stores of any ethnicity seem to do quite often). So that was a definite incentive to come back straight off the bat. We came back and probably spent about 45 minutes taking the place in and seeing what they had. It's not as big as Ti Nam but it's sizable and everything is very neatly arranged. Halfway through our browsing (and loading up on far more than we came there for) the owner came to check on us. I was pretty taken aback as my gf and I are tattooed and maybe a bit shady looking to the more conservative older set and usually when we're approached at that sort of place it's because someone thinks we're stealing or no-good-niks. But he was simply checking on us and we commented on his fresh produce which he seemed genuinely excited and flattered about.And as my Mandarin is still not that good, he helped us find some great snacks and even some amazing coffee (Super Power Coffee :9 ). Plus this place had a lot of obscure flavored sauces (like Mushroom Soy Sauce) and desserts.And for you meat eaters, the cuts of meat I saw were insanely good. Made me almost break my vegetarianism. This place has a tiny parking lot and some odd hours but believe me, we will definitely be back. I'd only recommend getting your noodles from Ti Nam since the noodle selection was not quite as large. But this place deserves a full five stars for just plain outstanding...ness. Frankly, I have never ever been treated so well at any type of grocery store ever. Especially not one with such cheap prices and delicious snacks. So go Golden Pacific. Woo.

54.description: Awesome grocery!!!!  What a treat to shop here. They have everything under the sun that's Asian. The candy and chips section is HUGE and fascinating -- great for children's party favors, too. They employees are nice and give personal service. It's so much cleaner than the other Asian markets on Broadway. They have cooking classes on Mondays, too.

48.description: If you are looking for the core Chinese, Thai, Japanese, Korean or Vietnamese ingredients, Golden Pacific is perfect.  I love to cook and wanted to tackle Chinese cuisine this Saturday after buying a Kylie Kwong cook book.  Golden Pacific had wide selection of the basics like Hoisin sauce, Shao Hsing Wine, Salted Black Beans, etc.  There wasn't a thing that the store did not have for the half-dozen recipes I chose.  In addition, Golden Pacific has a great frozen section of ingredients and prepared foods. Five different brands/types of wonton wrappers!  True, the vegetables weren't the freshest, but then this really isn't the forte of a small Asian grocer.  Finally, a very helpful staff, despite the small language barrier.  Pointing to the items in Kylie's cook book was the simplest way to show what I wanted!

44.description: Golden Pacific is a regular stop for me whenever I'm in the area.  As Mike C. pointed out they have THAI BROWN JASMINE RICE.  They explained to me at the store that in Thailand there is only one kind of brown rice grown, and that's jasmine brown rice.  Therefore if it says "Thai brown rice" on the label, it's Thai brown jasmine rice," which has got to be the best of all worlds of taste, health, and aroma.  They also have Thai red rice which I mix 1:1 with the brown jasmine and make it in my rice cooker with some chopped garlic.  I also get their fried tofu there, which I marinade and use in stir fries.  Also I get whole bags of dried chrysanthemum flowers there which we use to make tea.  For what I get the prices are good.  Also the store is well lit and a bouquet of roses compared to some other asian groceries I've visited in the area.  It us usually pretty empty so I hope they stay in business.  Everyone go to Golden Pacific!  They are just north of the Jewel.  I park in a meter spot next to Jewel, but a reviewer said they have more parking in back so I'll check it out.  Their Golden Pacific lot in front is just way too tiny.

24.description: I've finally found my new, go to, Asian grocery store.  I'm so glad I found this place thanks to all the great Yelp reviews.  I called ahead to ask if they carried Thai chili flakes.  I've been having a hard time finding some as good as I purchased in Thailand.  The clerk was very nice on the phone.  When I went to the store that evening, he remembered my phone call and showed me all the different varieties.  He asked me what I wanted to make, and I said papaya salad.  He grabbed all the ingredients for me since I didn't have a recipe in hand.  He even suggested ingredients you normally don't find on Western friendly, recipe sites, like fermented, raw fish, rice paddy crabs and dried, little shrimp.The parking lot fits 8 cars uncomfortably.  I know if the lot was full, I'm not a good enough driver to pull in or out without a minor mishap.  The grocery carts are teenie, tiny.  Mine was overflowing in 15 minutes of browsing.  The prices are similar to the other Asian grocery stores in Vietnamese town, but the products here are neatly arranged, there is enough variety without being confusing, and there isn't that Asian grocery store smell of things being a little bit too fresh, fishy or just plain pungent. The best part of the store is the super helpful gentleman who is happy to have your papaya shredded for you, answer all your question, and generally make you feel welcome.  Customer service means more when you don't know what you're looking for.

7.description: I like coming to this market because it is clean and organized.  I come here to find primarily asian items.  It is not super crazy like over at Tai Nam. They are very friendly and helpful here.  The prices are also pretty good, you might pay a little bit more here than Tai Nam.  They are closed on Mondays, I think.

49.description: Is this necessary?I'm not sure I really need to write a review since the rest really sum it up:  A great store that's CLEAN, with incredibly FRIENDLY employees (who often give you a free SAMPLE of something when you leave), and a great SELECTION. Yes, some things are pricey but for the most part you'll save.  And they have THAI BROWN JASMINE RICE which is so much tastier than just plain jasmine or regular brown rice ... and good for you too!And if you really want some smelly frozen durian they've got it for you as well.

40.description: SImply the best place to get Asian groceries - fairly affordable and the staff is very nice and willing to help!

53.description: I really love this place!Amazing selection, great prices, and the staff is so friendly.  I stopped in to pick up a ridiculous bunch of candy for a party I was attending.  They had everything I was looking for and much more.  I also treated myself to some fresh fruit and basic grocery items.  Everything was wonderful.Very impressed and I plan on coming here very often!  The fish market seems nice, actually.  Being an East Coaster myself I've seen my share of fresh fish and must say that everything here seems to be of high quality and very well stored and prepared.  I can't wait to come in and do some real shopping.

30.description: Love Edgewater for its friendly people, quaint neighborhood and of course, the "surprise" stores!  Golden Pacific was incredibly well-stocked with Japanese, Korean, Vietnamese, Thai, Indian, Chinese..... you name it! I honestly think you can pretty much get anything "Asian" you want here - not to mention the amazing fresh BUSHEL of Basil for less than $3!! I was sold the moment I walked in the door =)Wonderful grocery store that's clean, well-lit, laid back with each aisle thematically organized ;) Was hoping to find myself a nice Wok today, but couldn't find any =( They even had Mexican tortilla makers!! $10 minimum for Credit card, otherwise cash only~Make sure you pick up some SourSop juice when you come - a must try if you haven't had the juice before!

46.description: If you don't have the time to drive to Mitsuwa or Hmart, this place will do.  There is a great selection of japanese products and the place is really organized.  I think the products are a little pricier than Tai Nam and Hmart.  However, I feel like more relaxed, clean, and stress free when shopping here because it's not a mad house like these other grocery stores.  But, if you think about it the few extra cents you pay here might even out for the gas or wait time at register if you shop here.  Also added bonus, there is no strong stench of fish when shopping here.
