37.description: I *love* Chicagoland Games (aka the "Dice Dojo").  I've never been to their previous, smaller storefront, but I've come fairly regularly since moving to Rogers Park and discovering this place only five minutes away.  The store is divided into two sections: a front section with an excellent selection of "gamers' games" (Eurogames and Ameritrash board games, as well as RPG books and wargaming miniatures), as well as a smattering of more ordinary board games for more mundane sorts; and a back section with several long tables and literally *hundreds* of demo games that you can simply pick up and start playing anytime you like.  The staff is extremely friendly, and they live by their motto "we don't close 'til the game's over" -- on some nights, things can run to midnight and beyond without a hint of pestering from the staff (likely because the staff is playing right along with you).  Being able to play a demo game here has turned curiosity into a purchase several times already, and I doubt I'm alone there.The place certainly isn't as big as Games Plus over in Mt. Prospect (my former game store of choice, and still a great place), but at a five minute drive vs. one hour for Games Plus, it's hard not to visit the Dojo on a regular basis, especially on Wednesday nights (which are dedicated to board games).  I've never had trouble finding parking on the curb right out front; there's a parking pay box a few storefronts down.  They're also very close to the Bryn Mawr Red Line stop, which I'll take advantage of sometimes on my way home from work.

21.description: On north Broadway there is a storefront and in this storefront there is a Mecca of Nerdom so immense, so complete and so magnetic it draws geeks from around town to its warm, inviting tables to sit, kibbitz and share in our common activity: rolling dice and being complete dorks. The Dice Dojo is a necessary, vital part of Chicago's teeming gamer scene. Packed wall to wall with every board, card and otherwise geeky game imaginable. If you're looking for -that- expansion of -this- game, odds are they have it or can get it very quickly. Safely ensconced behind a glass case of rare Magic: The Gathering cards sits one of its helpful employees waiting to advise you on a purchase or shoot the breeze over the latest gaming news. This is a literal candy store for nerds and gamer geeks alike. But ho, that's not all.Dice Dojo serves another purpose and that's one of incubating, nurturing and helping the local Chicago gaming scene thrive through its numerous weekly events. Any given night you can find something to do here with friends and strangers gathering to play games together. From complex board games like Battlestar Galactica to good ol' fashioned pen 'n paper Dungeons and Dragons to social games like Are You A Werewolf you can find groups congregating and sharing their love for all things gaming in these hallowed halls.The Dice Dojo is the epicenter of gaming within the Chicagoland borders and deserves nothing less than our financial, spiritual and moral support. Stand behind your store, Chicagoland.

16.description: This place is pretty sweet. We were visiting some friends in the city, and they wanted to go and get games for our weekend hangout. None of us had been here, so we didn't know what to expect. We ended up walking in on the gaming side where a lot of people were playing random games. It seemed pretty cool. The other half was all games and it was awesome. I really wanted to get one of the Discworld games, but sadly did not have the monies. We probably spent a half hour checking out all the games. All the employees were super friendly too. They informed us that we could play any game in the other room. There was a wall full of games that we missed on the way in. We're going to go back on the next visit and check it out. I think you can get food too, since there was a gigantic pizza on one of the tables.

17.description: Dice Dojo the gold standard against which I compare all other board game stores.  They have set a mighty high bar.Their game selection is unparalleled.  More importantly, the staff is incredibly knowledgeable.  A number of times I've walked unsure of what exactly I was looking for, and I've always been pleased with what I left with.If you're into Magic or D&D, these guys are great too.  Again, the staff knows their stuff, and they host lots of competitive tournaments.

10.description: I called a couple of friendly local game stores, and this is the one that had what I was looking for (sorry Wanderers' Refuge!). The staff over the phone was nice, and they were doubly so once I arrived in person. Inside, the layout is pleasant. Well-lit, well-staffed, and clean. The shelves are full of so many board games, including some hard-to-find titles, but it doesn't come across as cluttered. From what I gather, they host Magic drafts and tournaments and such, and it gets pretty packed with sweaty nerds. Being a sweaty nerd myself, I hate to downgrade them a whole star for something some folks might see as minor, but there's a very noticeable funk to the place. The unwashed nerd smell is strong, to the point of being off-putting. Need to set off some kind of deodorant bug bomb in the place.Prices are what you'd expect. MSRP is fair enough. Sure, you can get it cheaper on Amazon, but hey, shop local and what not. All in all, a good store. A real paradise for those who love customer service, and don't mind the malodor of nerd funk.

11.description: Their owner has gone out his way multiple times to help me with my hobby - including letting me use Primer, Glue and Tools for free. It's a great place to hang out for hours and no one ever pressures you to buy anything - you can simply go there, play games, and they expect nothing in return. I'll always support this place.

26.description: The events are all free (except for the Magic tournaments) and always fun.  You can always find people to play with, you can buy all the games and supplies you need (or borrow them), and the staff is excellent.  Monday night D&D is the best.  Talk to Lexx; he's a really nice guy and he'll help you find anything you need.

27.description: I came in here really wanting to like the place, but to be honest the employees seemed rather pompous and rude to me. Most of the guys playing other games were doing their own thing and the employees that night were interacting with them a lot, but there's no need to treat your newer customers like shit. I work in customer service too, and all I want is a little bit of courtesy. They really left a bad taste in my mouth.I can see there's a lot of good things going on with this store, the rating is just from my personal experience thus far. I hope that it was just a fluke and that future experiences are more positive.

35.description: Great games and friendly service!

8.description: Dice Dojo/Chicagoland Games is for anyone who loves card games, board games, dice games, figurines, and game games. We were in here looking for European strategy boardgames for adults, and were met with staff that were super enthusiastic and helpful in recommending a handful of options to start, like Puerto Rico, Dominion, Agricola, Ticket to Ride, etc. The wall of boardgames is immense. I'm pretty sure you could find any board game that is ever made here. We walked out with Caylus for $60. I'm very much for supporting local business so I'll be back, but our game was only $45 on Amazon. The backroom is a games room, where you can come on their game nights and play with other fans, or just try out a game before you buy. Very neat. The game room did seem to be a place where little kids like to hang out and play games with their pals, without parental supervision.

0.description: I love this store! They have an extensive selection of  board games and their staff is friendly and helpful. I once ran into a saleswoman who was so knowledgeable and enthusiastic that I walked out with 4 board games that afternoon! They have a lot of space and a game room where you can try games out. My husband even participated and won a Malifaux tournament that was held there! It's a pretty awesome business.

38.description: This place is all about community.  I quickly went in and saw people playing board games in the back.  It was amazing to see people of all walks of life enjoy themselves.  The business has reviews from different media outlets posted up on how they are developing the community in Edgewater.  Very friendly service and a good selection of games.  I'm sure to pick Chicagoland Games as my first choice when I decide to buy a board game.

20.description: This place is just super-duper!  So many awesome games, friendly staff, and lots of place to play the games.  Not too mention, they will happily show you how to play said games.  They've recently expanded to take over a neighboring storefront.  Good Game!

19.description: I came here for a Wednesday game night a few months ago.  After a couple of hours, I left with a giant headache and backache.  Even at the beginning of the night (well before it is filled), it is extremely LOUD, probably because of the tin ceiling and the lack of any sound dampening materials (everything is a smooth surface - wood, metal, etc. - no fabric or carpet).  Once the place is filled (100+ people), it is deafening.  You have to yell at the person sitting next to you.The seating is basic metal folding chairs - hard and no lumbar support.

33.description: Man if I wasn't so shy I'd live here. The only thing that's intimidating for me is the community of REALLY friendly people all playing together in the back part of the building (it's like a big room that's sectioned off a bit). A man who didn't even work there greeted us as we walked in as friendly as can be. There was a D&D game going on and everyone was having a BALL! It's the kind of place you want to go to meet other nerds like yourself and have a good time. I personally am more of a shy person so it's harder for me to do, but I dig it man, I dig it.Every night they have a different "theme" even a night just free for all. Wednesday nights are board game nights for example. We walked in not knowing what to expect, and the man behind the desk/cash register was sitting quietly reading a comic book. He answered all of our questions politely and we looked around to find all of the board games we could imagine. All the kind that you really want to play as a grown up nerd but can't always find. Of course a ton of them are mega expensive, but it's still THE place to go to buy games. Card games, board games, roll playing games...it's all there for you to enjoy. And though it was seemingly impossible to find, I think that may be a good thing, it's like a diamond in the rough. Very clean, friendly people, space used efficiently (not too crowded or empty anywhere), easy on the eyes, great variety, all around good time.

2.description: Wow, this place rocks! Absolutely AMAZING selection of games free to play (board game night is Wednesday 6p-12a). Really nice people, not overcrowded. Huge selection of games for purchase as well. Really friendly staff. Nice clean store. Can't wait til Wednesday!

34.description: So, let me put a caveat to this. I am not a gamer. I have never been a 'gamer'. I like fun board games with cartoon-y looking characters. I love mario and was the first person to mock my boyfriend about his Wow love. So when we walked in, I felt very, very out of place. He felt at home and reminisced about his childhood for 2 days afterward. At first, I clung to his side- I feel awkward and judge situations like this. However, I will say this: this had tons of games. The kind of game that you go all over the place looking for but can't find anything interesting sounding at Toys R Us because it's meant for kids. We went in to buy a fun but simple card game called fluxx. The guy in the store gladly showed us where it was at. They had games I was comfortable and familiar with, and games that are really really out there- but overall, it has a great selection, and as soon as I get over being uncomfortable with "dorky"/dark graphics as opposed to something you'd see disney do, then I'll love it. I'm going tonight to get said boyfriend a game he's wanted forever and cannot be found at any other local store!

32.description: Chicagoland Games is well stocked and run by a friendly, talkative crew of guys. There's a huge shelf full of opened up board games that you can pull off the shelf and play right there in the store. Plus, they always have table space if you want to bring something in.

18.description: This must be board game nirvana. Great selection of board, strategy and deck-building games.  I love that they've got a wall of open boxes and a sizable area to test drive games before you buy. Think there were about 5 different games going on when we walked in and about 8 other open tables to join in. The staff were nice and know their stuff with recommendations on the ready. Prices were fair. I'll definitely be back.

13.description: You may pass this shop, and think, "Hey, did it get bigger since the last time I was there?"Yeah, it probably did. And there is a reason.Few shops leave an impression like they do. The overall staff spend so much time immersed in this stuff, they clearly know what they're talking about; and you will always find someone who specializes in the kinds of games you like.Their events are to die for. Any calendar month is loaded with tournaments and opportunities to socialize with others in the community, you could go to this shop and no other, and still keep your finger on the pulse of the gaming world.Every convention they attend, I always find myself shopping at their booth, and the employees staffing those booths are equally as helpful. Top notch shop. I'd recommend this place to anyone, and I often do. :)

4.description: If you even slightly enjoy board games, you should check out Chicagoland Games, otherwise known as the Dice Dojo.  But be prepared for a seriously nerdy time.  My boyfriend has been going there for several years, and I've been dragged along for many open board game nights.  In one half of the store, they have a huge selection of board games to purchase, and on most trips, we've left with a board game to add to his extensive collection.  The other half of the store is an open space with many tables set up for tournaments and open board game days/nights.  The entire wall is pretty much covered with shelves holding open demo board games to choose from, so you can play almost any game your heart desires.  They have an open board game night on Wednesdays, which is BYOB and you can bring/order food.  People sure work up an appetite while playing games.  Any and all are welcome at the Dice Dojo, and you don't have to make purchases to hang out and play board games there.If you love board games, you know and love the Dice Dojo.  If you haven't been, you should definitely check it out.  We've converted many people to board game lovers after bringing them to open board game night.

24.description: I am a certified Normal so this store wasn't made with me in mind; this is a total geek gamer haven. If I was a geek gamer this place would get a perfect score. But the place is friendly and there's opportunities to connect with fellow nerds on Wednesday nights for Open Game Night. If you want to delve deep in nerdom, like a Masters Degree level cirriculum, come out to learn about Warhammer, Magic The Gathering and the like on the other nights.

6.description: I've been coming here for years now and this place is the best. The folks who work here really put the F in FLGS (Friendly Local Game Shop). Everyone is very knowledgeable and willing and able to answer any questions you may have about their products. The owner, Lexx, is a really nice guy as well. Personally, I go here to buy Warhammer 40K and Warmachine minis and supplies; they have a well stocked inventory of both, as well as several opportunities to get a game in.The Dojo also provides a lot of great opportunities to learn or just play some great board games. I cannot recommend checking this place out enough. Check their event calendar on the site (chicagolandgames.com) for everything that's going on this month.

22.description: Kind of hard to compare this place to any other really. Any board game lover should check this place out at least once. If you're curious, you should stop by on wednesday night to check out a play a game For free before you buy it.

15.description: This is my favorite place in chicago. I come for the open play on Wednesday nights. Everyone is so friendly and their game library is incredible.

7.description: Definitely the best gaming store in the city, and one of the best I've ever visited period. They have an enormous collection of the latest and some more obscure titles, all neatly organized by genre. I found a couple of games I haven't been able to find in my local stores in Virginia, and I didn't see them anywhere else in Chicago either. On top of the great selection and friendly service, they have an adjoining space as big as the main store with lots of tables and a giant selection of games to play. There's no charge for using the tables, and no charge to borrow something from the library to play. It's a great way to spend an afternoon. I disagree with the fellow that mentioned a "sweaty nerd funk". Maybe it's just because they had the back door open and there was a nice breeze, but it smelled fine (unlike some shops I've visited). Having a clean bathroom was also a nice plus.Bottom line: if you're looking for a board game and/or a place to play in the Chicago area, this is a must-visit.

36.description: Right off the bat, Dice Dojo doesn't fall into the two basic traps that many gaming stores do. One, the place is clean, well lit and doesn't reek of b.o. How pleasant that is cannot be emphasized enough. Two, the employees are not at all intimidating or condescending. As with any subculture, those that lord over the cash register and sales floor can be stand off-ish and condescending (I'm looking at you, record store clerks) but the crew here is laid back and helpful.After finding my old cards in the garage, a couple friends and I have started casually playing Magic: The Gathering again. In a recession, any form of cheap entertainment is a plus, and my house is byob. I decided to buy some new cards, but had to clue where to start seeing as I hadn't played, or even thought about the game in nearly a decade. Every question I had was answered to my satisfaction, and the prices are pretty fair.The only thing that stops me from going stars is that the last two times I've dropped in I've either dealt with a seemingly new and kind of lost employee, or it's taken a while to get service because there was so much going on. That being said, I won't beat up a new guy, and it's good to see a business inviting people in from the neighborhood to hang out and play games.

30.description: This place is like a second home now. I love most everyone who goes and am slowly being accepted into a new group of friends.  I love learning to play all the new types of games and though I could buy a board game cheaper on Amazon I will give my money to the Dice Dojo out of love for the establishment.  Wednesday nights are a blast, I hate that I have to work so early because I never have my fix of games.  This place is awesome and everyone should support and buy games from here.  On top of loving the place the owners JP at Lexx are cool guys who know games and give you advice on anything.  They have helped me get into gaming in a big way.  Thank you.

3.description: It seems like I'm down everything these days, but once again, I have to take the experience of the product alongside the service with which it's delivered.  The Dice Dojo is fantastic, with a huge selection of games to play onsite, and the selection in the store is unparalleled -- if they don't have it, it can't be had.  But the service is pretty hideous; every time I've gone in, I've waited for ages for someone to ring me up, and the staff often seems distracted and unwilling to help.  The customers can be a major headache, as well.  Why are all my hobbies ruined by the people who like them?

14.description: HUGE selection of games, I found stuff that has been out-of-print for months, and at reasonable prices. Board games, card games, collectibles, Warhammer, expansions, RPG supplies, this store really has something for everyone.The only drawback is that if you don't know to go in the door closer to Bryn Mawr that leads you directly into the game shop, you might enter the Dice Dojo side of the store and have to cross it to get to the goods. They host tournaments in the Dice Dojo side and have play space which is great, but when that room is in action, the place absolutely reeks of unwashed young male. Going in that room as a female elicits reactions ranging from surprise to hostile glaring as well, so they can keep their stink (eyes and smell) to themselves.

12.description: I question the entire corporation's viewpoint on refrigeration. The ice cream is melty, the meat is disgusting and the whole store has ill-tasting aroma.The fruit is bashed up. The bread is stale. The cashiers are unattractive. They have these disgusting 'banana' candies on the rack at the checkout. I was high one day and thought they looked interesting. I took one bite and felt like I was chomping on the 1970s. Crusty, moldy,  putrid, repugnant old style banana candy. Avoid them.I only used to go in there for booze/cigarettes. Thankfully, I found the lord & quit both of those things. I haven't returned to Super Foods since then. Pray I do not relapse.

3.description: It's nice to have a neighborhood grocer between me and Mariano's for quick stops closer to my house. Unfortunately this place leaves much to be desired.There is almost always a manager or owner up front hovering by the registers near the lottery tickets that really creeps everyone out, he always looks like he's aching to punch someone.Finally, if you buy sale items you need to watch the computer screen when they scan your items because they often ring up full price --- on purpose or oversight? And if you call them out on it, be prepared for pushback.

1.description: i go here when i want to pick up a simple meal, and not drive all the way to Jewels. they have sales on foods at times, just to get rid of it. if you live in the Edgewater neighborhood, you should definitely stop in.

2.description: Scamming customers by not entering sale prices into the register, so sale items ring up at full price and it's up to the customer to call them on it. Cashiers will just override and key in the sale price, the owner & managers will often argue, despite the fact that the items have signage on them in the aisle. Just to satisfy my own curiosity I did an experiment, and this happened 8 out of 8 times in the last couple weeks.I love having a nice, convenient neighborhood grocer that isn't 7-11 or Walgreen's, but I'm not shopping at a dishonest business.

9.description: Love Super Food!  The staff is really sweet.  Great beer selection for a small food & liquor store (but the beer is a bit overpriced).  Quality produce, and basic grocery essentials.  So glad it's in the neighborhood.

10.description: LOVE this place! Good prices, surprising selection, friendly staff and open late!

4.description: This place is great.They have whole chickens for $3.98 that, when roasted, is enough for three meals!Now that BYOB Nookies has opened nearby, the wine selection and quality has skyrocketed. They've still got 40 oz'ers of malt liquor, but now they've got Chilean red wine as well!The produce quality and selection is also much better. The fruit no longer looks like it fell off a truck.I've been shopping here since 1996. Don't believe the one-star reviews, this place is a staple in the neighborhood. The staff is very friendly and they're my neighbors as well. Awhile ago, they started carrying Middle Eastern food products, adding to the Mexican and Eastern European goodies that were already there.They have the most delicious brand of cottage cheese here that I've ever tasted. IBareman's, it is so good. Plus, I like the name.

6.description: Super Food desperately needs to expand their beer inventory. To be sure, Super Food has a better beer selection than the abysmal "Pantry" down the street (I believe the only non-water-beers they sell are 312 and Sierra Nevada Pale). But this isn't saying much. They stock Dogfishead, Great Lakes, and Goose Island's 312 at exorbitant prices (I think $10-11 per sixpack). This is a start, but I don't see why a place like this wouldn't stock a couple more micro-brews from the area. Metropolitan Breweries is about a mile away. Half Acre and Two Brothers would be nice additions as well. Convenience stores on Bryn Mawr should really take a page out of the book of La Primera Fruit Liquor & Meats (On Clark, between Winnemac and Argyle). They've got it all figured out- they have a wonderful beer selection and I think they do quite well.

15.description: I love this place.  They have everything you need at good prices.  The bread was stale, but that might be because they get it from a local bakery so there's no preservatives.  If they started carrying organic yogurt, I probably wouldn't shop anywhere else...

0.description: Do your taste buds and wallet compete for your attention? Satisfy them both by shopping at Super Foods!As a former west sider of Chicago who went to Stanley's religiously for produce and the like this is the north side equivalent but better for chefs and home cooks needing reasonably priced goods on the fly.Super Foods not only has great fruit and veggies -ethnic and rare too- at more than reasonable prices but also a 99cent discount rack for things like limes, lemons, plantains (bananas), potatoes, cactus leaves and more that I personally pull from once a week to use that night or shortly after. As for their regular produce and meats they've lasted me up two two weeks at a time with proper refrigeration and storage unlike Stanley's which was maybe just over a week. Maybe.My absolute FAVORITE part about Super Foods is their meat selections. No joke, it's like having a butcher with out all the chit chat and know how if you're an inexperienced cook looking to learn how to cook or experiment with any and all parts of an animal. The butchers in back are skilled and bring out fresh cuts in the morning and around 1pm at the least on weekdays. The best part of their work are the pre-prepped packages of chicken fajitas, spiced ribs, and the best diced pork & cilantro and I guess magic because it makes the BEST pork tacos. Sorry guys but it's so good I may have tried to pass it off as my own... The staff couldn't be nicer or more welcoming. I've never had issues paying with a card but out of courtesy and respect for their business I typically pay cash so they don't get hit with fees. You'll get the random crazy yahoo in there from time to time but if you live in the area you already know how to handle them and so does the establishment.TLDR: Need meat, produce or bakery items and live nearby? GO HERE. Need essential pantry items or beer and boozy stuff? Come here too if you're willing to pay reasonable convenience prices.  Buying frozen dinners, microwave meals, canned goods or dairy products?? No, just no, go to the Jewel or Mariano's on Berwyn or the Whole Foods on Thorndale.

5.description: In a pinch? Go to Super Foods!I do like this little, hidden grocer. Discovered it one day when I needed a few items and did not feel like walking to Jewel. They have your basic grocer, produce, and alcohol needs. They do not have everything, but they do well for what they have. Service is usually friendly and fast. Super Food is a clean store and the layout is easy to understand once you have been here once or twice. Prices are reasonable. They do not have a minimum on debit or credit cards, which is a plus.Overall, if you need something in a pinch, Super Foods is your place!

13.description: Super Food is the jam, really the only place you need to know.  The meat and produce are cheap and fresh, and you can get Bimbo bread for two bucks.  The only two weak points are their lack of selection in spices and magazines.  If you want the latest issue of Playboy, head to Super Food, but they don't carry much else.

11.description: I love Super Food!  I used to live across the street and it was so nice to be able to just walk out the door and buy fresh herbs, etc when I needed them.  The prices on the meat and produce are also very reasonable, and they always have lots of sale items. They also would occasionally carry Milka chocolate bars, which are awesome and hard to find otherwise.  Of course, the downside is that this place is very tiny so the selection of goods isn't that great, but overall Super Food is pretty awesome.

8.description: This store has come a long way since even 5 years ago when I moved foot steps away..produce and meat are always fresh and the best prices..I brought my neighbor in who was skeptical, and walked around the store with her mouth opened in amazement! Support this local business..all the people that are complaining, I don't know why..very nice people working here, and helpful..so what if a few derelicts are in there once in a while, they are entitled to shop too ya know! Anyway, maybe a few more produce items like kale would be great..but maybe they have now..always something new in there...love this little Bodega!

14.description: great store....decent peole who work there....cheap liq + fruit + meat = win for the hood. I'm in there daily.

7.description: I love their produce section - especially the herbs and veg.  This is where I get my dil, brussel sprouts, okra, cilantro, parsley, bell peppers, and scallions.10 limes for a dollar?  This is also a great place to stock up on lime juice for your bar-tending needs.  They also seem to have a nice selection of meat - it doesn't look spoiled like some of the reviews say - I think they must have upgraded to better coolers.  I love the baked goods that they sell here - but make sure you buy them when you see the delivery being made - which is randomly.And every time I have a pastry-tooth, this store also sells pound cake that hits the spot.

28.description: I have tried my best, but I give up. Although this store has a great selection, the staff muck it up. I went here recently to find a specific yarn I needed to complete a project and the guy was totally unhelpful and dismissive, with just a touch of rude. Sifu here I come...

1.description: The owner, Mandy, totally grasps customer service and is very good to interact with; she will offer value-added info, website suggestions, etc.  Not exactly sure about how she chooses the other staff; I've encountered a new woman on weekdays and she seems kind of frosty and defensive (or overwhelmed) in interactions. Reading some of these other reviews, looks like some other staff stuff going on, too. I think Mandy needs to look at how she chooses/trains staff.  Good yarn selection, lots of fun stuff.  People do really want warm, with-it staff to interact with and in a boutique atmosphere they will go elsewhere. Knitting is meant to be a relaxing, fun experience-- including the store.

39.description: It's been a year and I can still say that this store rocks. They continue to have a huge selection of yarns in a large variety of colors. Recently I needed Cascade 220 in colors to match my existing stash for a project. They had a huge selection of complimentary colors to choose from.The atmosphere is still relaxed and friendly, the staff knowledgeable. They carry a lot of interesting brands of yarn. My favorites are Malabrigo, Three Irish Girls, Dream in Color, Madeline Tosh, and Fleur de Fiber.

9.description: I love these guys! Excellent, well-curated and -priced selection of sumptuous yarns and --even better-- EXCELLENT CUSTOMER SERVICE. For some reason, people skills can be in short supply in a lot of yarn stores, but that is not the case here, and to that I say HOORAY. You CAN be nice and sell pretty yarns. These folks are proof. I knit a lot, and they get all my business.

29.description: Absolutely my favorite yarn store. I've been visiting this store for over a year and a half and every single time I stop in the experience is no less than completely delightful. I'm from Cleveland, but I always make a point to stop in when I visit Chicago because the selection is just fantastic, not only in brands, but in range (few stores in my city carry more than one type of laceweight yarn). The store layout is open and airy and filled with natural light, and there are swatches of the yarns laid out below the displays. Sample projects are placed throughout the store-- including plenty of shawls in popular patterns kept on the chairs (spotted a Color Affection and a Hitchhiker on this visit) so you can pick them up and get a better idea of what your own project would look like. A lot of thought has been put into this store and it really shows. There's always a tablet in the middle of the store in a little seating area for looking up patterns-- such a great, functional detail. Prices are always clearly marked on the yarn and there's a great selection of instructional books and pattern collections. I've never had any trouble finding a specific yarn here-- it is always clean and organized. The store is pretty small, but the space is utilized so effectively that Windy Knitty manages to display a better selection than I've seen in yarn stores with twice the space.I can't finish this review without talking about Mandy, the owner. She is always incredibly helpful and gracious and her memory is remarkable! I doubt I get a chance to visit her store as much as most of her repeat customers, but even from the second visit she could recall that I was out of town and what yarn I've purchased or played with in the past. While I was browsing today, she stopped me to ask if I've seen new colors in a brand and weight that I purchased months and months ago-- I hadn't, so she took the time to pull the new colorways down from the shelf so I could take a look. She also didn't balk at winding the lace I'd picked up (I've been to many stores where employees groan at winding yarn), and explained it would just take a few minutes longer than usual since there was so much yardage. Regardless of the (awesome) selection, Mandy's amazing customer service will keep me shopping here whenever I'm in town.

23.description: I had some extra time on my schedule and thought I would hop the red line to Andersonville from the city. It was worth it.  Brent not only showed me to yarns I was looking for but he spent the time with me to educate me about any product I was interested in while throwing in a few laughs.  I wish I had brought my crochet project so I could stitch and chat more.  I am new to crochet so he was happy to answer all of my novice questions.  I would highly recommend this store for  artists.  I will definitely be a returning customer and send my friends there.  It is such a happy place!

5.description: Windy Knitty is the best yarn shop in the city. The staff is so friendly and they really know their stuff. They're super helpful when it comes to picking out colors and figuring what yarn would work best for a project. They have a vast selection of yarns, all ethically sourced and reasonably priced. So many beautiful colors! They also have a great selection of books, tools (hooks, needles, buttons, etc) and everything else you might need to complete your project.They also offer a number of crochet and knitting classes, which are super awesome. I've taken a few and learned so much! Jill is an awesome crochet teacher! :)

31.description: It's hard to find a quality knitting place in the city that also has the space to showcase a wide variety of yarns and supplies.  Windy Knitty accomplishes this with the friendliness of a high quality local neighborhood vibe (even the customers we ran into were sweet, which I attribute to the open, airy vibe).  In particular, there were lots of cute gift ideas (packaged projects w/ matching nail polish, and intricate accessories) that I know I'll be back to peruse come Christmas/Birthday time.Visited with my friend, who is a choosy hardcore knitter, and there were no complaints to be had.  We purchased two books and a couple skeins of yarn (had to hold back on the Lorna's Laces and Madeline Tosh of course).  Looking forward to making the trip up to Andersonville again soon. Btw, we've been to 8+ various knitting stores (Chicago, Western Suburbs, Champaign) so have seen a lot out there.Btw, there's also a cute garden store and tasty Greek restaurant nearby, in case you make a half-day out of it.  Easy free street parking found right around the corner off the main streets.

25.description: Windy Knitty is great! I almost get overwhelmed because the yarn selection goes up to the ceiling. But the staff has always been very helpful in finding me the correct yarn for my projects.They have a great selection: along with some smaller indie labels, they have staples like Cascade and Berroco. I took a class there with Jill and we had a great time. She's an excellent teacher and we have the same sense of humor. Mandy, the owner, is friendly and helpful without being overbearing.  It's a great lace to spend your fiber dollars.

12.description: I stopped here after brunch with a friend and he willingly went in with me and didn't seem tortured by the experience. I loved this shop. I liked that parking was easy, the staff was nice without being annoying, and they had an awesome selection of yarn. I'm sort of on a yarn diet but was traveling for work and needed to get yarn for a class I'm taking, and they had lots of options here. I didn't ask for help but I saw them helping others and they were very knowledgeable and helpful without being annoying (I hate it when you ask one question and then have a salesperson attached to your side until you leave). I love that they have spud and chloe, malabrigo, and neighborhood fiber co., which is what I bought. Also, the lighting in here was awesome--I don't understand yarn stores that have dim lighting, how do they expect us to SEE the colors like that?? I've started to be picky about that in my old age. Overall, great store.

37.description: This is my favorite yarn store in Chicago. I love it! Their selection is great, and their staff is so helpful. They really go out of their way to help you out. The store is easy to browse or to go grab exactly what you want, and the atmosphere is really pleasant.

21.description: Windy Knitty was my first Chicago local yarn store experience and I have to say it didn't disappoint.  The store is bright and colorful and has more yarn than I've ever seen in one place.  It also seems as if Windy Knitty has done a very good job in cultivating a strong community of loyal clients.  Since I'm both a fairly novice knitter and a very poor grad student, most of their incredible selection was out of my budget, but I will definitely be returning here to buy a special skein or two every now and then.

16.description: I really want to give this yarn shop 5 stars. Here's what's AMAZING: locally-owned, in my neighborhood, good/solid selection, beautiful displays, excellent samples, spacious. I am quite glad this shop is in my neighborhood. I have a pretty good place to walk to when I need a yarn-fix, notion or just to browse. Staff is knowledgeable.What I don't like is the snobby, off-putting staff member. He happens to be male. I have NOTHING against male knitters, in fact, I love love love them. (I know many male knitters that get bad raps.) Anyway, this guy is so unfriendly. He has been so to me in person and over the phone. I don't understand what gives. Perhaps this is a Chicago thing...when I first moved here, I had trouble finding places that offered good customer service. I feel like I'm interrupting his knitting time or something when I have a question. Yikes, guy, the owner is paying you to help her customers, not for you to just sit there and knit. I used to work at a yarn shop in another city and I would have been fired if I had treated customers in the same way. Perhaps the novelty of having a male knitter work in the store allows him to get away with it.I like this store enough to either avoid him or just ignore his attitude problem. Other staff members are super-nice and extremely friendly.

17.description: Cute place, nice staff and lots of events. They even have knitting classes here.

10.description: Just love. I learned to knit here two years ago and I've been knitting ever since. Yes, online yarn shopping can be a bit cheaper and I've even checked out other local knitting stores. But even if Windy Knitty wasn't my closest knitting store, I would keep shopping here because I've always felt welcomed and the store is well-stocked, CLEAN as a whistle, and competitively priced.And, of course, I've received lots of expert advice from Tara and Grace. These are people with wool in their blood and they happily share their time, care, and advice!Apologies in advance for feeding your knitting addiction and your stash. You'll thank me later.

11.description: 5 wooly stars.  Yarny Yarny blissful yarn.  Very good selection of yarns.  Very helpful ladies running this place. Patterns, needles, kits and yarn.  What more do you need?????

26.description: A friend and I just completed the beginning knitting class. It's once a week for four weeks. They give you metal needles and some nice yarn and teach you basic skills. We learned to cast on, cast off, knit, purl, read a basic pattern, do increases, decreases and gained confidence with every step. Our teacher, Grace, was smart, patient, funny and very supportive. I'm looking forward to taking a round needle class there and hope to come back again and again. Thank you Grace, and Windy Knitty, for such a great experience.

27.description: Worth the trek from Wicker Park. Cute and friendly, huge selection, lovely people.

35.description: Great shop!!!  Trouble is, I don't have the time to learn how to knit in time for XMas (which is what I'd set out to do).  Anyone out there who'd be willing to knit a hat or two for me (or as many as you can get out of one skein) for hire?  Nothing special--just your basic hat.  Should be easy money for all those more gifted and more dedicated to knitting than I am c. December 2011!!!

8.description: I really want to love Windy Knitty since it's the closest yarn shop to my house, but I've been really disappointed the last few months. The first issue was when I began knitting a pattern that was on display in the shop, ran into an issue, and came in to ask a question and was totally dismissed by the guy who had knitted the sample. He told me just to rip it out and start over. Look guys, I want to support my LYS, but it IS cheaper just to purchase yarn online, so if I can't come in and ask a simple question as a paying customer, what's the point? Secondly, and most frustratingly, three times, my balls of yarn that have been wound here have ended up containing a rat's nest of yarn in the middle, to be painstakingly and maddeningly detangled later when I'm halfway through a project. Simply, life is too short to be detangling yarn, so I'll be taking my business elsewhere.

0.description: To me, a yarn store is no good unless the staff is friendly and knowledgeable about yarn, and knows at least a little bit about knitting, crocheting, gauge, et cetera. (Ever been to one of those shops where the people who work there just sit on a couch working on a project, acting like you're intruding?) Windy Knitty carries a wide selection of yarn that's budget-minded, all the way to the high-end stuff. There are also classes and drop-in knit sessions. When I first moved to Chicago, I had such a nice interaction with the staff at the store, one of whom not only recommended an apartment in her building, and the other of whom walked me part way to my El station. Again, this is when I was new in Chicago! I emphasize the friendliest factor because anyone who has frequented a lot of yarn stores appreciates the difference between the snooty places where you feel dumb asking any questions  and the places where the staff is willing to help.Let's please support our local stores where the staff can give advice and help you learn how to knit or crochet, as opposed to the big-box stores selling the low-end stuff and whose staff can't really answer your questions.Windy Knitty is officially my favorite yarn store in Chicago!

38.description: I first came into Windy Knitty just after their grand opening last year (2011) and loved the store. The design of it, the way the yarns are showed off, everything was great. And the yarns? OMG, the yarns. Mandy has TONS of stock and options for everything you're looking for, and it goes from extremely reasonably priced (great for kids projects or big sweaters) to the super swanky, high end stuff that is all hand dyed and hand spun and makes you want to immediately start projects and never stop.Since I first went into the store, I've visited MANY times. Every time, I've walked out with something more than I went in for (always the sign of a good store). But what makes this a great store over a good yarn store is the people -- Mandy rocks. She knows her yarn, knows her customers and somehow knows exactly what to carry to make everyone happy. Her assistants are great and give you advice on what you're looking at, will tell you if the color you're trying out isn't quite for you, and they know their yarn materials and can make awesome suggestions for how to match something to a pre-selected pattern. I hope that this store will always be there because it's a beautiful addition to Andersonville, is within walking distance of my house (probably the most dangerous part) and is a haven for knitters and creative people.  If you're looking for a great store to buy yarn, knitting and crocheting accoutrements, stop in. You will not regret it.

20.description: GREAT yarn store!  They have an amazing selection of yarns here, many of which are high-end silk and alpaca blends, but they also have really nice cotton and wool yarns that can fit a tighter budget.  The selection is MUCH bigger than Sifu and MUCH nicer.  The store is also organized nicely and not as crazily frenetic as Sifu.  The staff at Windy Knitty is generally very friendly (I can think of one exception) and they have a rewards program, so if you spend a certain amount (I forget how much) you get money back.  I definitely think this is the best yarn store on the North Side and far and away kicks Sifu's ass.  My one major complaint is that Windy Knitty charges you a dollar to wind balls of yarn that you didn't purchase in the store, which is unneighborly.

19.description: I have tried my best, but I give up. Although this store has a great selection, the staff muck it up. I went here recently to find a specific yarn I needed to complete a project and the guy was totally unhelpful and dismissive, with just a touch of rude. Sifu here I come...

33.description: I have been taking Crochet classes here with Jill for the past couple of months and I love it!Jill is wonderful and patient and extremely talented. The store has an enormous variety to offer and both Brent and Mandy are always happy to help.

2.description: I love Windy Knitty so hard. It's on my way home. Which is full of win. I also love the selection that they have. I find myself walking around, fondling yarn, looking at tags and thinking to myself, " AHHHH! So this is what all the fuss is about with *insertpopularyarncompanynamehere*! It's where my mom wants to go look at yarn when she is in town. And she always finds something to buy. I have always had good experiences with the staff there too. I had a friend visiting from the UK. She also loved Windy Knitty. And loved it even more after we had gone down to the South Loop to yarn shop. That was super sad and super disappointing. Said friend was quite glad that she had purchased yarn at Windy Knitty. Oh and I don't know if they still charge a dollar to wind skeins that you don't buy there, as stated in another review, but I fully support their decision to do so. Seriously? You bring in yarn from another store, or worse, that you bought online, and you want them to wind it for you for free? NO. Just. NO.

34.description: Windy Knitty is one of the more beautifully organized knitting stores I have visited. The store is wide open and airy and yarns are displayed in shelves reaching up to the ceiling, organized by weight... In other words, knitter heaven!! I stopped in on a visit to Chicago, so I am not a regular. As far as I can tell, the store carries mostly higher end brands at average retail prices for those brands, but I was able to find Cascade 220 and Berrocco among the madeline.tosh and Debbie Bliss. The owner was very friendly and welcoming, and the store seems to be a wonderful place to just sit and work on a project. I recommend stopping in if you're ever in Chi-town, and hopefully I can make it back here someday.

32.description: The Windy Knitty is awesome and Tara was so helpful, authentic, and kind! I paid the store a visit because I was looking for some really unique buttons to update my winter coat. They have a fantastic selection of well priced, artful buttons. Looking forward to building upon my experience by taking a beginner's knitting class this autumn! Great atmosphere, brilliant display, and fantastic proprietor.

18.description: Windy Knitty is great! I almost get overwhelmed because the yarn selection goes up to the ceiling. But the staff has always been very helpful in finding me the correct yarn for my projects.They have a great selection: along with some smaller indie labels, they have staples like Cascade and Berroco. I took a class there with Jill and we had a great time. She's an excellent teacher and we have the same sense of humor. Mandy, the owner, is friendly and helpful without being overbearing.  It's a great lace to spend your fiber dollars.

13.description: I've been here twice and both times I've had a good experience. They had a wide selection of needles, yarn, and samples of patterns to peruse.I went in today to get a wool wash so I could block the shawl that I just finished knitting, and I ended up talking to the employee working who spent fifteen minutes with me guiding me through my next pattern. I was going to use one pattern for a hat, but when we went through reading the pattern together, she suggested that I either use different yarn or find a new pattern. She showed me a similar pattern on their computer on ravelry, as well as a sample in the store. I like the ambiance and selection of items here. I would highly recommend this shop.

4.description: Lovely place with a nice selection of yarn that ranges in price. They're very helpful here. I walked in with a pattern that required aran weight, which I learned is a European weight, and they helped me find a good substitute.

24.description: I really want to give this yarn shop 5 stars. Here's what's AMAZING: locally-owned, in my neighborhood, good/solid selection, beautiful displays, excellent samples, spacious. I am quite glad this shop is in my neighborhood. I have a pretty good place to walk to when I need a yarn-fix, notion or just to browse. Staff is knowledgeable.What I don't like is the snobby, off-putting staff member. He happens to be male. I have NOTHING against male knitters, in fact, I love love love them. (I know many male knitters that get bad raps.) Anyway, this guy is so unfriendly. He has been so to me in person and over the phone. I don't understand what gives. Perhaps this is a Chicago thing...when I first moved here, I had trouble finding places that offered good customer service. I feel like I'm interrupting his knitting time or something when I have a question. Yikes, guy, the owner is paying you to help her customers, not for you to just sit there and knit. I used to work at a yarn shop in another city and I would have been fired if I had treated customers in the same way. Perhaps the novelty of having a male knitter work in the store allows him to get away with it.I like this store enough to either avoid him or just ignore his attitude problem. Other staff members are super-nice and extremely friendly.

6.description: They have a nice enough yarn selection but wow are they rude and unhelpful.  My friend and I had planned our whole evening around starting new knitting projects. We showed up about a half hour before closing and spent several minutes picking out about $80 worth of yarn. We went up to pay and were told extremely rudely by the male clerk that he wouldn't wind our yarn (some of which was lace, so there is NO way to reasonably wind at home) because they were "technically closed."  At that point I looked at my phone and saw it was indeed 3 minutes past closing. However there'd been no warning, and there was no reason for him to be so rude. They were happy to take our money, so I'm not sure what he meant by "closed."  Obviously we left without buying anything. I'll be ordering my yarn online now!

22.description: I've been in there several times, and although the yarn selection is impressive, the service has always been less than impressive.  A couple of Sundays ago, I went there with some friends, and although there was only one other customer in the store when we entered, neither employee (and there were two working) set down their knitting nor offered to help.  To the credit of the male employee, he did greet us, but that was it.  The staff comes across as pretentious and I will only shop there as a last resort.

15.description: I bought 4 balls of yarn to make a baby blanket. They were already wound, but the way were wound was really poor.  I don't know what they did, but I had to unwind, untangle  and then rewind two of the four.  It wasted hours of my time.  It's apparent they didn't use a winder, and even if they did it by hand, it shouldn't have turned out with this tangled mess.  I will never go back to this store.

7.description: Love finding local yarn shops on my explorations, and Windy Knitty is a gem. They stock a wide variety of gorgeous yarns at a wide range of prices. Lots of patterns, needles, and accessories too. The sales associate was friendly and helpful, but also just let me browse and wander at whim. As a veteran knitter (over 20 years), I appreciate a thoughtful, well lit, well organized store, and Windy Knitty gets it all right.

36.description: I consider myself to be a somewhat critical person and I have yet to find a negative with this store.  Mandy, who owns the store, is super friendly and helpful.  The selection here is awesome.  The prices are competitive.  I kick myself for not going here more often, especially since it isn't very far away.  Every time I go here I love this store more.

30.description: Bright, spacious, colorful shop, good selection of quality yarns, helpful and knowledgeable staff, moderate pricing. Unlike many small yarn stores in which the owners seem bent on carrying tons of unusual, exotic, and novelty yarns no one has ever heard of or can afford to regularly use, this shop has some good mid-range products, including lots of the usual go-to brands, like Berrocco and Cascade. Worth a look.

3.description: I travel a lot and go to yarn stores wherever I land, and this is one of my favorites! Sometimes yarn stores can be a little too upscale fancy in the brands that they carry but this was not the case at Knitty City. It's beautifully curated for the trendy city knitter, and they carry everything from basics like Cascade to niche faves like Brooklyn Tweed and Mad Tosh. The must like color because the color selection was awesome. There aren't too many sample garments, but they do have a lot of swatches to help see how the yarns knit up.

14.description: I love Windy Knitty.  They are a friendly group of knitters and very helpful.  This was my first shop to go to for yarn.  Now I have come to the dark side.  Yarn everywhere.

12.description: I really like this place for loose leaf teas.  The selection is unbeatable and the prices are very reasonable--unlike some uppity, chain stores that charge an arm and a leg for a mere few ounces.  They also have tons of tea and coffee brewing paraphernalia, which also reasonably priced.  I bought a small, stove-top espresso maker and a French press from here--brand names you'd pay more elsewhere.This is definitely my go-to place to stock up on teas, coffees and other goods.

7.description: Today I visited this store for the third time with my partner. We are tea addicts! I also use a lot of spices in my ethnic cooking, so this place is perfect for us. The reviewers are right -  EXCELLENT assortment of bulk teas, cheap bulk spices, and fair prices overall. We've also purchased the nuts - the roasted and unsalted ones, YUMMY! You're not hassled, they're not pushy. So why only 2 stars? While we love their merchandise, the customer service is sub-par. Today, we went to the register with two teas and the total only came up to around $2. I was surprised it was so cheap and turned to my partner to see if he had cash. I didn't want to pay for such a paltry sum using my card. We didn't have cash. I asked the older man behind the register if he would take the card (I didn't see a sign for a minimum card purchase), and proceeded to get YELLED at! "NO THIS IS RIDICULOUS. $8 MINIMUM! CASH FOR THIS." I turned to my partner and told him to get more tea, while I grabbed some nuts. Our new total was $18, we paid with card, and left without saying a word. No apology, nothing.My White American and very culturally-competent partner played devil's advocate and attributed the interaction to a language barrier. But I've interacted with my fair share of middle easterners and Muslims in America because I'm one myself. I saw it for what it is: rudeness. Not sure if we'll come back here again...

19.description: Wow!  Such a remarkable transformation since the move.  The new store is very open and bright.  I assume this transformation means they are doing well, and I am really glad to see Pars benefiting from the growth around Andersonville.  Why do I come here?  Pars has the Best loose tea selection in Andersonville (or really anywhere on the north side) and the prices are more than reasonable.  My wife is a huge tea drinker and is never disappointed with the selection or quality.Pars also has all your Persian staples, including many bottled/jarred items, spices and seasonings and relatively cheap Basmati rice.   They sell all of the tea and coffee supplies you could need short of an espresso maker and they carry Bodum products which are top notch (though a bit fragile.)  The guy at the counter (the owner?) is very nice, but not overly friendly.  This is perfect for me as I like to peruse the store in search of new finds.  I always seem to have a good experience when I step in the door.

1.description: I accidentally stumbled upon this place while I was on my way to another store in andersonville. I am always looking for places that carry loose leaf tea and there was a sign in the window for it.First of all, the variety was surprisingly large. I prefer black tea and there were many to choose from. Secondly, they sell in (reasonable) bulk quantities. I also drink tea every day, so buying smaller amounts is ridiculous for me. In fact, after having been back a couple of times and asking for larger bags, the store owner started carrying bigger bags in which to fill with larger quantities of tea.Third, on my most recent visit, the store owner came and told me what kinds of tea were in each blend. He also made sure that I got a good mixture of the tea, giving me tips on stirring the leaves before I bagged them. He is SUPER nice.They also sell bulk spices and a variety of bulk nuts, as well as coffee and tea brewing items. It is a hidden gem.

2.description: Really fun shop with a big collection of items and some great teas. Definitely worth a stop to browse around.

9.description: I received a Christmas gift of an assortment of tea from Pars. So far, I've had two varities and both were just delicious. I can't wait to visit and to explore more of this store's offerings.

6.description: I love Pars Persian for its selection of affordable loose-leaf teas. They have pre-mixed selections such as Vanilla Raspberry Rooibos, Fruit of Pearls, and Apple Cinnamon, but they also have bulk selections of varietials of black, green, and rooibos teas, with jars where you can get other items (dried flowers, etc) to create your own tea blends. I go back about 4x a year to stock up!

18.description: A fantastic little hidden gem that has some of the best teas ive ever had. The tea selection is amazing and while not cheap, the quality is excellent. They also have a nice selection of spices and nuts.

10.description: Looks like a great place to get loose and bagged tea along with seasonings and spices if you know what you're looking for. They also have lots of knickknacky stuff and unique mini pots and hookahs.I walked in here with my sister and although there seemed to be a few people either working there or possibly just hanging out, we weren't acknowledged in the slightest bit. I walked in to find some saffron and as I walked through the place and didn't notice any, I walked back out. Had someone said hello, I would of felt less intimidated about asking about the wonderful spice. They didn't even look at us. Were we were invisible? I don't think I had my invisibility cloak on at the time so it didn't make much sense. Oh well, I may return, only if I cannot find saffron anywhere else since I know they do carry it from previous reviews.

13.description: Awesome selection of teas at great prices. Lots of unique spices also.

16.description: Love it.  Fantastic tea selection, as well as bulk spices.

17.description: Ah, this little authentic Persian market.....I love it.  Absolutely charming in every way and they carry my favorite Persian ice cream in the universe.  Made and packaged in Westwood, Los Angeles, I am convinced that this ice cream is karmically imported solely for MY benefit.  No, but really, you MUST try it.  This market and its owners/workers make my heart happy and I'm sure they will do the same for yours.

15.description: A very unique store, no joke!  Step in here and you think, WOOW!  Your eyes become dizzy from not being sure of what to look at.  Yet, you don't faint due to the peaceful scent of fresh teas.  They have hooka items, belly dancing outfits, furniture, foreign food products, pots and the TEA SELECTION!  Jeeez!  That's what reeled me in here.  They have a full wall of it and all at great prices.  They also have large plastic canisters of loose-leaf tea for $14.99 a pound (can't say I'd ever be able to drink that).  However, I disliked how these teas were not in air-sealed canisters, yet they did smell tea-licious.I mean the best teas origins do come from the Middle East, get yours here!

0.description: Pars Persian store, sells authentic Saffron, Persian tea,Turkish coffee, dried fruits, persian sweets, basmati rice, and middle eastern seasonings.  I usually get Persian tea Ahmad brand or Sadaf with cardamom flavor which has a very unique taste.  Mr. Haghighi, the owner, is such a friendly person, he is always kind and helpful. He also sells beautiful tea cup sets with middle eastern designs, fancy brewing pots, Persian rugs and all sort of amazing goods. It is a place to find a unique gift for a especial person.

5.description: I've become obsessed with Moroccan Mint tea since having it in Dubai, and I was so excited upon seeing this shop on a weekend stroll down Clark street. The selection of tea is huge, and the gentleman running the store was very kind and helpful. Very unique store with Persian jewelry, art, tea, coffee and also food and snacks. There was a really neat section in the back with old books in Arabic which was awesome.

11.description: I am in love with this store! I passed by it constantly for almost a year until I finally decided to go in. The sapphron and rose ice cream was the most delicious, unusual thing i've ever tasted. It's one of my favorites now and I thank Pars for having it there.

8.description: Great place for unique teas and persian specialties.  I like how no one hassles you here and let you browse to your content.

3.description: A wonderful store for affordable tea, coffee and spices.  All kinds of apparatus for coffee and tea as well.Tea -- global tea selections at bulk rate.  There are a few in a box as well.Moroccan Mint Tea -- smell and taste super duper minty.  Steeped for 5 mins, it tasted like the real deal from restaurants without the tedious process of traditional preparation.  I got this from the dark green big bin.Coffee -- Mexican, Costa Rican and Jamaican beans etc.Arabic Coffee maker -- fancy design, all for $8.  Yay!

14.description: Went here looking for Persian tea similar to the one I had at Noon O Kebab. The woman working there was very nice after I started talking to her and willing to explain the many (at least 40+) different teas they carry. Although we sometimes had difficulty understanding each other, we were eventually able to figure it out and I picked out two delicious smelling teas. They carry all different varieties of tea including Japanese maatcha, which another customer had been looking all over for. Also picked up green cardamon which is supposed to be great for cooking and rose water.

4.description: I love this store! So many wonderful varies of loose tea & other goods. The owner is very friendly. I've moved out of the area but every chance I get to return, I still stop by to shop & visit!

58.description: Try a cannoli from the bakery. Very authentic. Seriously, the filling is imported straight from Italy. You will be transported. An amazing deal for $2.Wet your whistle with a quart of limeade from on the juice wall, made from actual fruit in the store - that's right, squeezed right out of the fruit right there - it's crisp and tart! So wonderful!And who needs Garrett's popcorn when they make even yummier versions fresh all day right in front of your eyes and the price is incredible for the same, but better flavor!Fresh floral designs are made on the spot by professional artists using high quality flowers; the same used in the Rose Bowl parade and the Miss America pageant.You can buy literally anything in the store and the grill chefs will cook it for you, FOR FREE. Seriously. Free. Any way you want it. Hello, night off from the slaving over the stove!And the chicken salad in the deli is so comforting and good. It's like a hug for your tastebuds.I buy my coffee there every morning. Better than the mcdonalds across the street for the same price and hello, the tenth one is free.Ohhhhhhhhhh, and a new thing they have in the gelato bar, lemon-basil flavored heaven. Do it. It's really something! Again, the tenth one is free with a Mariano's card!I love this store. The staff is so friendly and helpful and the prices are very fair. I've been shopping there consistently since the day they opened and they're only getting better.

56.description: This location is the only Mariano's I've been to.  When I was last in the city, it was a Dominick's.  While the store is a little small, I was really impressed with both the variety of food, and the quality.  In the produce department, they carry a salsa that is just great!  I was impressed all the way around with it.  The only negative was that the cashiers could have been a little friendlier.We'll be back the next time we're in the neighborhood!

29.description: Some of the wait staff are good here, some of them frankly suck. I think its a combination of overworked and underpaid, and just plain bad management. Today I asked for a Paris sandwich with a Kaiser roll in place of the pretzel bun and the guy looked at me like I was from outer space. He said, "I don't know what a Kaiser roll is." Well he gave me one last time and I don't expect him to remember one time in the past but then he was a bit insulting as if I must be imagining things. Then I actually had to go to the bakery, have one Kaiser roll priced out for him to make the sandwich. They made one for me at the Mariano's in Ravenswood mind you with no problem, a much better store! I actually don't know why I went through all this, maybe because if a place is advertising sandwiches you should be able to get one, and I don't like pretzel buns lol. Meanwhile, he's serving up crusted over, dried out, and overcooked pizza left and right. The pizza there is pretty bad.

42.description: The store runs very smoothly. The  pleasing layout and organization makes you want to stay and shop more. Love the piano playing. Cheese and wine area is great. Selection overall is impressive, unique yet well rounded. Customer service is touch and go at times. It depends on the day and the amount of hs to college kids behind the checkout counter - you can get anywhere from a smile to a hood-like grimace. The cashiers are also not happy when you ask for paper bags for some reason. It's beyond me. The amount of grunting and displeasure from cashiers when you prefer paper is really ridiculous. lol Maybe it's really tiring to double the bag? They actually only offer you plastic.... they always say "is plastic okay?" - Nah. its not okay actually. These are management issues, clearly. Staff should be more friendly and courteous. Thats what should always make Marianos stand out.

23.description: I'm all about customer service no matter how good the product is.  It is about the delivery of that product or how well you present yourself with it.  Attitude matters.  We all work with people regardless of your position in business and that said, the  workers there are, as I put it bluntly, suck.  They don't smile nor greet you.  They aren't very good listeners either.  You ask them where you can find a product and they go off on something completely different or instead of admitting that you DON'T KNOW, why don't you just say something like "Let me see if I can get someone to help you".  I kid you not, hire some older people or train these wet behind the ears to make me feel like I want to shop there.  So your products and selections and even the prices are good.  Great, but where's your spirit?  Again, attitude.  Work on it.

47.description: I miss Dominicks. A lot. That being said, the only reason this location gets two stars is because some of the employees can be nice. Sometimes. The hot bar people can't cook your steak at this location. Don't ask about it. They will get not only confused, but angry. Also, I miss hard to find items that Dominick's had. I'm not positive why other Mariano's have them and this one doesn't. Considering the limited amount of grocery choices in the area it is a mystery why this one is so scaled down on options. But boy. Someone sure must think people in this neighborhood drink a lot of juice....I was reading someone else's review and they had an a very good point. The greeting card/piano player area is taking up a huge amount of real estate. Put food there. It seems Mr. Mariano thinks people in this neighborhood don't have money to spend on quality and hard to find products.

8.description: I shop at this Marianos location frequently and I always end up buying something extra! I love that this location is always clean and that they always have everything stocked. They always have samples no matter when I go- for instance today they had a sample of elis cheesecake and a pizza which I walked by. Today they also had a piano player playing different kinds of music like beethovens fur elise and more current songs like sam smith. Ilove the way they have the layout of the wines and cakes at the back-my favorite place to go! Overall, I love grocery shopping here, the only reason I would give it 4 stars and not 5 is that some of the things are a little overpriced but for the most part, the shopping experience is always great  and I would highly recommend it!

31.description: I've given this Mariano's 4.5 stars in the past, but things aren't going as well at this location lately. 1) The "cafe" section in the front- where you can take a rest while getting your meat item cooked or wait for the next bus or whatever is a no-go, because it's always full of homeless/elderly/mentally ill folks and CTA drivers. Its crowded, usually pretty dirty, and I'm disappointed that Marianos let this area go to sh*t. Couldn't predict THAT happening in Edgewater! Police this area a little bit, Marianos!2) M&M cookies from the bakery. A dozen, and 85% of the time soft, delicious, perfect. 15% hard and crappy, but it's a gamble. Well- haven't been able to find them at all, and last time the bakery guy told me that they are discontinuing them, despite the fact that they usually sell out. Yeah- great idea. Get rid of the thing that sells. 3) Missing random items. I only splurge on Ben and Jerry's for one flavor, which they NEVER HAVE. (Phish Food) This is probably a good thing, but that's some BS. I couldn't find Amstel Light the last time I went. 6 packs of hershey bars were also on sale- and out. Dark chocolate 6 packs of bars were in stock, but not on sale. Granted, these are all items I do not need, but this is annoying. 4) Growing discontent among patrons and employees. Last week, a patron yelled- in general to all of us- "Can I get a MANAGER around here?!?!" You could feel the frustration in the air.Time for new management, methinks.

34.description: Very clean, friendly workers, fast checkout.

16.description: I've given this Mariano's 4.5 stars in the past, but things aren't going as well at this location lately. 1) The "cafe" section in the front- where you can take a rest while getting your meat item cooked or wait for the next bus or whatever is a no-go, because it's always full of homeless/elderly/mentally ill folks and CTA drivers. Its crowded, usually pretty dirty, and I'm disappointed that Marianos let this area go to sh*t. Couldn't predict THAT happening in Edgewater! Police this area a little bit, Marianos!2) M&M cookies from the bakery. A dozen, and 85% of the time soft, delicious, perfect. 15% hard and crappy, but it's a gamble. Well- haven't been able to find them at all, and last time the bakery guy told me that they are discontinuing them, despite the fact that they usually sell out. Yeah- great idea. Get rid of the thing that sells. 3) Missing random items. I only splurge on Ben and Jerry's for one flavor, which they NEVER HAVE. (Phish Food) This is probably a good thing, but that's some BS. I couldn't find Amstel Light the last time I went. 6 packs of hershey bars were also on sale- and out. Dark chocolate 6 packs of bars were in stock, but not on sale. Granted, these are all items I do not need, but this is annoying. 4) Growing discontent among patrons and employees. Last week, a patron yelled- in general to all of us- "Can I get a MANAGER around here?!?!" You could feel the frustration in the air.Time for new management, methinks.

13.description: The flowers we received for our Labor Day weekend wedding from Mariano's were wayyyyy beyond our expectations.  They were stunning!!Lisa in the floral department is patient, considerate, and willing to work within your budget.  We researched floral for a long LONG time and this by far was the option that gave us the best value and the most beautiful floral pieces.  The bouquets, boutonnieres, wrist corsages, and centerpieces were all done by Lisa and her team. I highly recommend any bride to consider this option!

11.description: I live right down the street so this place is fine for a quick stop. However they really need some new management. Their deli counter is so slow unfriendly that I typically avoid it. One time I realized  it was the Deli manager waiting on me and I was shocked because his attitude seemed to suggest he'd rather have a root canal than wait on customers. Today however the guy helping me order a cake was very cheerful and helpful.I have asked several times why the produce is so nasty it has never been a great selection of freshness. Several times I've made produce purchases and they've spoiled in less than 3 days. This store is very disappointing. I still go back to the Jewel for my main shopping where the staff look alive and the veggies do too.

39.description: Wanted to check back in and give a update review.  Much better Jon, Catherine, and Russell (customer service) and  Sarah, Josh, and two other African American Women in catering are beyond professional!! Also the floor staff assistance has improved, gone are the Doe face looks when asking for help, instead they actually HELP. One young lady went above and beyond last night to help me find Knorr bouillon cubes. Keep up the great work!

37.description: I want to love this place but I've learned to be very aware of expiration dates. A couple of days ago I bought a chicken and opened it up a few hours later and nearly passed out from the stench. When I looked at the expiration date it was only 1 day old so clearly it wasn't stored properly. The two times I bought cold cuts from the deli, something was wrong with them. The turkey on one occasion tasted awful but I thought maybe it was just a new seasoning. The second time, the turkey was very dry and the ham had a slimy substance on it by day two.  How do you get a slimy substance on a 'fresh' cut ham? I think it may have been on sale but that's disgusting.The worst, though, was when I bought a CoffeeMate at the Ravenswood location (not my usual location). When I went to open it found it was over a month past the expiration date. Over a month??!!??While they always refund my money it's an added hassle. The fresh squeezed juice  keeps bringing me back but I now buy my deli meets at Treasure Island where they sell Boars Head and try to look at every expiration date when I need to buy from Marianos. So, a word of caution, based on my experience, check your expiration dates.

0.description: Bought a wedding cake from Costco and when I picked it up, it had white frosting with white lettering.  Didn't have time for them to fix it and had to stop by Mariano's on my way to work.  Stopped by the bakery and talked to Steve about what happened.  He told me he could fix it.  Ran to my car, brought in the cake and he fixed it in 5 minutes at no cost.  Employees like Steve are why I am loyal to Mariano's.  Thank you Steve for your great customer service!

38.description: The produce is terrible. Do they play racquetball with the apples and basketball with the melons? Every 1 in 3 pieces of fruit I bring home is bruised. And believe me, speaking from experience, I know damaged fruit. I sometimes end up back at Jewel down the block.Other than that, the people are great, the store is clean, everything is always stocked, and the shelves are all organized.

51.description: I really like the Mariano's on Foster and Sheridan. It is very convenient for me and I like that it is very clean and orderly. The staff are always very helpful. They don't always know the answer, but they will find someone who does.They have a wide selection of organic and gluten free items and the produce is pretty good.

27.description: corrected my granddaughter for running down the isles and mariano's thug security creating a scene.So I called CPD.
